title: 5 Surprising Bourbon Facts to Inform Your Next Cocktail Hour
post_content:
Bourbon whiskey is the only liquor that originated in the United States, and it’s one of the most popular. In fact, many people prefer bourbon over all other whiskeys. Unlike other whiskeys, bourbon can’t be supplemented with added ingredients to change its color or flavor. But there’s a lot you don’t know about bourbon. Next time you take a long pull of your favorite make, ruminate on these interesting tidbits.

  1. 1. It Is the Most Strictly Regulated Spirit In the US

    The strict regulations that govern bourbon distillation are what account for its unique qualities and what make it the purest form of whiskey. In order to be labeled as bourbon, whiskey must be made from a mash that contains at least 51 percent corn — the rest can be barley, wheat or rye. The law stipulates that bourbon mash be distilled at 160 proof and barreled at 125 proof without additives of any kind. Crucially, the bourbon must be aged in a new charred oak barrel. The charring on the inside of the barrel is what gives it its flavor. Because the barrels used to age bourbon can’t be reused, bourbon distilleries often sell them to other distilleries, where they’re used to make Irish and Scotch whisky.

  2. 2. Bourbon Distilleries Aren’t Always in Kentucky

    Though bourbon does originate from Bourbon County, Kentucky and most of the major manufacturers of this whiskey are located there, bourbon doesn’t need to be made in Kentucky in order to be considered bourbon. Distilleries throughout the United States are free to make bourbon, as long as they use the distillation process laid forth in the Federal Standards of Identity for Bourbon, discussed above. All bourbon must, however, be made in the United States.

  3. 3. The Name Might Come From the Street — Not the Other Way Around

    Most people assume that bourbon gets its name from Bourbon County, Kentucky, where it was originally invented by Elijah Craig, the first person to age corn whiskey in charred oak barrels in 1789. While this might be the case, some historians believe that it actually takes its name from Bourbon Street in New Orleans, where Kentucky distillers were most likely to sell their corn whiskey in frontier days.

  4. 4. Climate Influences Bourbon’s Taste

    Kentucky bourbon is said to age much faster than Scotch and Irish whisky because the climate in Kentucky is so much hotter than the climate in Ireland and Scotland. Variations in the weather and temperature at which bourbon is aged can have a massive influence on the taste of the final product. Barrels that are aged in hotter weather — or even on the upper floors of the rick houses where whiskey barrels are stored — tend to have a sweeter, richer flavor.
    When a tornado struck Buffalo Trace Distillery in Frankfort, Kentucky in 2006, numerous barrels of whiskey were left exposed to the elements for months. When tapped, they were found to have a superior flavor to their counterparts that had not been left exposed.

  5. 5. Bourbon Distilleries Produced Penicillin During WWII

    When World War II broke out, the nation’s distilleries were pressed into service making fuel alcohol and penicillin. Penicillin, which was newly discovered at the time, is made via fermentation, so only distilleries were able to create it in the massive quantities necessary for the war effort.

Bourbon is a truly American invention, and one of the country’s most beloved spirits. The next time you and your friends are enjoying fine bourbon, you can regale them with your intimate knowledge of this American whiskey.

title: How to Build a Wine Collection From Scratch â€” And on a Budget
post_content:
You don’t need to have a huge wine cellar and a heap of spare cash on hand in order to build an impressive wine collection. As any wine collector can tell you, collecting wine isn’t about acquiring status symbols or showing off; it’s about enjoying the wines you love at various stages during their lifetimes. If you want to start a wine collection but you’re on a budget, never fear; you can start a fine collection with just a few hundred dollars, and add to it slowly over the years.

Find a Place to Store Your Wine

Collectors who buy investment wines — wines that will grow in value over the years until they can be sold for a profit — typically rent space in a wine storage facility where their purchases can be looked after by professionals. The casual collector storing wine for his or her own personal enjoyment doesn’t need to go that far, unless, of course, he or she lacks space at home.

You can store your wine collection in the basement, in a closet, or even in a kitchen cupboard — any place sheltered from heat, light and vibrations will do. If you plan to age some of your wines for years, you should store them in a wine refrigerator. Ideally, wine should be kept between 50 and 59 degrees Fahrenheit, although it can be allowed to get as warm as 68 degrees Fahrenheit. Extreme heat or cold as well as wild fluctuations in temperature can harm your wine.

Wine bottles should be stored on their sides so the cork doesn’t dry out and deteriorate, spoiling the wine. Don’t move the bottles around too much in storage, especially if you’re aging them for a long time. Keep your wine in a mildly humid environment where they’re sheltered from natural light — a windowless basement room is ideal.

Set a Budget

As with any hobby, it’s not always easy to decide how much you should spend on wine for your collection. But if you’re on a budget, you’ll be happy to know that you can get some good bottles of wine for around $25 to $30 apiece. You can often get good deals on wine “futures” from your favorites wineries. If you go this route, you’ll be buying bottles from vintages that have yet to be bottled, so you’ll be taking a chance. You can also get good get deals on end-of-vintage sales, though again, you’ll be taking a chance. If you’re on a budget, your best bet is to shop discount wine retailers.

Buy Wines You Like

For the casual collector, the whole point of a wine collection is to buy wines you’ll enjoy drinking later. Though you may want to add a few exquisite “trophy” wines to your collection, you’ll mostly want to stick to buying wines that you’ve already tasted or vintages from wineries that you know you’ll enjoy. When you find a wine you like, order a case or as many bottles as you can afford. That way, if you open a bottle and find it has not aged enough, you’ll have the opportunity to try it again a little later. If your budget won’t allow you to buy a whole case, you might get a mixed case for a discount; or you could even just buy a bottle or two when you can afford it.

Building up a wine collection from scratch is not as difficult as it sounds. If you choose your wine carefully and store it properly, it can give you decades of enjoyment.

title: Wine and Cheese: The Perfect Pair
post_content:
Pairing Wine with Cheese

Everyone knows that wine and cheese have a long history together. For many, a meal just isn’t a meal without a cheese course paired with the perfect wine. While the thought of creating the perfect combination might be daunting for some, it does not have to be.

We have favorite wines, and we have favorite cheeses, and we love to combine them. We’ll discuss a few of the most popular cheeses and look at the wines that complement them best. Before you know it, you’ll be an expert.

Bleu Cheese

Bleu cheese is one of the most assertive cheeses available, but it’s also one of the most popular. Bleu cheeses often have a number of different tastes simultaneously, and these can be salty, sweet, bitter and tangy.

Bleu cheese pairs best with a sweet wine that will offset the sharp flavor and complement the natural sweetness of the cheese. We love the Fonseca 10 Year Tawny Port with bleu cheese as the acidity and richness of this port highlights the salt and acid flavors of the cheese perfectly.

Cheddar

Many people might view cheddar as a fairly mundane cheese that lacks some of the character that is abundantly present in other, more elegant types of cheese. The truth is that cheddar is a rich and complex cheese that deserves more credit.

As cheddar is a mature cheese with a great deal of robust flavor, it calls for a wine that can stand up to it. Red zinfandels or cabernet sauvignons are best. We love the Earthquake Zinfandel from California, as its strong berry notes complement the intense flavor of the cheddar without overpowering it.

Manchego

Some people might not be familiar with this delightful Spanish sheep’s milk cheese, but it’s worth getting to know a little better. It has a tangy, nutty flavor that is long on the palate and salty at the finish.

Ideally Manchego should be paired with a Spanish wine as the core flavors are similar. We love the Bodegas Riojanas Vina Albina Reserva as this wine is exceptionally balanced and plays up the salt in the cheese with its strong and complex flavors.

Fresh Mozzarella

Distinctly different from the mozzarella found on pizza, the fresh version of this delicate cheese is a real treat that should be enjoyed more often. The true Italian version is made with buffalo’s milk and is smooth and sweet with a slightly salty tang.

Fresh mozzarella can be served with either a red or a white wine, but it’s best to choose from the wines produced in Italy. The Sartori di Verona Rosso is an elegant Italian wine with a sharp acidity beneath its floral notes and is a wonderful complement to the mild mozzarella.

Brie

A French cheese characterized by its soft, smooth texture, Brie is a staple in the cheese world and is quite popular. Typically spread on rustic breads or served with fruit, Brie is a sweet and mild cheese that pairs well with a number of wines.

Try Brie with a full-bodied and powerful red wine for the best combination of complex flavors. The E. Guigal Cotes du Rhone is a rich and robust wine, with berry notes and high tannins that meld perfectly with the sweet flavors of the Brie.

Learning to pair wine and cheese can take some practice, but imagine all the fun you’ll have while doing it!

 

Cheese board image by ulterior epicure from Flickr’s Creative Commons

Wine and cheese image by pkingDesign from Flickr’s Creative Commons

title: The City Wine Cellar Guide to Food and Wine Pairing
post_content:
If you research food and wine pairings you’re likely to run into lists of “rules.” Usually those lists begin with the No. 1 rule: Drink what you like. While this is absolutely true (it is certainly important that you enjoy the wine in your glass), I do believe that there are some fundamental guidelines that can give you a base to understand an intricate subject.

I don’t like to drink in terms of “rules.” Wine is meant to be fun and enjoyable, not intimidating. So, let’s dispense with the idea that there are any official rules to pairing wine with food. Instead, let’s talk in terms of recommendations that will help you get the most out of any dining experience where wine is involved. Who knows, maybe you’ll even have an “ah ha!” moment with that perfect pairing.

For me, the primary focus of any food and wine pairing is synergy — creating something that tastes better than the individual components do on their own (that “ah ha!” moment I referred to). It is also about balance. The food should not overpower the wine, nor should the wine overpower the food.

Pay attention to the following elements of food and wine:

Complementing Flavors

The taste of the food and the wine should be similar. A sauce shouldn’t be sweeter than the wine, and the acid in the dish should be sufficiently matched to the acid levels in the wine. More on this below.

Contrasting Flavors

Opposites attract. Match up contrasting flavors such as sweet wine with a salty dish, or sweet wine with a spicy dish. Or even a light, high-acid wine, with a rich fatty dish.

Body and Weight

The weight of a dish should be matched by the weight of the wine.

When it comes to detecting weight in wine, the best analogy is to compare wine to skim milk, whole milk and heavy cream. Skim milk is light on the palate. The more you move toward heavy cream, the heavier it feels on your palate. Light-bodied wines, pinot gris for example, feel more like skim milk, whereas full-bodied wines, like syrah or zinfandel, are closer to that whole-milk feel. Both white and red wines can fit into both categories, light-bodied and full-bodied.

Pair full-bodied dishes with full-bodied wines — stewed meat in a rich sauce paired with full-bodied red wine like merlot or syrah. Avoid heavy stewed dishes like this with pinot noir (for example), since most are delicate and lighter in body and will be overpowered by a heavy rich dish like this.

Medium with medium — like shrimp scampi with a lightly oaked white wine. Avoid having shrimp scampi with a heavy red wine because both the light flavors of the dish and the lemon will clash with a heavy red wine.

Light with light — light white fish with unoaked, light-bodied white wine. Just as in the medium example given above, a heavy wine will overpower a light or delicate dish.

Oak usage in wine will generally translate to a heavier feel on your palate. Some wines state on the label whether they have been aged in oak. Others won’t. If you are unsure, it’s best to ask the wine steward in your wine shop or liquor store if the wine has been aged in oak.

Sweetness

The sweetness of a dish should be matched to or exceeded by the sweetness of the wine (otherwise a dry wine tastes sour and unpleasant). This can be especially difficult to do with desserts, which is why pairing wine and chocolate can be tricky — but not impossible! Sweet wines also pair well with a contrasting flavor, like spicy food. This is because sweet wines can help to cool and refresh the palate after a bite of something with a spicy kick to it. An example of a wine that can be sweet is riesling. Some riesling wines have a useful scale on the back of the label that lets you know the sweetness level of the wine.

If a wine is described as “dry,” it usually has zero to very little sweetness.

Acidity

Acid is an important factor to consider, and it is found in both food and wine. It’s what keeps a wine lively on the palate and gives it an innate ability to pair with food because it acts as a palate cleanser. Good acidity in wine can be detected by a sharpness or jolt in the mouth, usually near the front of your tongue, followed by your mouth starting to water. The more your mouth begins to water, the higher the acidity.

When it comes to pairing, the acidity of the dish should be matched by the acidity in the wine.

If the food is more acidic than the wine, then the wine will taste flabby or flat. Flabby? Think about what happens to soda when the carbonation wears off. The soda becomes flat, uninteresting, and all you taste is the sugar. Would you like to test this out? Try tasting a salad with lemon and vinegar based dressing (two ingredients that are very high in acidity) paired with a viognier or an oaked chardonnay. The wine, which has much less acidity than the dressing, will taste unbalanced and flat paired with the high-acid dish, but with a high-acid wine, like Sauvignon Blanc, it can work quite well.

This is one of the reasons why Chianti (made from sangiovese grapes, which are high in acidity) and spaghetti or pizza (made with tomato sauce) pair so well. The tomatoes are high in acid, and the sauce is usually medium-heavy bodied. Both go well with a wine that is matched in weight and also high in acid.

Generally speaking, wines from cooler climates tend to display higher levels of acidity. Wines that are generally high in acid include (but are not limited to): sparkling wine, sauvignon blanc, riesling, pinot gris/grigio, sangiovese, and pinot noir.

Intensity

If a food is intense in flavor, then the wine should also be intense in flavor. You want a similar level of intensity, not combative. This is why barbecued foods or dishes with rich heavy sauces go better with big, bold intense wines like zinfandel, tempranillo, and syrah.

Intense wines can stand up to fuller-bodied foods. Bold and intense wines, however, will overpower delicate, lightweight, dishes. Similarly, light-bodied or delicate wines don’t stand a chance with heavy, rich, bold dishes — the wine will get lost in the bold flavors of the food.

Fruit, Vegetable, Herbs

What a dish offers in fruit, vegetables, and herbs can be complemented by similar or contrasting notes in the wine. For example, a light vegetable dish with lots of fresh herbs will pair well with a grüner veltliner, which is a white wine that offers lots of herbal elements. Or, grilled shrimp with fresh lemon squeezed over the top will pair nicely with a wine that offers citrus flavors such as sauvignon blanc.

Additional Pairing Tips

Pair complex wines with simple dishes such as a simple roast paired with aged, quality red wine, like an aged Bordeaux. In this case, the wine is likely something special or unique so you want the wine to stand out but not be overpowered by the food, and you want to be able to focus on the complexities of the wine without interference from the dish.

Alternatively, pair simple wines with more complicated dishes. A spicy Asian dish that has several ingredients could pair with a simple semi-sweet white wine. Here, you’re also incorporating contrasting flavors, balancing the spicy and sweet.

Think regional pairing — what grows together goes together. Goat’s cheese with Sancerre (made from sauvignon blanc grapes) is a traditional pairing demonstrating this, and it’s one of my favorites. Italian red wines go with pasta. Spanish wines pair with tapas. Pacific salmon with Oregon pinot noir is also a no-brainer and another one of my favorites.

Components That Interact

Alcohol accentuates heat. Try tasting a high-alcohol wine like a zinfandel that has more than 15% ABV paired with a really spicy dish. Everything, both the wine and the dish, will taste hotter (the food will seem spicier and the wine will seem more alcoholic).

Sweetness reduces perception of sweetness. When you taste a sweet wine paired with an equally sweet dish, you notice the perceived sweetness less. When paired just right, they balance each other out.

Fat and protein reduce perception of tannin. This is why red meat and young cabernet sauvignon go so well together. The protein and fat from the beef soften the mouth-drying tannins that come from the wine.

Salt also reduces perception of tannin. Try melting salty blue cheese on a steak and pairing it with a cabernet sauvignon or a tempranillo from Rioja or Ribera del Duero. The salt also reduces the otherwise noticeable tannins of the wine.

Drink What You Like

Like I said earlier, nearly every wine expert will tell you that the No.1 rule of wine drinking is Drink what you like. And while this sentiment is true, I do firmly believe if you want to get the best out of both your food and your wine, there are recommendations you can follow to make the most of your experience. And if you’re the type to just drink what you like anyway, then why did you make it to the end of this article?

 

By Mary Cressler, Certified Sommelier

Mary Cressler is a wine educator, Certified Sommelier through the Court of Master Sommeliers, and founder of Vindulge: Wine Education & Consulting — a wine consulting company focusing on enhancing consumers’ wine experience through classes, seminars, private buying in addition to commercial consulting.

A frequent tasting panelist and judge for wine competitions, Mary also speaks at conferences and events on various aspects of wine. She is also author of the blog Vindulgeblog.com.

She has a special affinity for pairing wine with barbecue and loves all things sparkling wine. For more information, you can send Mary an email at mary@vindulge.com or visit her website at Vindulge.com.

title: 4 Sparkling Wines That Wonâ€™t Break the Bank
post_content:
By now, we should all be aware that we can’t call a sparkling wine by the name Champagne unless it has indeed come from the Champagne region of France. We also know that true Champagne can be one of the most expensive wines in the world.

For those with tighter purse strings, there are many fine selections of sparkling wines from around the world that allow you a fizzy wine that won’t significantly deplete your savings. While there are occasions when true Champagne is preferable, for all of the other times there are these exceptional choices.

1 – Coppola Sofia Blanc de Blanc

A gem from the famed Coppola vineyard, this sparkling wine packs a fruity punch then soothes with a crisp finish. It’s a delicate and bold blend of pinot blanc, sauvignon blanc and muscat grapes.

This bottle is a great accompaniment for a light brunch, a charcuterie or as the perfect beverage for a picnic of fruit and cheese. In short, we love this sparkling wine and the $13.99 price doesn’t hurt the wallet.

2 – Korbel Brut

The California Korbel Brut has been the sparkling wine of choice for weddings and other celebrations in the United States, and it’s easy for us to see why. We enjoy this crisp, dry brut, and its spicy notes keep the wine from coming off cloying.

Not only does the Korbel Brut have exceptional drinkability, but it pairs well with food. Try it with an herb roasted chicken or a rosemary and salt crusted pork tenderloin. It can also complement Asian dishes like a creamy Thai green curry or a spicy Szechuan noodle dish.

At $25.99 per bottle, drinkers could easily use this sparkling wine for weddings or other festivities.

3 – Llopart Rose Cava Brut Reserva

We can’t have a non-Champagne discussion without including Spain’s contribution to the sparkling wine world. Cava is one of our favorite sparkling wines, and we love to talk about it.

This Llopart brut is bright and aromatic, and its delicate pink color belies the boldness of its flavors. Fruity top notes mesh seamlessly with the acidity of the tannins, and the tastes come together in a perfect example of Spanish cava.

Try this wine with any type of spicy food, but a good paella would, in our opinion, be the perfect dish to pair with this Spanish beauty.

At $19.99 this bottle is worth a try.

4 – Martini and Rossi Asti

This isn’t our mother’s Asti! Gone are the days when this wine was called Asti Spumante. Although this Italian sparkling wine from the Piedmont region is still crafted in the traditional ways, their image has been revamped and they’ve shortened and modernized their name.

This wine is considered lightly sparkling; therefore it creates a very different mouth feel. The fruit flavors are crisp and clean, and the body of this wine is extraordinarily light. It’s the perfect wine to pair with a light lunch of cheese, fruit and grilled chicken or with fish that’s dressed in a light butter sauce.

At $12.99 per bottle, we love the price as much as we love the wine.

These sparkling wines offer all of the flavor and body of their more expensive cousins, but won’t cost a fortune. You can try one of these at your next celebration or explore the wide world of sparkling wines for yourself.

 

Bubbles image by Gaetan Lee from Wikimedia Commons

This bottle is a great accompaniment for a light brunch, a charcuterie or as the perfect beverage for a picnic of fruit and cheese. In short, we love this sparkling wine and the $13.99 price doesn’t hurt the wallet.

2 – Korbel Brut

The California Korbel Brut has been the sparkling wine of choice for weddings and other celebrations in the United States, and it’s easy for us to see why. We enjoy this crisp, dry brut, and its spicy notes keep the wine from coming off cloying.

Not only does the Korbel Brut have exceptional drinkability, but it pairs well with food. Try it with an herb roasted chicken or a rosemary and salt crusted pork tenderloin. It can also complement Asian dishes like a creamy Thai green curry or a spicy Szechuan noodle dish.

At $25.99 per bottle, drinkers could easily use this sparkling wine for weddings or other festivities.

3 – Llopart Rose Cava Brut Reserva

We can’t have a non-Champagne discussion without including Spain’s contribution to the sparkling wine world. Cava is one of our favorite sparkling wines, and we love to talk about it.

This Llopart brut is bright and aromatic, and its delicate pink color belies the boldness of its flavors. Fruity top notes mesh seamlessly with the acidity of the tannins, and the tastes come together in a perfect example of Spanish cava.

Try this wine with any type of spicy food, but a good paella would, in our opinion, be the perfect dish to pair with this Spanish beauty.

At $19.99 this bottle is worth a try.

4 – Martini and Rossi Asti

This isn’t our mother’s Asti! Gone are the days when this wine was called Asti Spumante. Although this Italian sparkling wine from the Piedmont region is still crafted in the traditional ways, their image has been revamped and they’ve shortened and modernized their name.

This wine is considered lightly sparkling; therefore it creates a very different mouth feel. The fruit flavors are crisp and clean, and the body of this wine is extraordinarily light. It’s the perfect wine to pair with a light lunch of cheese, fruit and grilled chicken or with fish that’s dressed in a light butter sauce.

At $12.99 per bottle, we love the price as much as we love the wine.

These sparkling wines offer all of the flavor and body of their more expensive cousins, but won’t cost a fortune. You can try one of these at your next celebration or explore the wide world of sparkling wines for yourself.

title: 3 Fantastic Cocktails for Your Spring Party
post_content:
Spring is just around the corner and we simply can’t wait! Once the winter weather ends, we’re definitely ready to throw a party to welcome the season. There are many different themes associated with a spring party, but the ones that we love best are certainly the cocktails!

Springtime cocktails should be fruity and refreshing, and they should definitely use as many fresh ingredients as possible. Let’s take a look at some of our favorite cocktails recipes that are sure to make your spring get together the best one yet.

1 – Strawberry Basil Margarita

Who doesn’t love a margarita? The combination of tequila and fresh citrus is refreshing and very pleasing to the palate. There are many variations of this cocktail, but this one that uses fresh strawberries and basil is something special.

This drink is best made by the pitcher. Combine one can of limeade concentrate with two cups each water and tequila. We prefer the Cazadores Reposado for this one, as it has an earthy taste that is perfect for this recipe. Add a dozen sliced strawberries and a handful of crushed basil leaves. Stir the mixture well and place in the refrigerator for at least four hours.

Once the flavors have melded, your margarita mixture will be a delicate pink color. Serve over ice and garnish with a strawberry slice and a small sprig of basil.

2 – Gin and Tonic with Cucumber and Rosemary

Who doesn’t love a gin and tonic? This cocktail classic is about as refreshing as they come, and they’re perfect for warm spring days. While the gin and tonic is typically garnished with a simple lime wedge to let the flavors of the spirit shine, this version accents the gin with classic cucumber and bold rosemary.

As always, it’s best to start with a premium gin. Hendrick’s gin is a superb choice as the natural botanical flavors really come through. Another good choice is Caledonia Spirits Barr Hill gin, which adds a touch of local Vermont honey to their recipe.

Begin by peeling half of a large cucumber and slicing the lime into thin wedges. Add one and half ounces of the gin to a glass then add two peeled cucumber slices, the juice of one lime wedge, and a sprig of rosemary. Muddle this well, then strain over ice into a highball glass, then top with tonic. Garnish with a cucumber slice and a sprig of rosemary.

The rosemary in this drink plays well with the botanicals of the gin, creating the perfect balance.

3 – St. Germain and Champagne Cocktail

This delightful twist on a traditional champagne cocktail is simple to make and adds a touch of elegance to a spring function. The elderflower essence of the St. Germain complements a crisp, dry champagne perfectly.

Simply shake one ounce of the St. Germain with ice for a few seconds, strain into a champagne flute, and top with champagne. We love the Perrier Jouet Grand Brut for this cocktail, as its floral and mineral notes blend seamlessly with the St. Germain.

Spring is coming up quickly, so while you wait out the last of winter, start planning your spring get together and add one of these gorgeous and delicious drinks to your menu. Your guests will thank you.

title: The Geography of Wine
post_content:
For those of us at home in the United States, choosing wines from different regions can be a difficult and sometimes daunting choice. The great thing is that here in the U.S. we’ve got a huge selection of wines from all over the world to choose from. Californian wines, particularly the ones from the Napa Valley, have huge status and the added bonus of buying a domestic product.

If you’re lucky enough to live in a wine-producing region, then you probably have a few local vintners you should try to seek out and taste. If you’re trying Californian, then you have a huge variety to choose from — there are over 100 different varieties of grape grown here. Two of the leading varieties in California are chardonnay and Cabernet sauvignon. Ask your typical Spaniard on the street whether he or she prefers Spanish or French red wine with dinner, and you’re likely to get a lesson in European history as well as a clear show of nationalism. For some, the choice of what wine to drink with dinner is a personal, political and even patriotic decision.

Staying in the Americas, Chilean and Argentinian wines are also popular. In fact, Argentina is one of the top five wine-producing regions in the world. When the Spanish colonized South America, they brought grape vines and knowledge of viticulture with them. Later, immigrants from other regions contributed to the development of local wine-making, including vintners from France and Italy. Chile’s best-known exports are its cabernet and sauvignon blanc wines, while bottles of malbec are the hot commodity from Argentina. Argentinian wines are often known for their intense flavor.

Across the Pacific in Australia, the wealth of wines available will suit almost any occasion. Australia has over 60 designated wine-making regions and each of those have their own star grapes and tailored appeal. Though it’s hard to generalize, from New South Wales, you’ll find some of the more traditional, established vintners, though South Australia and Western Australia also have long histories of wine-making. The top grape Down Under is shiraz, though cabernet sauvignon is also popular. Australian wine is becoming more and more popular with consumers because of its overall level of quality between expensive and inexpensive bottles.

Europe has so many different wine regions you could fill a library with books about them. French and Spanish wines are go-to bottles to impress dinner guests, while Italian wines make a fine, earthy companion to any meal. Some of the most popular Italian wines to try are barbaresco, from Piedmont, and, of course, Chianti. For white wine from Europe, you’ll find many great varieties from the countries just mentioned, or you might branch out into German or Austrian wines. While grapes for red wine need more sunlight to create a full-bodied flavor, white wines from northern climates are also distinctive and delicious. Reisling and müller-thurgau wines are two of the most important German wine varieties.

For more information about which wine is best for your table or at your next event, please contact us.

title: The Perfect Bloody Mary
post_content:
If there’s one cocktail that we love, it’s the Bloody Mary. This classic drink goes perfectly with a Sunday breakfast or brunch, and it’s an excellent accompaniment while watching a football game.

The origin of this cocktail is murky. Some claim a bartender in Paris first created the drink in 1921, while others attribute its invention to a bartender at New York’s 21 Club in the 1930s. Regardless of its inception, the Bloody Mary has consistently been a top seller at bars (and brunches) around the world for years.

As always, recipes for this drink vary widely, but the crux of the combination of ingredients is certainly the tomato juice and vodka. We’ll let you in on our secret list of added spices and flavors so that you too can create our favorite Bloody Mary.

 

The Vodka

Of course, the Bloody Mary’s success depends greatly on the vodka that is used. Some people choose an inexpensive brand for their Bloody Mary, especially if they’ll be serving a large number of guests. A good choice would be Smirnoff or Stolichnaya as both of these vodkas have a smooth, pure taste that lets the other ingredients shine.

Some bartenders absolutely eschew the use of flavored vodka in the Bloody Mary, but we disagree. For those who like their Bloody Mary to pack a punch, consider the Absolut Citron or the Crop Tomato Vodka. Each of these flavored vodkas add complexity to the final product.

 

The Spices

Again, everyone is different, but we have a tried and true list of spices and other ingredients that makes our Bloody Mary sing. We start with eight ounces of fresh tomato juice and add two dashes each of celery salt and black pepper. A healthy dash of Worchestershire sauce is followed by a small dollop of horseradish and a few drops of Tabasco. Add a tablespoon each of olive brine and spicy pickled bean brine, then a squeeze of lemon. Stir the mixture well then combine your desired amount of the mix in a cocktail shaker with ice and vodka. Tumble or stir, then strain over ice.

Of course, each of these ingredients may be adjusted for taste, and some of them, like the pickled bean brine, may not be available to everyone. However, these ingredients are a good basic start.

 

The Garnish

The standard garnish for a Bloody Mary has typically been a celery stalk and a wedge of lime or lemon. While these garnishes are fine, why not change it up a bit? After all, one of the draws of the Bloody Mary cocktail is the edible goodies that come with it.

Consider something salty like a strip of bacon or a boiled shrimp. Add another salt element with a selection of pickled vegetables on a small skewer. A few olives can also pair nicely with a Bloody Mary, especially if they’re stuffed with garlic or bleu cheese.

The garnish is a great way to further personalize your version of the Bloody Mary, and it’s certain to have guests singing your praises.

Perfecting the perfect Bloody Mary takes time, but the rewards are definitely worth it. This spicy, tart, immensely satisfying cocktail is definitely a must for your next get together. Try our recipe and enjoy!

title: Raise Your Glass: The Best Wines for Celebrating
post_content:
Celebrating an anniversary? A new job? Getting ready for summer, Graduation Day or just “I feel great” day? For many, the act of celebrating is synonymous with the popping cork of a champagne bottle.

 

Wine by Itself

If you’re planning on drinking the wine as a toast, without any canapes, entrees or other flavors to compete with, then the classic choice is sparkling wine. From the pop of the cork to the dizzy effervescence and crisp, light flavor, sparkling wine will help highlight your celebration. For many of us, the idea of “bringing out the Champagne” is synonymous with celebrating, but you don’t have to stick only with the French import —there are many other region’s products to consider as well.

Californian sparkling wine is a hit with many during the holidays, while Italian prosecco and Spanish cava also provide a bit of bubble for your special moment.

 

Wine With Dinner

If you’re celebrating over dinner, then popping the cork on a fine bottle of red or white wine will also add pomp to the occasion.

Make a statement by serving your guests a wine from the Chateauneuf de Pape region in France, or, serve a bottle of top-shelf Rioja from Spain. Red wines from this region are balanced and full of flavor.

If you prefer white wine with your meal, pour your fellow celebrants a glass or two of Italy’s favorite pinot grigio. A crisp, dry wine, the best-reviewed from this variety come from the Alto Adige region.

 

Wine With Cake

Some announcements are best served with something sweet, so if you’re planning on cake with your celebration, such as an office birthday party, you might choose to offer a dessert wine as well.

Ice wine, especially from Canada or Germany, is a smooth, sweet drink that pairs well with cake but is equally delicious on its own. Though the name comes from the harvesting and preparation process — the grapes are picked when frozen — and it is best served ice-cold.

If you won’t be able to chill your wine before serving, then perhaps Port is another will fit your celebration better. When buying this sweet, fortified wine from Portugal, choose a tawny or late bottled vintage (LBV) for best quality.

 

Wine for Non-wine Drinkers

For those who seldom choose wine, simply having it once can be a mark of celebration. If you don’t usually drink wine, but you would like to serve it, most experts recommend sticking with wines that are sweet and not dry. For example, rieslings from Germany are often described as light and delicate, and have relatively low alcohol content. Zinfandels are also good for new wine drinkers, though they tend to be more fruity.

If you’d prefer a red wine, or if that’s what suits your pairings best, then a pinot noir may be a better bet as it’s more light-bodied than most reds and goes well with a large variety of food flavors.

And, whatever you choose, congratulations!

title: Irish Whiskey Wars - Irish or Scotch?
post_content:
We’re aware of the distinct differences between Irish whiskey and Scotch whisky, the least of which is the addition or subtraction of the letter e in the name. Irish whiskey has a much softer taste and lacks some of the characteristic smoke flavor that some Scotch whisky has in abundance.

Still, there are some very apparent differences between Irish whiskies, and those are definitely worth looking into. Let’s investigate a little of the history of the top Irish whiskies, Jameson and Bushmills, and see why each whiskey has its own fierce supporters.

 

Jameson

While we try to never play favorites, it’s hard not to prefer this Irish whiskey over any other. It more closely resembles Scotch, and while that’s not the ultimate intention, its subtle woodsy and smoky flavors make Jameson a star.

Jameson’s was first brewed in 1780 when the Scotsman John Jameson purchased the Bow Street Distillery in Dublin. His whiskey soon became the most popular Irish whiskey brand in the world. By the year 1800, Jameson was producing over a million gallons of whiskey per year.

Jameson whiskey is a mixture of malted and unmalted Irish barley and is therefore considered a blended whiskey. The Jameson brand has persevered through many hardships over the years, including various wars, United States prohibition and fierce competitors, but it is now the bestselling Irish whiskey in the world.

 

Bushmills

King James I of England granted a distillery license to Sir Thomas Phillips in 1608, but the whiskey wasn’t produced under the Bushmills name until 1784. The distillery has changed hands many times over the years and is currently owned by liquor conglomerate Diageo. Located in County Antrim, the Bushmills brand, while not quite able to reach the sales of Jameson, has consistently produced a range of fine products.

Bushmills has more of a light taste, and the flavors evoke citrus and honey. The product is aged in the same types of barrels as other Irish whiskeys, ports and bourbons, but the final flavors of each whiskey are subtly different.

 

The Whiskey Controversy

Ask any fan of Irish whiskey which brand they prefer and you’re likely to get a very spirited response. Drinkers of either Bushmills or Jameson have very specific reasons why they choose one over the other, and while the taste may be one factor, it’s sometimes not the main one.

Jameson whiskey is brewed in the southern part of Ireland, officially called the Republic of Ireland, and the area is predominantly Catholic. Bushmills is brewed in Northern Ireland, which is a constituent of the United Kingdom and is predominantly Protestant.

The conflict between the two Irelands is ongoing, but many experts feel that it should have no impact on Irish whiskey, except Irish Americans. In fact, it’s those people of Irish descent who live in the United States who started the battle of Irish whiskeys in the first place.

The fact is that both distilleries are now owned by foreign companies, and the conflict between religions is no longer an issue in the creation and distribution of these whiskeys, if it ever was in the first place.

We love our Irish whiskies, and we hope that you will too. Whether you prefer Bushmills or Jameson, try it with a perfectly grilled steak or a fine cigar. You’ll be glad that you did.

 

Jameson image by Juergen Jauth from Flickr’s Creative Commons

Bushmills image by M Prince Photography from Flickr’s Creative Commons

title: How to Choose a Wine on a Budget
post_content:
Are you going to an event where you’re not sure you need to bring a gift, or just looking to jazz up some leftovers without cutting into your date night wine supply? There are plenty of times in life when a bottle of wine sounds like a great idea, but you don’t want to shell out a lot of cash for an expensive tipple.

Luckily, there’s plenty of wine, even imported wine, available today that is easy on both the palate and the pocketbook. How can a concerned consumer figure out which wine will taste best for less?

 

Ask An Expert

One of the best things you can do for your wine education is to start asking questions. The next time you visit a wine shop or bump into an off-duty sommelier start asking for recommendations. Don’t assume that experts will push you to the most expensive labels for a sale either; most experts in the wine industry truly love their product and will be interested in cultivating you as a long-term customer.

When you ask about the best wine for you, state your maximum price limit and give the person you’re asking an idea of when the wine will be imbibed. You’ll get a different recommendation if you’re pairing the wine with seafood, or with beef, or if you are taking it to a house party where you’re not quite sure what will be on the menu.

 

If You’re On Your Own

If there’s no one you can ask before you make your choice, you still have some rules of thumb that can guide to you to buying a nice bottle of wine that remains in your price range.

First of all, consider the basics. Do you want red or white wine? In general, if you are going to be drinking the wine while you eat something that has strong flavors, then you want to have a red wine. A steak or a hearty lasagna is complemented by a strong red table wine, such as a shiraz or a cabernet. Spicy foods can usually stand up next to red wine, as well. Following this rule, if you are planning to eat something with delicate flavors, then you’ll want a white wine. That would mean that your linguine with clam sauce or your grilled trout would do nicely with a pinot grigio or chardonnay.

If you are unsure which wine will suit your meal, or if you’re planning to enjoy the wine as an after-dinner drink, then you will have to use other criteria. If you like sweet drinks, then there are many fruity white wines available for $20 or less. Rieslings and sauvignon blancs are often citrusy and light.

On the red side, the less expensive Cabernet sauvignons will offer more body and less sweetness than white wine. Some of the Australian Cabernet or Shiraz blends offer great quality at a low price.

Still not sure? Contact us and we’ll help you decide.

title: Top 5 Whiskey Cocktails Everyone Should Know
post_content:
Although a few creative concoctions have surfaced over the years, sometimes it’s best to stick with the classics. We present to you the top whiskey cocktails that every connoisseur, professional or recreational, should know.

 

1. Old-Fashioned

A timeless choice with a simple rye whiskey base, easy to enhance with key ingredients, the Old-Fashioned has weathered many variations, but we think the original version triumphs over all the rest.

What you’ll need:

1 sugar cube

2-3 dashes of Angostura bitters

club soda or water (optional)

2 oz rye whiskey

ice cubes

orange

What you do:

Place sugar cube in glass and moisten with a few dashes of Angostura bitters and a skimpy splash (just a drop) of club soda or water. Crush the cube with a wooden muddler (if you don’t have one, you can improvise) until the sugar and liquid form a paste. Add whiskey, an ice cube (preferably one large cube), and a piece of orange peel. Stir and serve.

 

2. Manhattan

The Manhattan is undeniably one of the top whiskey cocktails around, as bold and beloved as the city itself.

What you’ll need:

2 oz rye whiskey

1 oz vermouth

2 dashes of Angostura bitters

maraschino cherries (optional)

What you do:

Stir (don’t shake) ice, whiskey, vermouth, and Angostura bitters well. Strain drink into glass and garnish with a maraschino cherry or two.

 

3. Ward Eight

A fan favorite for more than a hundred years, the Ward Eight mixes citrus juices and rye whiskey to create a smooth cocktail with little bite. Hardly a fancy find, the Ward Eight’s simple sour characteristics is what earned its recognition.

What you’ll need:

2 oz rye whiskey

3⁄4 oz orange juice

3⁄4 oz lemon juice

tsp grenadine

What you do:

Add whiskey, juices (preferably fresh squeezed), grenadine, and ice in a shaker. Shake, strain and serve over ice. For a lighter drink, mix with club soda.

 

4. John Collins

Not to be mistaken for a Tom Collins (made with gin) a John Collins is a refreshing bourbon based cocktail perfect for sipping during summer months.  

What you’ll need:

2 oz bourbon whiskey

1 oz lemon juice

1 tsp simple syrup

2 oz club soda

orange slice, lemon slice, maraschino cherry (optional garnishes)

ice

What you do:

In your shaker, add bourbon, lemon juice, simple syrup and ice. Shake, strain and serve over ice. Add club soda, stir and garnish to your preference.

 

5. Irish Coffee

No top whiskey cocktails list is complete without the Irish Coffee. Some may prefer the cheat recipe, solely mixing Baileys and coffee, but not us. Here is the authentic cocktail with all the ingredients.

What you’ll need:

2 oz Irish whiskey

6 oz hot coffee (freshly brewed is best)

2 tsp brown sugar (or more to taste)

heavy cream

What you do:

Spoon sugar into a glass mug, pour in hot coffee and stir well. Add whiskey and stir again to blend. Over an upside down spoon, slowly pour heavy cream (best if whipped before) and serve immediately (do not stir).

title: Wine Aging
post_content:
Street wisdom regarding wine tells us that the older wine is, the better it is. However, this is not always true. Understanding how aging works will contribute to your understanding of when a wine is right to drink or not. As you’re building your collection, make sure that you’re building your knowledge so that the wines that need to wait will have their time, and the wines that have a shorter shelf life can be enjoyed as well.

Although many believe that aged wine is best, surprisingly only 10% of wines produced actually have the chemical ability to age at all. This means that over 90% of wines are meant to be enjoyed within only a few years. Wine is always perishable, but understanding the properties of a wine’s sugars, acids, compounds, an tannins are essential to determining what a wine’s ideal aging process should be.

The first step to skillfully aging wine is to make sure you have the proper conditions for storing it. You’ll need a wine storage rack inside of a dark, damp, and quiet space. The more out of the way from activity the best, as you want your wine to be free from vibrations. It might be tempting to store red wine in the refrigerator, but avoid this temptation: low humidity will cause corks to shrink and the wine will spoil. Also, you want to make sure your corks stay moist by storing wine tilted sideways or upside down. Again, if the cork dries, the wine could spoil.

The strategy behind aging can be complex, as it varies between wines and requires attention to a variety of chemical details. For example, tannins – a chemical found in wines – have enormous influence over the aging, color, body, flavor, and dryness of a wine. As time passes, these tannins break down and form a visible sediment at the bottom of the bottle. This creates a sort of brick, rusty coloring. Also, wines with a low Ph also have greater capability of aging. In white wines, sugar performs similarly to tannins and helps to preserve the wine. The white wines with the capabilities of aging are the ones with the highest level of extract and acidity. Additionally, the quantity of water inside of a grape prior to harvest affects its ability to age: the less water, the more aging.

The best advice to remember is that every wine reaches a point where it is ideal to drink. Too much aging, and the best qualities of the wine are missed; too little aging and the wine might be consumed prematurely. Without the right knowledge of your wines, you might end up holding onto a bottle for far too long. Once you know the aging strategies appropriate for your wines and you are able to store them properly, then you will be on your way to having a magnificent collection.
meta_keywords: Wine Aging, Wine Storage, Red Wine, Ageing
meta_description: Strategies behind wine aging, what wines to age, ideal wine aging time, and why you want to age some of your wines.

title: Types of flaws in wine
post_content:
Nothing in this world is perfect and wine is no different. The process of making wine must be handled carefully. Wine is a very delicate drink and a lot can go wrong even after it leaves the vineyard. From the vineyard to your glass one little slip up could cause it to go bad or to become undrinkable. As such, you should pay special attention to its flavor, texture and color before you start drinking.

Unbalanced. A balanced wine is a good wine: none of the its elements sticks out or covers the others. Generally speaking, for red wines, it is desirable to achieve balance in the fruit, tannin, and acidity levels. Since whites generally lack tannins, only the fruit and acidity need to be balanced. Most fine wines cannot become balanced if they do not benefit from a certain number of years of bottle age.

Oxygen. A lot of oxygen is required during the fermentation process of the wine and the ageing process in the barrels. Nevertheless, oxygen is still an enemy to everyone in the wine world. Too much oxygen can cause wine to spoil. If a wine is exposed to too much oxygen, for whatever reason, that wine becomes an oxidized wine. Oxidized wines will sometimes have an unmistakable note of dark earth or mushrooms. Although there are many things you can do to extend a wine’s life, once a bottle is opened it is in threat of becoming oxidized.

Cooked. When a wine is “cooked” it means that the wine has been exposed to too much heat. Cooked wines are sometimes difficult to identify because there are different levels kinds of damage the wine can suffer. At its worst, a cooked wine can have the aroma of something dull or stewed, but it can also smell sweet like caramel. The smell of a cooked wine is generally a smell of something that has been slow-cooked.Cooked wines will generally also lack in fruit and suffer an imbalance of flavor and alcohol content. It is important to keep the wine at its proper temperature in order to preserve its fineness.

Corking. Experiencing a “corked” wine is very common in the wine world and is said to public enemy number one. This condition is also known as cork taint; it is when a microbial fungus, which usually comes from the environment, finds its way into the cork, contaminates it, and then taints the wine. Corked wines have very strong characteristics such as an odor like a moldy newspaper, a damp cloth or a wet dog.

Brettanomyces. Also known as Brett, brettanomyces is a very controversial flaw because some say “little” Brett is a good thing in a wine. Brett is the spoilage yeast that is sometimes introduced to produce compounds that alter a wine’s flavor. At low levels, winemakers agree that the presence of Brett has a positive effect. At high levels, Brett can produce a funk-like flavor similar to that of sweat or body odor. Even though some people say a little Brett is good, Brettanomyces is very difficult to control once it starts to spread.

title: Is Wine Good for Your Teeth?
post_content:
We can all remember seeing humorous laundry detergent commercials that show us that dangerous glass of red wine slipping out of a woman’s hands – in slow motion, of course – and all of that delicious red wine splattering gracefully all over her white blouse. For many people, this is a worst-case scenario: how will you ever get out red wine stains? Unfortunately, many people associate this dastardly staining with the way red wine supposedly stains our teeth; some people have even switched to drinking entirely white wine out of fear that they’re pearly whites will not be too pearly or too white for very long.

Fortunately, recent research says different than those laundry commercials about our teeth.

Here’s how your teeth get damaged: the bacteria that damages your teeth are called streptococcus, and they reside in the mouth feeding off of the sugars in your diet. These bacteria stick to the enamel, and they trigger the process called “demineralization” which is exactly what it sounds like – it strips the minerals off your teeth and starts to form holes in the enamel.

So wine has sugars – doesn’t that mean wine will damage your teeth?

Not necessarily. Scientists have found an active ingredient called proanthocyanidins will block streptococcus from sticking to enamel. This ingredient is found in grape skins! Furthermore, later studies have shown that polyphenols, also an ingredient in wine, fight off diseases like periodontitis, which affects the gums and jaw. You can also find these compounds in cranberries, which are well-known infamous for preventing plaque and cavities.

Of course, consuming too many sugars from any source will ultimately have a negative effect on your teeth, but this is only when sugar is an excess part of a diet. As long as you’re consuming wine, cranberries, or other sugars in moderation, it is considered normal consumption. And when you regularly brush your teeth and floss, it is likely that your teeth will remain in tip-top condition. That’s more than any laundry detergent brand can claim.

So put down the white and pick up the red – it’s safe for you to enjoy!

title: Production of Sweet Wine
post_content:
Wine comes in many different forms, shapes and style, from red dries to sweet white, each wine has its own unique flavor and qualities that make them special. Now there are three types of wine: white, red and rose. Each wine is made from a combination of different grapes, and how the wine is made will determine its style.

What is sweet wine? To beginning, there are both sweet red wines and sweet white wines, although generally speaking sweet white wines are much easier to find. Sweet wines are wines that lie on the sweeter side of the spectrum; they are the opposite of a dry wine and have certain flavors and qualities that are very different from other wines. Most sweet wines don’t go that well with full meals but they do go very well with desserts. So when a person is asking for a sweet wine what they are saying is they prefer a wine that is not dry.

The production of sweet wine is fairly similar to any other wine, such as it goes through the picking of grapes, the crushing with or without its skin, the fermentation and so on, all the way to the bottling and storage. Now what makes the process different is more about the types of grapes, the varieties, and one major step during the fermentation.

It is the type of grape that really determines what type of wine it is going to be. Since a Sweet wine can be red, white or rose, this first step of the process is generally up to the winemaker in which grapes he wishes to use. The most important feature of the grapes is their age. Wine producers who make sweet wine will choose grapes that had a late harvest. If a grape is left on the vine past the normal harvest time, it will develop a greater concentration of sugar and flavor. Late harvested-grapes will have too much sugar in them, and this residual sugar makes the wine sweeter. Another important fact to know about the grapes that are chosen for Sweet wine production is something called Botrytis, also known as noble rot. This rot is a fungus that saps moisture from the grapes, leaving them with a higher concentration of sugar and acidity.

Sweet wines come in many different styles. Aside from regular sweet white and red wines, there are also dessert wines such as Ice Wine, which are very sweet. Ice wines are really unique because they are made from frozen grapes off the vine, the grapes are literally frozen when picked, and they are then pressed and fermented. The result from a frozen grape is a rich, ultra-sweet wine. Another interesting Sweet wine is Moscato, semi-sparkling, semi-sweet to sweet winesmade from Moscato grapes. These wines take aromatics to a whole new level, with fresh floral, ripe stone fruit and exotic spice mark, an extraordinary component to this unique sweet wine. Another Sweet wine is known as Sherry, this is a fortified wine that is produced in Spain within the “Sherry Triangle” from white wine grapes. Sherrys are very rich and depending on the style can range from dry to Super Sweet.

title: What Is Tannin?
post_content:
Read the back of almost any bottle of red or rosé wine, or hear any expert describing such a bottle, and you’re sure to hear or read the word ‘tannin’ at some point. Tannins have become a key component for describing the body or character of any bottle of wine, with wines containing a high tannin content being described as ‘full bodied’, and those with few tannins being ‘light bodied’. Although discussion of tannin levels is common among wine enthusiasts, few of us truly understand exactly what they are and what they do.

Here are a few simple facts which we can consider to help us improve our knowledge of these special compounds and be able to speak about them with a little more confidence when describing a wine.

The Purpose of Tannins

Tannins are found in a wide range of plants, not just grapevines. They occur naturally in leaves, in bark, and noticeably in young fruit on almost all fruit-bearing plants and trees. The tannins present in these lifeforms are responsible for forming complex binding components with the proteins in plants, and in other organic polymers (such as polysaccharides). Most scientists today believe that tannins originally evolved as a sort of defense mechanism for the plant – tannins have a distinctive and bitter taste, and create a powerful astringent effect in the mouth.

Think of eating an under-ripe grape or plum, and you can see the effect the tannins have on the tongue and roof of the mouth. This effect could put off herbivores and other animals seeking to eat the plant, and as such they are now present in a wide range of vegetation.

When it comes to the grapevines which eventually produce the wines we know and love, the plant itself uses its strongest tannins rather cleverly. Basically, the vine wants the grapes to be eaten. This is how it spreads its seeds – through the excrement of birds and other animals which eat its juicy fruits. However, when the grapes are young, the seeds within them are not yet ready, and as such, the grapes are extremely astringent and unpleasant to taste. Fascinatingly, it is at the moment when the grapes begin to change color when the tannin levels drop significantly; the grapes become both more visible (red, blue, black, purple etc) to birds and more delicious to eat at the same time, making the plant more likely to spread its seeds and thrive elsewhere.

Tannins and Wine Production

When it comes to wine production, a winery wants to have a certain amount of control over how much tannin is in its wine. The tannins found in wines do not come from the under-ripe fruit of the vine, though, they come from the seeds, the skins and sometimes the stems of the grape. As such, it is the length of time the grape juice has in contact with the skins, seeds and stems of the fruit that dictates just how much tannin there will be in the wine.

Why would a winery wish to have tannins in their wine? Why would they insist on keeping these bitter and astringent compounds? Wine without tannins, especially red wine without any tannin, is often flat and lacking in character. The ‘body’ of the wine is what holds the wines complexity and allows the vintner to balance the different aspects of the wine against each other. Just as if the wine’s alcohol content was too low, or flavor or acidity too weak, the wine would be imbalanced and uninteresting, the same applies when it comes to the body, or tannin content of the wine.

Tannins and Aging

Tannins are incredibly important when it comes to aging wines. Young wines often have a stronger tannin presence in the bottle, and this sometimes means that the other, subtler and more complex characteristics of the wine are overshadowed by its astringency. By ageing red wines, either in oak barrels, or in the bottle at home or in a cellar, tannins begin to soften and ’round out’, producing more balanced wines capable of expressing more interesting and subtle features. Generally, aged wines are considered far finer than young wines, as there will be a far wider bouquet of aromas and flavors detectable in the bottle, and the wine will be more balanced and interesting on the tongue.

title: The Myth of the Taste Map
post_content:
The science-class diagram is familiar to everyone: a healthy, pink tongue divided into circles and ovals of taste receptors. The very tip of the tongue whispers sweet nothings, and tastes the sweet things in life in return. Receptors for salty tastes flank the sweet on each side. Sour receptors lie close behind. Finally bitterness is tasted at the back of the tongue. This chart, we are told, describe the fundamentals of the human perception of taste.

The idea of the taste map originated in the early 20th century, from psychological research on perception. The original research, published in German and translated into English, demonstrated that all areas of the tongue could perceive all tastes, at various levels of sensitivity. Sugars were sweet, salts were savory, and bitters were acrid, no matter where they fell on the tongue. However, researchers documented some variation in the levels of sensitivity to taste stimuli across different parts of the tongue. These statistical differences in sensitivity across regions of the tongue were minute rather than absolute, but that fact became lost in the translation. The results of the translated study produced a precisely zoned map of tasting ability. This mistaken scientific understanding then became the authoritative scientific model of the tongue for the next several decades.

The taste map is an admittedly attractive theory, for several reasons. The categories are neatly labeled, mutually exclusive, and seem logical. They complement and contrast: sugar and salt, sweet and sour, and so on. Therein lies the beauty of wine, grapes, cheese, and crackers – their taste profiles complement each other harmoniously.

Creating an effective wine pairing often starts with a consideration of the taste profiles of the food and the intended drink. By using the taste map concepts to choose well-paired products, wine enthusiasts from hobbyists to sommeliers can achieve outstanding effect. The descriptive capacity of winemakers and professional tasters and judges has created a wealth of gustatory information from which wine enthusiasts can evaluate their beverages.

The existence of the taste map is treated as a part of the oenological canon, even though there is no evidence to support it. The misunderstanding in the translation has created a popular knowledge misconception of taste that has persisted ever since. The very strictest interpretation of taste mapping theory – that tasting abilities are confined to specific zones of the tongue – has long been disproven. However, that doesn’t mean that the theory is left without any sort of legacy. Taste mapping theory achieved long-lasting (and arguably, ongoing) popularity because it offers a straightforward, qualitative measure of taste. The ability to qualify and describe wines in a standardized fashion has enabled greater popular engagement with wine culture.

The popularization of wine culture and improvements in perception research methodology has renewed interest in taste mapping theory. Newer research has confirmed the conclusion of the original study, that taste receptors of all kinds are present throughout the tongue. What creates the illusion of the taste map is the density of each type of receptor on the tongue. It’s possible – but not yet proven – that there are more sweet receptors at the front of the tongue, salty on the sides, sour and bitter in the back. How would this impact the nuance of complex tastes?

The objective scientific answer is, “not much.” As early as 1875, research on taste supported the idea that taste receptors of all kinds were located throughout the entire tongue. The evidence indicated that there was very little difference in sensitivity across different areas, which suggests that the receptor density and distribution may be fairly uniform. This suggests that the experience of taste may be highly consistent across the tongue, and that this consistency itself might be a feature of taste perception.

What does this finding mean to wine drinkers who attend to the entire experience of wine: taste, aroma, aeration, flavor, and mouth feel? What does it say about the engineering efforts that have gone into optimizing glasses, decanters, and other tools of the trade?

The technology is still sound and its purpose, still worthy. Even if the experience of tasting each sip is consistent, the quality of that sip is shaped by your serving choices. Choosing serving vessels that bring out the best in your beverage is, and always will be, a part of the presentation and consumption of fine wines. And that is a matter of the best taste!

short_content:
The science-class diagram is familiar to everyone: a healthy, pink tongue divided into circles and ovals of taste receptors. The very tip of the tongue whispers sweet nothings, and tastes the sweet things in life in return. Receptors for salty tastes flank the sweet on each side. Sour receptors lie close behind. Finally bitterness is tasted at the back of the tongue. This chart, we are told, describe the fundamentals of the human perception of taste.

The idea of the taste map originated in the early 20th century, from psychological research on perception. The original research, published in German and translated into English, demonstrated that all areas of the tongue could perceive all tastes, at various levels of sensitivity. Sugars were sweet, salts were savory, and bitters were acrid, no matter where they fell on the tongue. However, researchers documented some variation in the levels of sensitivity to taste stimuli across different parts of the tongue. These statistical differences in sensitivity across regions of the tongue were minute rather than absolute, but that fact became lost in the translation. The results of the translated study produced a precisely zoned map of tasting ability. This mistaken scientific understanding then became the authoritative scientific model of the tongue for the next several decades.

The taste map is an admittedly attractive theory, for several reasons. The categories are neatly labeled, mutually exclusive, and seem logical. They complement and contrast: sugar and salt, sweet and sour, and so on. Therein lies the beauty of wine, grapes, cheese, and crackers – their taste profiles complement each other harmoniously.

Creating an effective wine pairing often starts with a consideration of the taste profiles of the food and the intended drink. By using the taste map concepts to choose well-paired products, wine enthusiasts from hobbyists to sommeliers can achieve outstanding effect. title: The Differences between Appellation and Varietals
post_content:
Learning all of the differences between how countries label their wines can seem like a trying ordeal. Reading labels from around the world can seem intimidating, but really there are a few simple distinctions you can learn to make that will incredibly increase your ability to comfortable read these labels. One of these differences is between varietal and appellation. When you are familiar with what these terms mean and which countries use them, you will no doubt be better prepared to know what you are drinking from any country.

The term varietal is used when talking about the actual grapes used in a wine. This is perhaps a little bit easier to decipher, because when a bottle says “Merlot” you’ll know that those were the grapes that were produced and that’s the kind of wine that you’re drinking. This type of labeling is used in most countries, including North America, Australia, Chile, and South Africa. Many people feel comfortable with this type of labeling since if you know the characteristics of the grape used in production then you will likely be able to know what the wine will taste like. There is one technicality with this type of labeling, though: the labels only show the varietal that is used the most in the wine. For example, a Merlot may contain 10% zinfandel, but because the majority of the grapes used in the wine are Merlot, then the wine would be labeled a Merlot.

The other labeling style, called appellation, is a system of labeling based on a wine’s location of production. It tells you where the wine’s grapes come from. This style is used most often for the old world wine countries like France, Spain, and Italy, each which labels their wines from the regions. So if you’re reading a French red wine bottle that says “Bordeaux France,” it means they will have certain characteristics of a Bordeaux styled wine. So if red Bordeaux are full-bodied and dry, then you’ll know by reading this label that your red Bordeaux will likely have these characteristics.

Many might say that one labeling style is better than the other, while others say that both are fine. It is hard to tell which system of labeling is actually better, but more countries have been using varietal labeling.

Now, no matter which label you see, you’ll be able to read and understand what it’s telling you just a little better. With time and experience, you’ll know what kind of wine is waiting underneath that label. As always, enjoy.

title: The Sugar Content in Wine
post_content:
In today’s health-conscious culture, we find ourselves asking questions we hadn’t considered years ago. One popular question has been, “How much sugar is in wine?” While we enjoy the sweet flavors many wines provide, we also feel obligated to make sure we are not overindulging in one of America’s favorite vices. Just like everything else about wine, there is a large variety of how wines achieve their sweetness, and once you learn the science behind the sweetness you will be better equipped to identify the wines that are best for your health concerns.

A wine’s sweetness depends on a variety of factors, including alcohol levels, acidity levels, and concentration of tannins, among other factors. The natural sugars in grapes develop through a process of translocation of sucrose molecules produced through photosynthesis. These molecules are converted into glucose and fructose – our friendly sugars. These sugars are then converted into alcohol by fermentation. And the delicious sweetness we taste is largely determined by how long the fermentation process lasts.

Residual sugar

Fermentation does not consume all of a wine’s sugar. The sugar that remains after fermentation is known as residual sugar, and this is measured in grams per litre of wine, which is usually represented by g/l or g/L. The lowest amount of sugar you will find is about 1g/L. It is rare to find any level lower because some sugars, like pentose, just do not ferment.

The quantity of sugar ranges quite a bit, however. The highest amount of sugars can range anywhere well above 50g/l. Wines like Tokaji and some ice wines are over 100 g/l. This might sound over powering, but such wines are balanced with acidity to make them very delicious. While some wines are infused with acidity to balance their taste, others have residual sugar added to them to purposely make them sweeter. This process is called Sussreserve, and it is primarily practiced in regions in and around Germany.

Terms of sweetness

Much of understand wines comes with understand the terminology for its different aspects. There are different words or names that are associated with sweet and dry wines as well as the levels of sweetness in sparkling wines. Below you will find some of the most common terms associated with a wine’s level of sweetness of dryness.

Champagne and Sparkling wines:

1. Brut Natural- contains around 0-3 g/l of sugar. This is as dry as a wine can be. 2. Extra Brut- contains 0-6g/l, and offers a very dry taste. 3. Brut- contains 0-12 g/l, while not as dry as “Brut Natural” or “Extra Brut” is still on the dry side and contains far less sugars than other wines.
4. Extra Dry, Extra Sec, Extra Seco- contains12-17 g/l. A middle-of-the-road wine in terms of how sweet and dry it is.
5. Dry, Sec, Seco- contains 17-32 g/l. The dryness decreases and the sweetness increases once you reach this level.
6. Demi-Sec, Semi Seco- contains 32-50 g/l. These make for delicious complements to fruits and desserts.
7. Doux, Sweet, Dulce- contains 50+g/l. The sweetest level of wine available.

As you drink certain wines expecting them to be rather sweet, you must remember that other contents in the wine – like its alcohol and acidity levels – will balance out the sweetness. This can cause supposedly sweet wines to not taste as sweet as you might expect:
1. Dry- Dry wines fall somewhere around or up to 4 g/l depending on acidity and alcohol.
2. Medium Dry- These wines have up to 12 g/l
3. Medium- These wines have up to 45 g/l
4. Sweet- These wines have more than 45 g/l

The levels indicated on the labels are estimated, and will certainly vary depending on that specific wine’s level of acidity and alcohol. People frequently mistake sweet wines with cheap wines, but this is not the case. In fact, sweet wines can be rather expensive. Sometimes, sweet wines have a high level of acidity that makes them taste dry or, conversely, dry wines might have a high level of alcohol that makes them taste sweet.

When searching for your next favorite brand and flavor of wine, consider the quantity of sugar and the relationship of that sugar to the wine’s alcohol and acidity. Enjoy exploring wines and searching for that ideal balance for your palate!

title: What is a Full-Bodied Wine?
post_content:
Sometimes we talk about wine like we talk about women. “I love the body!” But what do we mean when we say this? What does it mean when we speak about a wine being “full-bodied?”

A wine is not just a drink, but an engrossing experience for the senses. The body of a wine refers to the full inundation of our senses when the wine is in our mouth: the wine’s texture, weight, and feel all compose our impression of the wine’s “body.” No single component of the wine determines what its body is like, just like we can’t look at a person’s arm and discern the rest of their shape. The features of a wine’s acidity, glycerol, extract, alcohol, and so on all contribute to that rich, well-rounded flavor we have lingering in our mouths.

Some of the red wines known for being described as “full-bodied” include Cabernet Sauvignon and French Bordeaux. Full-bodied white wines include Chardonnay and Sauvignon Blanc. The uniting feature of each of these is that they are dry – dry wines frequently possess that pucker type of feeling that loiters in our mouths like a guy loiters near a girl’s house after his first great kiss. These wines are also typically aged in wood.

Sugar also has the ability to give a wine a full-bodied feeling. Dessert wines, for example the Sauternes, have the extra sugar needed to give them that robust flavor.

Ultimately, though, the idea of a wine being full-bodied is really in the mouth of the taster. Everyone possesses their own unique perception of a wine’s characteristics, and so what might feel full-bodied to one individual might not taste as full to another. A good comparison for understanding the term “full-bodied” can be made with milk. Different milks come with different textures, from cream to half and half, from regular milk down to 2%. As you experience different bodies of milk, you can think of wine similarly.

Of course, to fully enjoy any wine’s body, you want to consider certain food pairing recommendations. When enjoying what to you is a full-bodied wine, the ideal partner might be a hearty meat or a heavy pasta. If the meal is “full-bodied” and hearty, then the wine should be too, and vice versa. Light foods likewise deserve light wines. I distinctly recall enjoying a Vinho Verde with a salad, and the combination made the green bell pepper so vivacious and intense. But the best way for you to enjoy wine, learn about body, and find the ideal food pairings is to explore for yourself. Try different wines, experiment with combinations, and compare the way your senses discern different bodies.
