title: Whiskey Around The World
post_content:
Whiskey has proven to be one of the world’s most enduring and popular alcoholic spirits, with a vast range of countries attempting to produce whiskies in their own style today. While we commonly associate whisky with the golden age of Scotland in the 19th century, the Scots were far from the first to make this special and recognizable drink. Indeed, there is much evidence to suggest that the techniques still common to this day were being employed by ancient cultures across the world, and one often stumbles across debates over who was the first to make and enjoy this drink. One of the most popular theories points towards the ancient Babylonians of Mesopotamia, who could well have been fermenting grains for the production of whiskey as long as four thousand years ago, where it was enjoyed as an aromatic drink, flavored and perfumed with various spices, and used as a medicinal treatment for a wide range of ailments.

Whiskey was brought to the British Isles, where it was made in the 15th century by Irish and Scottish monks for both medicinal and recreational purposes. When Henry VIII dissolved England’s monasteries, whiskey production was forced into private hands. The whiskey produced in England in the 15th and 16th centuries was very different from the drink we widely enjoy today, as the distillate was not left to age and mellow in wooden casks, resulting in a harsh, highly alcoholic, and somewhat brutal drink. Indeed, it is likely that several people died from drinking this early whiskey, as it was difficult to control its alcohol content.

Scottish and Irish Whiskeys

Over time, whiskey became an important product for the economies of both Scotland and Ireland. Both countries initially made whiskey in similar styles. Today Irish whiskey distinguishes itself from Scotch whisky (which is sometimes spelled without the “e”) by being distilled three times. By law, Irish whiskeys must be aged for a minimum of three years in wood, where it takes on its distinctive earthy and oak tones. Irish whiskey is also usually made from unpeated malt, while Scotch whisky prides itself on the peat smoking process, in which the grains or malt used in the production are infused with smoke from burning the black peat which is found all over the country. This process which helps give Scotch its unique flavor.

Whiskies of the USA

One of the other key countries to involve itself in whisky production over the past couple of centuries has been the United States of America, where immigrants from the British Isles were quick to set up whisky distilleries of their own in the New World. American whiskies differ quite considerably from their Scottish and Irish cousins, as they commonly use both corn and rye in their cereal content – ingredients which were growing extensively in the United States and required little cultivation.

American whiskies are split into several categories, being Bourbon, Malt, Rye, Corn, Rye Malt and Wheat whisky, each of which must contain no more than eighty percent alcohol, and must, by law, be aged in wooden casks (with the exception of corn whisky). One very American whiskey is Tennessee whiskey, a style which normally stands out from other American whiskies and which is enjoyed all over the world. In Tennessee, it is common for their whiskies to be filtered through charcoal made from sweet maple, which lends the drink a distinctive and very American flavour.

Canadian Whisky

Further north, we find the interesting and highly drinkable Canadian whiskies, which are often far lighter and smoother than their USA counterparts. In Canada, whiskies are often sweetened using caramel, and have various flavorings added to the blend. Although Canadian whiskies are unlikely to satisfy purists in the Old World, they are widely popular in Canada and various other countries because they are so accessible.

Other Countries

The past few decades have seen an explosion of whisky production all across the globe, and notable countries include those in Scandinavia, where distilling all sorts of grains and herbs has been commonplace for centuries. Scandinavian whiskies – particularly those made in Sweden and Finland – have received critical acclaim, and it is expected that several more distilleries will open in the next few years. Germany is also establishing a whisky culture, as are countries as far away from whisky’s spiritual home as Japan and India, where drinking and collecting fine whisky is seen as a status symbol.

title: Sparkling Wines: The Difference between Brut and Extra Dry
post_content:
Champagne and sparkling wine labels possess many potentially confusing components that can easily frustrate an earnest buyer. What does it mean when you see “brut” or “demi-sec” on a label? Or when a bottle is identified with “NV” on it? Each of these labels refers to the champagne or sparkling wine’s level of dryness. “NV” stands for “non-vintage,” and means that the product is a blend of several different years. In fact, the majority of champagne and sparkling wine market is dominated by non-vintage types.

Classifications of Dryness

Since champagnes and sparkling wines are identified according to their dryness, it is important to understand how to interpret these labels. It is, in fact, not very difficult once you grasp the terminology:

Extra Brut – This is the driest classification. Many people falsely believe that “extra dry” is the driest, but this is not the case. If you like dry, then Extra Brut might be the best for you.

Brut – While not as dry as “extra Brut,” Brut still represents a fairly dry drink.

Extra Dry – This classification, confusingly, is actually the middle-of-the-road dryness. Extra Dry champagnes and sparkling wines make great aperitifs or can mix well with juice for delicious mimosas.

Demi-Sec – This is the sweetest and least-dry designation. These champagnes and sparkling wines pair well with desserts and fruits.

The Bubbles

Children love playing with bubbles. Adults enjoy drinking them. The bubbles you’ll find inside of your favorite champagnes or sparkling wines come from the second fermentation process. Other ways bubbles arrive are through either the company injecting carbon dioxide into the mixture, or by adding sugar and a few grams of yeast which will carbonate the drink. You’ll find that the standard amount of pressure in a bottle of champagne or sparkling wine stands at 80 PSI.

The intoxicating aromas of champagnes and sparkling wines feel reminiscent of pears, apples, or – thanks to the yeast – from fresh bread. The flavors also frequently provide fruit-inspired tingles, ranging from apple to strawberry, and even suggest hints of cream and vanilla. Like any wine selection, the prices you pay depend on the capacity of your wallet – overall, though, inexpensive champagnes and sparkling wines can still possess delicious flavors.

title: What is a Pot Still?
post_content:
A pot still is more than just a stationary pot – it is a specifically designed pot used for distilling. This distilling device will separate liquids and helps with the production of liquor. Aside from helping produce spirits, a pot still can be used to separate out impurities from water, take nitrogen and oxygen from air, or even to refine crude oil. A pot still works simply by heating a liquid and capturing the rising vapors through the oddly-shaped necks on the top.

Distillation makes it appear as though a liquid’s essence, or “spirit,” is being taken out of it. This phenomenon explains why liquor is sometimes dubbed as “spirits.” Ancient alchemists used the pot still to distill all kinds of liquids in their pursuit of gold. Although they never managed to make gold, they did manage to develop and refine the pot still distillation process.

One of the pot still’s more infamous applications was during America’s Prohibition era, in which bootleggers would produce a highly potent spirit known as Moonshine. Pot still’s contributed to Moonshine’s characteristic of having extremely high levels of alcohol, nicknamed by many as “white lightning.” Anything from car and home radiators to oil drums were used by bootleggers to create their Moonshine. Although this was highly illegal in the US, bootlegger practices led to many of today’s best known distilleries and contribute to Kentucky and Tennessee’s distinct style of Bourbon.

Today, owning your personal pot still is illegal. While you could use a pot still to make your own whiskey, doing so privately and without a license will get you in a lot of trouble. The US government discourages private bootlegging since unreported production and distribution of alcohol could be dangerous for society and because the government makes enormous sums of money off of taxed imported whiskies.

title: Which Wine is More Dry: Cabernet Sauvignon or Merlot?
post_content:
How many times have you entered a wine store and seen individuals staring blankly at the enormous wall of red wine? How many times have you been that person who is overwhelmed with the vast selection of red wines? Today, there are so many different varietals and styles of wine to select from that unless you walk into a store having some information about wine, you will very easily be overwhelmed. Here are a few tips to help you understand the different types of red wines just a little bit more.

Let’s start with the term “dry.” Have you ever that it’s funny that a beverage could be described as “dry”? Every wine has tannins in it. Tannins are are polyphenolic compounds that bind to proteins. Plants naturally produce tannins as a form of self-defense, swathing themselves in a bitter, astringent taste. By the time tannins get to us, they are giving the wines we drink a unique, irreplaceable flavor. That astringent, puckering sort of experience you get when drinking “dry” red wines is thanks to the presence of tannins. These tannins are bind to the proteins in your saliva to produce the full-bodied and dry tastes in wine. The more tannins a wine possesses, the drier it’s going to taste.

When it comes to comparing Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon has more tannins in it and would naturally be the drier of the two. However, the final product still depends on the type of production and goals of the individual winemaker. One factor that affects a wine’s dryness is the time it is harvested. Sweet wines often come from grapes that are harvested late in the season, when their sugars have more time to condense. If the grapes are harvested early, the grapes will have fewer sugars and more acids, making them drier. So there are many factors involved when determining how dry a wine will be.

If you are just starting out experimenting with red wines, I would go with a nice Merlot. It is an all-around wine that isn’t too dry and isn’t too sweet. Merlot can pair with many foods, and is also a great drink all by itself. While the flavor profile is similar to Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot tends to be less distinctive and slightly more herbaceous overall in taste and aroma.

Hopefully this article sheds some light on your next selection. You can find many great values and wide selection at CityWineCellar.com. And as always, I hope you enjoy your next glass of red wine.

title: Why are wine bottles dark?
post_content:
When you walk through a story and glance into wine bottles, you are likely not seeing the full picture. Wines are often described according to color, but why do so many wines look darkened inside of their bottles? Why can’t wine be distributed in clearer bottles so we can see what we’re purchasing?

The answer is that wine does not like the light. Most people recommend that wine cellars or caves – cold, dark wine cellars and caves – are the best places to store wine. Sunlight has a similar effect on wine as it does on photographs: it will prematurely age and degrade the quality of wine. The colored, dimmed bottles are fitted with UV filters that block out much of light’s destructive influence. This is why you will find wines, and especially red wines, are stored in darkened bottles.

There is historical precedent for the color and shape of wine bottles as well. Many wine bottle colors and shapes are distinctive to brands, styles, and regions. In fact, before even taking a sip of wine, an eye familiar with wine bottles can identity many features of the wine just by examining the bottle.

So when you’re in the store holding up bottles of wine to the light, you might want to think again. While you might not be able to determine the color quality of a wine by staring through its bottle, you can examine the bottle’s color and shape to inform you. Then, when convinced you’ve found the right wine, you can uncork it at home and discover for yourself it’s true color and beauty.

title: Why Are Wine Bottles Shaped Like That?
post_content:
Walking through a wine shop can often feel like we’re walking through a house of mirrors at a carnival – there are so many different shapes and colors that we can begin to feel overwhelmed, disoriented, and equally entertained. Although most bottles hold about 750ml of wine and are made from glass, there are an astounding number of differences between the ways bottles are made and the functions they perform.

Wine Bottle Shapes

The main reason why bottles feature the shapes and colors they do is because of tradition. Wine producers from traditional countries and regions have an extensive history of working with certain bottle shapes. By maintaining loyalty to the shape of the bottle, these producers are carrying on the tradition of their forefathers. In fact, you can frequently tell where a wine has come from just by looking at the bottle’s shape and color.

You might also notice that the bottoms of many wine bottles have what appears to be a sort of indent, or dimple. This is known as a punt – also known as a kick up – and doesn’t entirely seem to have a good reason for being there except as a tradition. It is rumored that glass blowers indented the bottle of wine bottles so that they could not leave a mark that would scratch the table. Others believe that this dimple made bottles less likely to tip over. And still others theorize that tavern servants stuck their thumb in the dimple to indicate to barkeeps if a patron was reliable or not.

If you were to look closely at champagne bottles, you’ll also see that they are thicker than wine bottles. This is due to the carbonation present. When it comes to wire meshes on sparkling wine corks, we can thank Dom Perignon, who was one of the first to invent this modification to prevent corks from popping off and hitting unsuspecting bystanders.

Typically, wine producers try to match a wine’s bottle shape to its style. For example, if a wine has characteristics similar to Bordeaux, then it would be placed in bottle similar to the Bordeaux bottle. Fortified wines, such as port or sherry, have studier bottles with a bulge in the neck, supposedly for catching fortification sediment. The types of bottles will vary as much as the wines themselves do. The more familiar you become with wines and their bottle shapes, the more quickly you’ll be able to distinguish between certain wine styles just by a glance at their shape and color.

title: Sparking Wine Production
post_content:
In this complex and beautiful world, many diverse people now live together, and our wines are no different. There are different styles and types of wine that can be enjoyed for different purposes and different occasions. From deep-flavored red wines to sweet and light dessert wines, each style of wine qualities that make it stand out and distinguish itself. But what makes a wine different?

The main difference between different wines is how they are produced.  This is most true in the case of sparking wines. Sparkling wines contain a high amount of carbon dioxide to make them “fizzy”. These dessert wines can be red, rose or white, but sparkling wine is generally white. A good example of sparkling wine is champagne. All wine styles are made differently, the way sparkling wine is produced starts just as any other wine, with the grapes.

Grapes that are normally picked for sparkling wine are usually a blend of Chardonnay, Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier. The grapes are picked, stemmed (sometime) then crushed. The pressing of the grapes into juice is done quickly so that they can be kept white. From this point the production of sparkling wine is fairly similar to all other wines, they are placed in a vessel that will allow the grape juice to undergo fermentation. During this first stage of fermentation, the process is pretty much the same as any other wine. Some yeast may be added into the must (another name for the grape juice) that will cause the sugars in the grapes to be converted and changed into alcohol and carbon dioxide.

After the first fermentation, the wine is still a regular wine. The next step in the production of sparkling wine is the second fermentation. The blended wine is placed in bottles along with yeast and small amounts of sugar. These bottles are corked with temporary plugs and stored in the wine cellar. During the second fermentation, the carbon dioxide is trapped in the wine, and the amount of sugar added will determine the pressure in the bottle. The whole purpose of second fermentation is really to get more carbon dioxide trapped in the wine.

After the second fermentation, the lees from the wine must be removed. For this to happen, the bottles undergo a process known as riddling. Riddling is when the wines are placed on special racks known as pupitres, which hold the bottles at a 45 degree angle. Once a day the bottles are given a slight shake and turn, alternatively on right then left, and dropped back into the pupitres, with the angle gradually increased. The purpose of this is that because of the angle of the bottles the rack causes a slight tap, pushing sediments towards the neck of the bottle. After a number of days the bottle is straightened up, and the lees settle in the neck. Manual riddling is still done, but it has largely been abandoned because of the high labor cost. Most sparkling wines are now done with mechanized riddling equipment.

Once all the lees are on the neck of the bottle the next stage would be to remove them. This is called disgorging. Traditionally, this has been a very time-consuming manual process, in which an employee would be required to remove the lees using a crown cap while losing as little liquid as possible and adding sugar. Now, the disgorging process is done automatically by freezing a small amount of the liquid in the neck then removing that frozen plug.

Immediately after the disgorging, the wine has a little sugar added to it, this practice of adding sugar after disgorging is known as dosage. The sugar is a mixture of the base wine and sucrose, with the addition of sulfur dioxide as a preservative. The amount of sugar determines the sweetness of the sparkling wine, the sugar previously in the wine having been consumed in the second fermentation. The sugar is not added to sweeten the wine, but to balance its high acidity. Finally, the wines are then sealed and then placed in cellars for aging.

title: Picking a Wine in a Restaurant
post_content:
Trying to select the right wine from a restaurant’s wine list can be as difficult as trying to guess a stranger’s name. You are more likely to guess wrong than right. Wines often have a strange language attached to them that can be difficult, or even impossible, to decipher. Even when restaurants do add descriptions, they only provide a brief sentence or two, and these sentences are usually inaccurate. Plus, if you think about it, it’s unlikely that you’ll get a good idea of what something tastes like just by reading about it anyway. Additionally, restaurants rarely employ a sommelier or waitperson who has enough wine knowledge to steer you in the right direction.

It’s difficult enough to choose food from a menu, let alone wine, so here are a few friendly tips to help you make confident wine decisions at restaurants.

1. When in doubt, go with what’s familiar. Randomly selecting a wine that “sounds good” will rarely provide you with a familiar experience. In fact, it’s quite likely that a random wine selection will turn an otherwise enjoyable dining experience into a horrible dining experience. Consider your company, too – don’t you want to make a good impression and help them enjoy their meal? The surest way to achieve this is to select a wine you already know you like. Don’t choose wines blindly.

2. Never select a wine based on price. Remember that just because a wine is expensive does not mean that it is good. Restaurant’s wine prices can be as outrageous as Richard Simmon’s outfits. Some wines are marked up to double their retail value. It doesn’t matter how much money you throw at a wine bottle, if it tastes cheap then it tastes cheap. And there’s nothing more disappointing than spending a lot of money on something you do not enjoy or appreciate.

3. Ask questions. Good restaurants will list a wine’s vintage, varietal, and price. Don’t be distracted by other, less important, information. When restaurants try to hide this, they may be trying to scam you by marking up an undesirable wine.

4. Beware of “mark up.” If you know what you would pay for the same or similar wine at the store, then don’t be suckered into paying two times or more of the wine’s retail cost. If the wine costs more than twice what you’d pay at the store, then you are paying far too much.

5. Try calling the restaurant ahead of time and ask if you can bring your own bottle of wine there. You’d be surprised at how many restaurants allow you to do this; some restaurants may simply charge a small “corking fee” for this privilege. When you call ahead, you have the additional benefit of speaking to the restaurant about its wine selection and making your plan ahead of time. If you do bring a bottle of your own, try to make sure it’s not a bottle from their menu – it would be considered rude to do so and you can expect a hassle.

6. While you might be thinking about the markup on a wine bottle, also beware of the markup on individual glasses of wine as well. Uninformed consumers can get suckered into paying far more for a glass of wine than they might pay for an entire bottle. Remember that you can get on average about four glasses of wine out of the typical bottle, so if one glass is costing you more than what the entire bottle is worth, then your smarter option is just to buy the bottle.

7. Finally, you should know that not all restaurants are trying to use wine as another way to dig deeper in to your pocket. Some restaurants are honest and have a genuine approach to their promotion and pricing of wine. At the same time, don’t be so eager to believe everything you see and hear – use your wine knowledge and your experience to guide you to make wise wine purchasing decisions.

There are just a few simply tips that can help guide you through the daunting task of ordering wine at a restaurant. The more educated, experienced, and confident you are the more like you will be to make a successful wine selection while dining out. So go with what you know about wine, and your selection should turn out fine. As always, enjoy!

These are just a few tips that can help you with the daunting task of ordering wine at your restaurant. I think the main thing to remember is to make a confident and educated decision. Go with your knowledge of what you know about wine and you should be fine. Enjoy!

Plus, if you think about it, it’s unlikely that you’ll get a good idea of what something tastes like just by reading about it anyway. Additionally, restaurants rarely employ a sommelier or waitperson who has enough wine knowledge to steer you in the right direction.

It’s difficult enough to choose food from a menu, let alone wine, so here are a few friendly tips to help you make confident wine decisions at restaurants.

1. When in doubt, go with what’s familiar. Randomly selecting a wine that “sounds good” will rarely provide you with a familiar experience. In fact, it’s quite likely that a random wine selection will turn an otherwise enjoyable dining experience into a horrible dining experience. Consider your company, too – don’t you want to make a good impression and help them enjoy their meal? The surest way to achieve this is to select a wine you already know you like. Don’t choose wines blindly.

2. Never select a wine based on price. Remember that just because a wine is expensive does not mean that it is good. Restaurant’s wine prices can be as outrageous as Richard Simmon’s outfits. Some wines are marked up to double their retail value. It doesn’t matter how much money you throw at a wine bottle, if it tastes cheap then it tastes cheap. And there’s nothing more disappointing than spending a lot of money on something you do not enjoy or appreciate.

3. Ask questions. Good restaurants will list a wine’s vintage, varietal, and price. Don’t be distracted by other, less important, information. When restaurants try to hide this, they may be trying to scam you by marking up an undesirable wine.

4. Beware of “mark up.” If you know what you would pay for the same or similar wine at the store, then don’t be suckered into paying two times or more of the wine’s retail cost. If the wine costs more than twice what you’d pay at the store, then you are paying far too much.

5. Try calling the restaurant ahead of time and ask if you can bring your own bottle of wine there. You’d be surprised at how many restaurants allow you to do this; some restaurants may simply charge a small “corking fee” for this privilege. When you call ahead, you have the additional benefit of speaking to the restaurant about its wine selection and making your plan ahead of time. If you do bring a bottle of your own, try to make sure it’s not a bottle from their menu – it would be considered rude to do so and you can expect a hassle.

6. While you might be thinking about the markup on a wine bottle, also beware of the markup on individual glasses of wine as well. Uninformed consumers can get suckered into paying far more for a glass of wine than they might pay for an entire bottle. Remember that you can get on average about four glasses of wine out of the typical bottle, so if one glass is costing you more than what the entire bottle is worth, then your smarter option is just to buy the bottle.

7. Finally, you should know that not all restaurants are trying to use wine as another way to dig deeper in to your pocket. Some restaurants are honest and have a genuine approach to their promotion and pricing of wine. At the same time, don’t be so eager to believe everything you see and hear – use your wine knowledge and your experience to guide you to make wise wine purchasing decisions.

There are just a few simply tips that can help guide you through the daunting task of ordering wine at a restaurant. The more educated, experienced, and confident you are the more like you will be to make a successful wine selection while dining out. So go with what you know about wine, and your selection should turn out fine. As always, enjoy!

These are just a few tips that can help you with the daunting task of ordering wine at your restaurant. I think the main thing to remember is to make a confident and educated decision. Go with your knowledge of what you know about wine and you should be fine. Enjoy!

title: Portuguese White Wine
post_content:
Not many people think of Portugal at all when they are thinking about wine, but Portugal produces many varieties of wine that can offer surprising and refreshing choices. Portugal produces very popular port wines and Madeira, but they also provide the world with some delicious red and white wines that are equally tempting.

The vast majority of Portuguese wines are produced in the northwest part of Portugal. These wines typically contain lower alcohol content with lots of acidity, and when compared to other wines they are described as refreshing, clean, and crisp, with hints of fruit and a touch of sweetness. Red and whites are fantastic options, but the country might actually be most largely known for what they call their “Green Wine.”

You might be most familiar with the Portuguese export called Vinho Verdes, which translates to “Green Wine” and describes the characteristics of the wine more than the color. Vinho Verdes is actually a white wine and is named after the region where it is produced. The region is in the northern part of the country, very close to the Atlantic coast.

Some of the grapes that make fantastic Portuguese white wines are the Alvarinho and Loureiro grapes. Other white wines that may stimulate your palate are Lagoalva Espirito Branco (which is a blend of Sauvignon Blanc), Alvarinho, Verdelho, Arinto and Fernao Pires. The Lagoalva wine region is located south of the Tagus River. Most of these white wines from Portugal are an excellent choice to pair with appetizers before a meal. They are also sensational with seafood and light salads.

title: How to Read a French Wine Label
post_content:
Wine drinkers know that some of the best wine in the world comes from France. But sometimes these labels can be a little mysterious to decipher. After all, they’re in French. But what’s more is that not only is the language difficult to read, the information the French wine labels display might not be the type of information you’re accustomed to finding on a label. Fortunately, there are just a few simple terms you need to learn that will turn your reading of a French wine label from a frustrating to an enjoyable experience.

First, you must understand that the French don’t label their wines according to type. For example, you won’t see “Cabernet Sauvignon” or “Merlot” on a label. This might be what you’re used to, since many of us go to the wine store and think “I want a Merlot” or “I think a Pinot Grigio will be good tonight.” Instead, the French prefer to label their wines based on location, and many bottles can give you very precise information about where the wine comes from. This might seem odd to you, but you need to learn that to the French, the region is the variety. They don’t think about wines based on what they are – they think about wines based on where they are.

All of the different regional classifications of France are broadly divided into four different labels. When you’re examining a French wine label, look for one of these four designations first:

1. First, there is the Vin de Table which is produced from a variety of different grapes and regions. This wine is usually less expensive and is not measured to specific quality standards.
2. Second, there is Vin de Pays which tells you that a wine is coming from one specific area. Usually you can find excellent wines for reasonable prices in this category.
3. Third, there is Vin Delimite de Qualite Superieure which is a classification that is a little outdated and you’re unlikely to see.
4. And fourth, perhaps the most exciting category, is called Vin d’Appellation d’Origine Controlee (AOC) which indicates that the wine is strictly controlled. This label will give you the most information, often including the specific grapes, specific region, and specific standards that are enforced to guarantee quality. It will likely even tell you the proprietor of the vineyard and it will name the estate where the grapes were grown.

Because France has very strict rules about how they produce and label their wine, all regulated wine must have one of these four designations. In fact, their system of labeling and judging wine – called the Appellation de Controlle (AOC) – is so thorough and precise that it has served as a model for other European nations.

Looking for one of these four classifications is the key when you’re reading a French wine label. Once you’ve identified the region and the quality, your last step is to take the bottle home and enjoy discovering which French regions you enjoy being transported to the best.

title: What is Rose Wine?
post_content:
Rose wines are often referred to as “blush wines.” They are not white wines, but they are not dark enough to be red wines. Contrary to the opinion of many, not all rose wines share the same characteristics.

Rose wine became popular during the 1970’s. The demand for white wine increased, but there were not enough grapes available for production. Many winemakers tried to produce white wine by using red grapes. Sutter Homes “White Zinfandel” was created in 1975 from a stuck fermentation where the yeast died early and left behind a pink, sweeter wine. The three most popular ways to make rose wines are skin contact, saignee, and blending.

Skin Contact

Skin contact is when the skins of the crushed grapes are left in contact with the wine for a certain period of time. The skins will usually have contact with the wine for one to three days. While making red wine, the skins would be left in the wine during the entire fermentation period. The longer the skins are left in contact, the darker the shade of the wine will be.

Saignee

Saignee is also known as bleeding the vats. In order to raise the tannins in a wine, the winemaker releases some of the juice from the must. The juice is lighter in color, and can be made into rose wine. The remaining red wine in the tank will have more tannin.

Blending

Blending is simply mixing red wine into white wine to give it a little bit of color. This practice is frowned upon, but it is an option as a way to make rose wine.

The term “blush” was originally used in North America, but is now used in reference to Austrailian and Italian wines as well. “Blush” was trademarked in 1978 and the name was used to market a more sweet, rose wine.

While rose wine was first made to be delicate and dry. However, after World War II, people started to prefer a sweeter taste. Grenache, Syrah, Carignan, and Zinfandel grapes are all popular to use in making this type of wine. Rose wines are now more popular than white wines in France, and they also make a great summer drink.

title: Sherry
post_content:
Sherry is not just the name of your cousin’s friend or some girl in a song (think “Sherry Baby”). The name belongs to one of the most popular fortified wine drinks, and sherry is now becoming an increasingly popular choice among wine drinkers. A great benefit of sherry is that its versatility allows it to be a desirable ingredient in many dishes, and also a drink cherished by cocktail enthusiasts. Sherry can boast that no other wine in the world is made like it. Of course, this also means that sherry is an acquired taste.

The vast history of sherry is very interesting. It has a wide range of different types and styles, and has been produced since the early 1600s. Sherry originates in southern Spain and it is a wine fortified with brandy. Even though the Moorish invasion of Spain had many downsides, one of the contributions they brought was the invention of sherry – the Moors introduced distillation to the region. The drink was originally known as Sherish (derived from Arabic).

One of sherry’s unique attributes is that it has a much longer shelf life than other wines, and this made it a great choice for transportation over long sea voyages. Sherry is produced in a system called the Solera system, in which newer vintages are mixed with older vintages, which results in a very high-quality wine. This is one of the reasons why you won’t see a vintage on a Sherry – it doesn’t have a single year it was produced.

The Many Styles of Sherry

There are a wide range of Sherries which range from dry to sweet. Some of the different types include:

Fino- Fino is traditionally the palest and driest of the varieties. It is aged under flor yeast to prevent oxygen contact.

Amontillado- This sherry is darker than fino and it is usually dry, although sometimes you will find it sold lightly sweetened.

Oloroso- Oloroso is darker and means “scented” in Spanish. This is a rich wine with a lot of alcohol in it.

Manzanilla- This type of sherry is a lighter version of Fino.

Manzanilla Pasada- This is a version of Mazanilla that has been aged and exposed to oxygen which gives it a nice, flavorful, nutty taste.

Palo Cortado- These Sherries are aged over three years

Cream Sherries- Cream or sweet Sherries are made with Moscatel grapes which give it sweetness is mixed with a drier wine.

One of the advantages of sherries is that they are both great to drink and great to cook with. So you can enjoy discovering not only which sherries you like the best, but also which sherry recipes are the most pleasing. Check out our wide selection of Sherries at www.CityWineCellar.com.

As always this is William Winehart wishing you good friends, good food, and good wine. Enjoy, my friends.

title: Shiraz, Syrah… What’s in a Name?
post_content:
Today, countries across the globe are producing wines made from both imported and native grape varietals, and the practice has spread almost as far as it possibly could in the eight thousand years or so since the first recorded vineyards in Georgia were being cultivated. The New World wine countries are no longer so ‘new’, and recent years have seen countries as diverse as India, Brazil and China begin to produce wines for the international market.

With so many countries, cultures and people establishing their own wines, methods and techniques, it should come as no surprise that certain words and terms have been changed over time. Indeed, this is nothing new at all – there has long been a huge discrepancy between the names of grape varietals in Latin language countries and Germanic language countries, which still causes confusion to this day for those travelling around Europe to taste wines. However, the one grape name which consistently causes confusion and is a source of some annoyance for various Old World purists involves the Syrah/Shiraz debate, an argument regarding the ‘real’ name of this particular grape varietal which has its roots back in France, but which has decidedly flourished in the New World.

France and Australia

In the Northern Rhone Valley of France, the Syrah grape has been cultivated for centuries, and is responsible for the large, full-bodied and fleshy red wines which epitomize the produce of the region. These deep purple, dusty grapes grow in abundance in the mineral rich soil of the Rhone valley, and they have been a stable source of income for vintners of the Rhone for generations. Partly the reason for this is due to the fact that Syrah grapes are reasonably hardy, and consistently produce quite high yields of decent quality, and partly because the jammy, fruit-forward nature of the wine is a big hit on the international market.

However, it is on the other side of the world where these grapes have really found a spiritual home, somewhere they can thrive in numbers unreachable in the relatively small Rhone Valley. In Australia, where the grapes are known by the name ‘Shiraz’, the southern regions of this hot and dry land are ideal for growing vast quantities of grapevines, resulting in a wine industry which uses this grape varietal as one of its flagship examples. Australian Shiraz wines are regarded as one of the most reliable and flavorful within any New World country, and being an affordable yet tasty red wine that matches well with a variety of international cuisines, it is a supermarket favorite with an enormous fan-base which reaches around the globe.

The History of the Name

So, if Syrah and Shiraz grapes are the same thing, why this discrepancy when it comes to the name? Where do these two names come from? The answer is one that stretches back into history, and remains surrounded by considerable debate. According to some wine historians and experts in mythology, the name ‘Shiraz’ comes from Iran, and refers to a town which made a famous ‘Shirazi’ wine which was much exported around the Mediterranean. Legend has it that these wines reached the port of Marseilles, and were so adored that the French demanded the grapes be imported and allowed to flourish in the fertile Rhone Valley. This suggests that ‘Syrah’ is merely a French synonym, and that ‘Shiraz’ is in fact the original and proper name of the grape. However, this gets called into question when many claim that whilst this legend has certainly been told for centuries, the origin of the story itself is French.

Other legends involve the wines coming from Syracuse, being brought by Roman Emperors, or being brought back from the Holy Land by crusaders. It seems all such legends have some basis in historical fact, but are impossible to prove and have plenty of evidence suggesting they are unfounded and untrue. What is curious to note is that the name ‘Shiraz’ has only really been used by Australians, leading some to claim it comes from nowhere more mysterious or evocative than a simple Anglicization or spelling error. Interestingly, however, the Shiraz wines of Australia have become so popular on the international market, that other New World countries (notably Chile and Argentina) have, in some regions, begun labeling their Syrah wines with ‘Shiraz’ in order to associate more closely with the quality Australian produce.

A Matter of Perspective

Wherever the name comes from, it is vital to remember that both of these grapes are the same, and produce similar wines despite being grown all over the world. Whilst it can be fun to explore the origins of a grape’s name, it has no bearing on the flavors or aromas that the finished product can provide, and this must surely be the most important factor when it comes to this particular grape varietal. It is perhaps also worth mentioning that the Syrah/Shiraz grape has, in fact, far more than just two names. Sometimes it is known as Balsamina, Candive, Hignin Noir, Sirac, Serine, or Entournerein. Although this all sounds complicated, you can rest easy, because these wines are all delicious.

title: Differences between Old World and New World Wines
post_content:
Old World Wine

Old World wines are produced in countries that have extensive histories and traditions of winemaking. Old World wines come primarily from parts of Europe and the Mediterranean. The term does not necessarily refer to the style of wine; it refers to the role of terroir and the practice of tradition. Old World wine countries can usually trace their history back hundreds of years. Former Roman, Greek, and Phoenician provinces can trace their winemaking histories back thousands of years. The process of making Old World wines is highly regulated. Harvesting and pruning must be done manually, whereas New World winemaking uses machines. Some wine lovers find a more subtle, soft style in Old World wines. A few countries that would fall under the Old World category are France, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Greece.

New World Wine

New World wines are not produced in traditional regions. Most of the regions that make New World wines can only trace their history back a short time. These wines might be made with new, innovative techniques or an usual blend of varietals. Hybrids, the crossing of grape varietals, are considered New World wines. New World wines are not dependent on geographical location; they have a stronger emphasis on branding.

New World wine pioneers would use grapes from any location and invent new blends. Max Shubert wanted to make the best table wine in South Australia so he invented Grange Hermitage, a blend of Shiraz and Cabernet Sauvignon. In 1951, the success of Grange marked the first recognition of the New World style. This encouraged other winemakers. New World wine countries include Argentina, Mexico, Chile, the United States, Canada, South Africa, New Zealand, and Australia.

Differences

Many wine lovers believe that New World wines have a more bold flavor than Old World wines, which are more subtle and graceful. Certain wines from Old World countries can be considered New World, such as Super Tuscans, because they are made with varietals that were not used in traditional wines. Your preference is entirely up to you, but knowing the differences of the two worlds is important knowledge to wine connoisseurs.

New World wines have been named for Old World regions, such as Champagne, Sherry, Port, and Burgundy. The reason was to make consumers believe that the wines might have an Old World taste, but many of the countries objected to the use of their names. New World wineries used grapes from many different locations, so using the name of a region can help describe the flavor of the wine. The production of Grange Hermitage inspired confidence in the varietal labeling. This new labeling system spread further during the 1960s and 1970s with the help of Robert Mondavi and other winemakers.

Old World Wine

Old World wines are produced in countries that have extensive histories and traditions of winemaking. Old World wines come primarily from parts of Europe and the Mediterranean. The term does not necessarily refer to the style of wine; it refers to the role of terroir and the practice of tradition. Old World wine countries can usually trace their history back hundreds of years. Former Roman, Greek, and Phoenician provinces can trace their winemaking histories back thousands of years. The process of making Old World wines is highly regulated. Harvesting and pruning must be done manually, whereas New World winemaking uses machines. Some wine lovers find a more subtle, soft style in Old World wines. A few countries that would fall under the Old World category are France, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Greece.

New World Wine

New World wines are not produced in traditional regions. Most of the regions that make New World wines can only trace their history back a short time. These wines might be made with new, innovative techniques or an usual blend of varietals. Hybrids, the crossing of grape varietals, are considered New World wines. title: How White Wine is Produced
post_content:
White wine, red wine, or in between: all wine is fermented grape juice, but there is a difference between red and white wines, not just in characteristics and flavor, but also production. What wine producers want from the grapes are also very different between red and white wines. In a white wine grape the goal is not to extract color and tannins but rather to retain the fruity flavor and freshness of the grapes.

After being picked, white wine grapes generally have their stems removed (sometimes, not all the time) and then they are gently crushed; just enough to have the skin of the grapes break open. The purpose of crushing the grapes is to allow the winemakers to extract more of the juice from the grapes. For certain wines (such as Champagne and Sparkling wines), this step is skipped and the grapes go to another stage known as whole-cluster pressing. In whole-cluster, the grapes are bunched together and pressed very gently to extract the juices. This does is it minimizes the amount of harsh malic acid and astringent tannins. After the crushing of the grapes comes the “cold soak” or prefermentation maceration (PFM) which extracts additional aromas and flavors from the skins into the juice. The grapes are pressed from their skins, and sometimes there is a period of cold settling which would allow any solids from the juice to fall to the bottom which would then be racked off leaving a clearer juice known as must. After the grapes are prepared and crushed, it is time for the fermentation.

Now, the grapes must be fermented with their skins, pulp and seeds. The fermentation stage of the production of white wines beginning with some yeast that is added into the must, this causes the sugars in the grapes to convert and change into alcohol and carbon dioxide. Fermentation has a lot of important variables, such as the temperature, vessel, and location. Whether the grapes are fermented in oak, stainless steel or some other type of container, nearly every decision changes the flavor and texture of the wine being produced. Certain containers go well with certain types of grapes. Chardonnay grapes are often fermented in small oak barrels, while Riesling or Sauvignon Blanc grapes are usually fermented in stainless steel vessels.

Temperature is very important to the overall quality of a white wine. White wines are usually fermented at cooler temperatures than red wines. The cooler the temperature, the more of the fruity aroma and flavor is preserved. On the other hand, he warmer temperatures produce a wine with more structure and body. Sometimes, during this stage, the wine will undergo malolactic fermentation, which converts the remaining tart malic acid in the wine into the softer lactic acid. For example, Chardonnay has a buttery note because it goes through this process.

Equally important is the next stage of production, which varies with the kind of white wine the winemaker wishes to produce. The producer can leave the wine on its lees, which is spent yeast cells, to give it a creamy texture and tastes with an aromas of butter. Or, the winemaker can let the wine chill near freezing temperatures, which is called ‘cold stabilization’, which prevents the wine from forming crystals. Then again the wine producers could age the wine in a wooden barrel, rather than leaving it in its original vessel, which would dramatically affect the taste and aroma of the wine adding marked vanilla, wood and/or even toasty flavors. Another alternative is filtering the wine to make it even clearer, but this process would remove some nuances of the flavor.

The last production stage of white wine is the aging, aging is very important to all wines. The wine can be aged in its original vessel or moved to a wooden vessel, depending on what the wine producers wishes, and will be left there for the aging process. From time to time, the winemakers can choose to stir the wine up, which allows the spent yeast to add more flavors and qualities to the wine. When the wine is ready, which is after its aging process, the wine will then be bottled and ready for shipment. But they are not shipped right after they are bottled. Usually wines that have been recently bottled will remain in the winery for some time on racks so that it gets some more aging in the bottle. Once the completed bottles are finished and have been aged properly, they will be shipped to stores, owners, buyers or collectors.

title: Liquors and Liqueurs
post_content:
It’s easy to see why someone would get confused between “liquors” and “liqueurs.” A slight change in spelling and a slight change in pronunciation make a big difference, but people frequently blend these two together and talk about one when they really want to talk about the other. I used to be one of those people, but now the differences between these two terms are as clear as day.

These two liquids do have several similarities that you should know. Both of these are considered “spirits,” which is a term used for distilled beverages. The term “spirit” is derived from the chemical process of fermenting a fruit or grain and watching the vapor of these ingredients rise. The vapor would then be captured, and the steam is then condensed into a liquid. So quite literally a “spirit” becomes the drink itself. This term was also commonly used in alchemy.

Liquor is an alcoholic liquid that typically does not have any added sugars or extracts. Vodka, rum, and whiskey are examples of liquors. The fact that liquors have no sugars or extracts added is the distinguishing difference between liquors and liqueurs. In fact, if you were to add sugars and extracts to a liquor, you would have a liqueur. Liquors can be used as a base for liqueurs.

This means that a liqueur is different because it does contain added ingredients and sweeteners. These might also be called cordials, although today we refer to cordials as being non-alcoholic. Liqueurs are infused with herbs and flavorings, and were originally concocted for medicinal purposes. An example of a liqueur is schnapps, which is usually brandy-based and infused with fruits. Flavors like peppermint, peach, and apple are created by steeping the fruits in brandy. Aperitifs are liqueurs with added herbs that stimulate appetite while digestifs aid with digestion after the meal.

We tend to loosely exchange these terms in conversation, but now you can have a better understanding between their differences. Hopefully now you know when you should or should not use one of these terms, and the next time it comes up in conversation, you’ll be able to use the right one.

title: The Noble Grapes and the Wines They Make
post_content:
There are countless varieties of grapes in the world, many of which have been used for wine production for thousands of years. Ever since the ancient civilisations of Georgia first began cultivating wild grapevines over eight thousand years ago, efforts have been made to make the most of indigenous strains wherever they grow. Over time, knowledge of how to cross-breed, clone and enhance nature’s bounty has spread grapes around the world, and vintners and wine scientists have created new strains developed specifically for wine production, prized for their flavor, their aromas, their ability to age well or their ability to express specific characteristics of the terroir on which they grow.

Wine production is an ever-developing field of agriculture, and even today we are seeing new strains of grape come forward or be re-discovered and heralded as important steps towards achieving viticultural perfection. Who knows what will happen in the near future? Now that China, India and Brazil are stepping up their wine industries, we can expect to see some huge jumps in viticultural technique and technology over the next few years, and it wouldn’t be surprising if some new or forgotten grape varietals begin to appear on bottles on the shelves of our wine stores or supermarkets.

Despite the enormous range of grape varietals in the world, there have always been those strains which are so revered, so appreciated for the quality and character of the wine which they produce, that they have gone down in history as the grapes of choice for those wineries wishing to produce world-beating and widely loved produce. These are the ‘noble grapes’ – a term being used less and less in today’s wine industry, but one which still hold some reverence among those pursuing perfection in a bottle. These grapes are handy signifiers of quality for those unsure about trying something new or unusual. To see a noble grape listed as the only or primary grape varietal on a bottle gives the buyer some idea of what to expect, as the characteristics, flavors and aromas of these grapes have been written about and discussed extensively. The ‘noble grapes’ offer something to both the expert and the novice, as they can be appreciated for their subtler points and their classic characteristics, just as they can allow a beginner to the world of wine a safe introduction in regards to what to expect from a quality bottle.

A noble grape is one which has proven to produce exceptional quality wines without the use of blending. This is important, as an unblended wine allows the true character of the single grape to shine. When we blend grape juices, the aim is to highlight the best features of each selected grape, to cover up its weaker points, or to balance out certain aspects of its natural character. Unblended bottles rely on the excellence of the varietal in regards to all its features: flavor and aroma, to dryness or sweetness, body, length and complexity.

Because the noble grape varietals were classified some time ago, it comes as little surprise that they are almost all French. This has led plenty of people to question the list’s relevance today, as plenty of other countries have since proven that their native grapes are more than capable of producing exceptional quality single variety wines, and this should probably be kept in mind. A modern list of ‘noble grapes’ would most likely be considerably longer than the small selection we have inherited from the golden age of French winemaking.

In white wine, there are three noble grape varietals. These are Sauvignon Blanc, Chardonnay and Riesling. Each of these white grapes have vastly different characteristics, and make very different white wines, each considered to be among the best in the world. With Chardonnay, we have the soft, rounded, almost buttery nature which comes about through the process of malolactic fermentation associated with the grape, proving to be a favorite for its subtlety and surprising versatility. Riesling has the ability to express terroir through its crispness, and Sauvignon Blanc produces a wide range of excellent white wines, whether grassy, fruity, plump or aged.

When it comes to red wine, the noble varietals include Merlot, which is renowned for its ability to produce wonderfully soft and rounded medium bodied wines, packed full of jammy and fruity flavors. The elegant and romantic Pinot Noir also makes the list, loved by all for its lightness, its gorgeous garnet color and its delicate flavors. The strong, astringent Cabernet Sauvignon is also included for its dryness, its full body and the fact that there is surely no other varietal which ages so well in oak, taking on earthy, spicy and fascinating complexity notes in the process.

title: What is Noble Rot?
post_content:
Botrytis Cinerea, also know as “Noble Rot,” is a grey fungus that grows only on certain fruits. A moist environment enables this fungus to grow into the initial stage called “Grey Rot.” Noble Rot can help produce sweetness in wines. The grapes usually become infected while they are ripe and shrivel into raisins when exposed to dryer conditions. Some winemakers purposely use this method to make sweeter wines.

Infected grapes have been used in winemaking since around 1570, but it was not until 1730 that vineyards in Southeast Slovakia began to classify those wines. Noble Rot grapes are used to produce very distinctive dessert wines such as Tokay, Tokaji, Aszu, and Sauternes.

Botrytis Cinerea is Latin for “grapes like ashes,” which is a reference to their color. The fungus dehydrates the grapes, leaving behind high concentrations of sugar, acid, and minerals. The most concentrated products possess a honey smell and a bitter finish. Noble Rot can also also affect fruits like strawberries and tomatoes. Workers who pick Noble Rot grapes can contract a rare hypersensitivity pneumonitis called “winegrower’s lung.”

While there are many stories about the practice of making wine from Noble Rot, one popular tale involves the Schloss Johannisberg winery in the Rheingau region. The Riesling producer awaited approval from Heinrich von Bibra, bishop of Fulda and the estate owner, before cutting the grapes. Von Bibra sent his abbey to give approval, but the abbey was robbed en route to deliver the message. The harvest was lost to rot and given to the peasants. However, the peasants made sweet wine from the rotted grapes. It became known as Spatlese or “late harvest” wine.

title: Jug Wines
post_content:
What could be better than a bottle of wine? How about a jug of it? In fact, jug wine is a term used to refer to really large bottles, usually in 3, 4, or 5-liter volumes. A bottle of wine might be sufficient for one or two people, but jug wine comes in handy when serving a party or special event.

Individuals might mistake jug wine with cheap wine, but the different between a jug’s and bottle’s quality are not significant. Plus, when drinking from a jug, it is more of the quantity than quality that you might be concerned with, anyways. =)

While you might be very familiar with what a jug is, you might not be aware of some of the varieties that jugs can show up in. Jugs typically consist of clay, glass, or plastic materials. Mankind has an intimate history with jugs; for example, Native Americans produced their jugs from sealing the inside of their woven baskets with a material called asphaltum. In other cultures, empty jugs easily double as percussion instruments. And you’ll also find a series of amusing jugs in barrooms the world over, created to entertain patrons, like the puzzle jug or Toby jug.

The puzzle jug might look like the Exeter puzzle jug, which had many holes in the top of the jug and the goal was to drink the liquid inside without spilling any. Another type of jug is the Toby Jug, also known as a Fillpot. This pottery jug takes on the form of a seated and usually recognizable person of status, like an English king.

title: Joining a Wine Club
post_content:
Wine is enjoyable on any occasion, but sharing wine in a group can truly amplify the experience. Joining a wine club may be just the step you need to to take to transform wine drinking into a fun, memorable, social experience. Clubs offer an array of benefits that any regular wine drinker will find advantageous.

The Social Wine Club

Some of the strongest friendships are forged over common interests. If drinking wine is one of your interests, then it is likely you will have fun sharing this experience with like-minded people. You may also find yourself learning a great deal about wine you didn’t know before.

The sharing, the conversations, and the relationships all enhance the overall wine drinking experience. Many people in social clubs are exposed to ideas or techniques, or even entirely new wines that they would never have discovered otherwise. Information related to flavors, aromas, terminology, and other wine drinking opportunities will all arrive thanks to sharing your experience with other enthusiasts. You, too, might have plenty to offer other individuals.

There are many free wine clubs where all you do have to bring is a nice bottle of wine and join in the fun. Another benefit is that most of the time discussions about wine topics are usually led by the manager, director, or administrator of the club, so there is no pressure on you to sound overly fancy about wine. Check out what your community has by asking around or investigating online.

Internet Wine Clubs

As long as you’re investigating online, you might also consider joining an internet wine club. Internet wine clubs provide you with exposure to a wide variety of red and white wines that you might never have considered before. Internet wine clubs are also famous for the discount opportunities they offer. Through your club, you might be able to make a wine subscription to receive variety of wines at a variety of discounts.

Make sure, though, that you’re aware of your state’s laws about internet wine and orders: transporting alcohol via mail may be subject to certain regulations, and you want to make sure that you’re enjoying your drinks legally. Both types of wine clubs offer great opportunities to explore and become a more educated wine connoisseur. Before joining a club, make sure you do some research and find out all the details. Ask your friends or your local wine shop if they can give you any information about these clubs. Most times your local wine shop will have a wine club or a website where you can get discounts and offers. title: Healthy Wine
post_content:
When drunk in moderation, wine can help improve your health. Most of the research that has been done on the benefits of drinking wine focuses on the antioxidant resveratrol, which can also be found in grape juice and certain plants. Experiments have reported that resveratrol has beneficial cardiovascular, anti-inflammatory, and anti-cancer effects. It can be found in the skin of red fruits, especially grapes.

Any wine that is red in color or has the skins left in the wine during production will be richer in resveratrol than white wine. While the levels of resveratrol are low, moderate wine consumption can still benefit your health. Cabernet Sauvignon and dry wines will contain some amount of this antioxidant.

More research is needed on resveratrol, but you must also consider the possible negative aspects of drinking wine for health. When abused, it can cause alcoholism and weight gain, leading to health problems in the future. These wines may contain pesticides or chemicals added during processing that might have negative health effects. It is also possible for organic wines to have chemicals added to them. Although there are good benefits, not all red wines are healthy.

title: How many calories are in wine?
post_content:
With our culture telling us to eat smarter, count calories, and exercise often, and with a media reporting that America’s obesity rate is increasing quickly, it’s little wonder that we should begin to question the impact of wine on our weight. Red wine has received a lot of good medical press recently for its positive influence on our cardiovascular health. But before you indulge in too much red wine as part of your health plan, make sure you’re aware of the calories you’re consuming as well. Make sure that when you begin regularly consuming anything, including wine, you’re educated on how it could affect your total health.

Thankfully, you don’t have to worry about fat content in wine – there isn’t any. However, do pay attention to the sugar content. Wine is not candy, but like any natural product from fruits or vegetables, it contains natural sugars. Sugar tastes great and generally only becomes detrimental to our waistlines when we consume more sugar than we burn. Sugar is not naturally fattening, but when our body does not consume all of the calories sugar brings in, it stores those calories as fat, thus leading to weight gain. At 16 calories per teaspoon, sugar might introduce more calories to our systems than are welcome.

Don’t take this as bad news, though. Just like any other consumption, moderation and knowledge are the keys to good health. Below you will find estimated information on the amount of calories contained in a bottle of wine. Use this to help make educated decisions about how much wine would fit your diet.

Calories per varietal:

Port, Muscatel, fortified wines: These wines, especially fortified wines may be high in alcohol. These wines are also on the sweeter side and contain more sugar than other wines. These wines can contain anywhere from 900 calories to 1,200 calories per bottle.

Cream sherry, Sweet, fortified wines: While not as high in calories as the above category, these wines can also contain high levels of alcohol, and sugar levels approach 1,065 calories per bottle.

Dry, fortified, Sherry wines: These wines can contain high levels of alcohol and around anywhere from 600 to 780 calories per bottle. If one serving size glass is around 6 oz., than you can get around 4 to 5 glasses out of a 750ml size bottle.

Champagne, Sparkling wines: Frequently these pleasant, refreshing drinks are unavoidable for celebrations and toasts. On average a bottle of champagne can contain anywhere from 450 to 531 calories per bottle.

Red wines, Rose, medium bodied wines: These wines are actually among the healthiest for you. Red wine contains high levels of resveratrol which studies have shown can help reduce the thickening of arteries and help improve cardiovascular disease. Red wines contain around 500 to 562 calories per bottle, which compared to other wines is quite reasonable.

White wines, dry, table white wines: These fantastic companions to light meals and appetizers will run anywhere between 480 to 560 calories per bottle.

You may or may not intend to drink an entire bottle, but you can estimate the number of calories per glass by considering a glass to be roughly 6 oz. Some simple division will help you calculate how many calories you’re adding to your diet with each glass. Of course, your own glass size might vary. Also, the true calorie count depends specifically on which wine you are drinking as well.

Calorie count gives only a partial picture of how a wine will affect your total health. Moderate wine consumption can provide an impressive range of health benefits, including decreased risk of stroke, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, osteoporosis and cardiovascular disease. Doctors urge older patients to drink about a glass of red wine a day with dinner: 140g to 210 grams per week for men and 84g- 140 grams per week for women.

Of course, over-consumption of wine or any type of alcohol abuse will introduce problems to your health, as well as possibly other areas of life. And as you have likely heard before, consumption is not recommended for pregnant women or women who breastfeed.

Below is a chart that helps clarify some of the comparables between wines.

*These are estimates based on average bottles of wine. Some wines may contain more sugars than others.

Wine Calories Fat(g) Carb Protein Amount
Wine, Fortified, Port, Muscatel 1,120 0 98 1.5(g) 750ml
Wine, Cream Sherry, Sweet Sherry, Fortified 1070 0 87 1.5 g 750ml
Wine, Dry, Sherry, Fortified 790 0 7.5 0 750ml
Champagne, Sparkling wines, Cava, Prossecco, average 540 0 12.5 0 750ml
Red Wine, Rose, Medium bodied 500 0 4.7 0 750ml
White wines, table, dry wines 560 0 7.5 0 750ml
Sake, Rice wines, Wines with higher alcohol 415 0 9.4 0.8 750ml

title: How to Become a Sommelier
post_content:
Sometimes you might study a menu at a restaurant and desire to know which wines are best paired with which menu selections. Then, likely one of two things has occurred: either the waiter – sometimes called a wine waiter – has been able to inform you about a certain wines’ prices and the basic label information, or a gentleman with a funny looking ribbon around his neck has been able to inform you in detail about which wines are best paired with certain menu choices.

A wine waiter is really little more than a waiter at a restaurant who only knows a little bit about what he can remember from the wine labels. This is only head knowledge and tells you extremely little about how a wine tastes. The gentleman with the ribbon who intimately knows wines’ tastes, textures, and pairings is known as a sommelier (pronounced suh-moll-ee-ay), and he likely understands not only the ideal food pairings, but even  details like a wine’s history.

Many sommeliers will forego wearing the ribbon, but the ribbon represents a portion of this profession’s history. Since wine was typically stored in dim cellars, it was rather difficult for sommeliers to judge a wine’s clarity and color in the poor lighting. Sommeliers wore a tastevin around their neck, which is a small cup with a reflective interior that amplified the amount of light directed at the wine. Even though modern lighting makes tastevins obsolete, many sommeliers wear the ribbon as a matter of tradition.

Sommeliers seem to have an extraordinary talent, but becoming one yourself is actually not too difficult once you understand the basic information. Of course, there are different levels of sommeliers just as there are different level chefs or karate masters. There are four different levels of certification. The introductory level begins with participating in a two-day seminar, but each successive level is increasingly difficult to achieve. Achieving the rank of master sommelier means that you will pass a variety of challenging tests, such as blindly identifying six different wines just by tasting them. Another challenge involves prospective masters giving tips for correctly opening and pouring still and sparkling wines while also being asked difficult questions from the previous tests. As you might have guessed, the passing rates of those taking the masters certification tests are rather low.

However, if wine is your passion and you have the strong desire to have the title of master sommelier, then the time you spend practicing and studying will be one of the most rewarding activities you could take up. In fact, becoming a sommelier might turn out to be a fantastic way to indulge in your hobby as well provide that unique boost to your resume.

title: How to Read an Italian Wine Label
post_content:
Many Americans know just enough Italian to order their favorite pasta – spaghetti, ravioli, gnocchi, and so on. But many of us stick to the standard wines we know and avoid the foreign ones – like the Italian wines – because we cannot discern what the foreign labels actually say. Although you might be able to make out what an Italian restaurant menu says, if you are not fluent in Italian, reading an Italian wine label can be an intimidating process.

Fortunately, there are only a few simple things you need to know that will transform reading an Italian wine label from a mystery into a pleasure. The biggest thing you need to know is that Italians label their wine in one of five classifications. Once you discern which classification the Italian Wine label has, the easier it will be to read the rest of the information.

The five classifications consist of the following:

Denominazione di Origine Controllata e Garantita (DOCG)- This is the highest classification for traditional Italian wine. It was established in 1963 and is designated for high-quality wines. The word garantita stands for “guarantee.” Every wine that falls under the DOCG classification has gone through very strict government rules before distribution, and each bottle has a numbered government seal across the neck. If a wine label has this on it, then it will likely contain much more additional information about the wine’s production as well.

Denominazione de Origine Controllata (DOC) – A majority of the wine in Italy falls under this classification. It is very similar to the French and their (AOC). The DOC and the DOCG place restrictions on the grape varieties, alcohol percentages and processing techniques involved in the wine’s production.

Indicazione Geografica Tipica (IGT) – This classification was created around 1992 and is also known as the “Goria Law”. Named after the minister of agriculture, this classification covers all the wines that don’t fall the DOC and the DOGC. The possibility that these wines don’t fall under the other classifications may be because of the varietals used and so these wines are considered Vino da Tavolas (VDT).

Vino da Tavola (VDT)- This classification covers all wines considered table wines. These wines do not follow the strict regulations. Some quality wines do fall under this classification because they don’t follow traditional guidelines.

Super Tuscans- A super tuscan is an Italian wine that doesn’t follow traditional Italian wine making techniques. They usually are a blend with grapes like Cabernet Sauvignon or Merlot. Some Super-Tuscans can be of high quality.

When you find yourself staring at a shelf full of Italian wine labels, you don’t have to shy away from reading them. Instead, identify the type of classification it hosts on its label, and then you’ll know much more about the type and quality of wine you’ll soon be enjoying!

title: How to Read Wine Label from Spain
post_content:
Sometimes staring down a confusing foreign wine label can be just as frustrating as looking at a broken car engine when you know nothing about cars: you know there’s a message there, but you just don’t have the experience or knowledge to know what you’re looking at. However, just like knowing about cars can help you fix the engine, knowing about wine labels can help you select the ideal wines. Sometimes we have the impulse to buy a wine just based on its label (even though we don’t know what the label says) and then we only disappoint ourselves. Although wine labels will vary by the producer, Spanish wine labels all generally contain the same basic information.

Spanish wine laws and classification:

D.O. or Denominacion de Origen is a term assigned to Spanish wines and foods. It is very similar to France and their A.O.C. (Appellation d’Origine Controlee). It is a classification system which establishes and regulates the quality of Spanish wine. The D.O. guarantees specific characteristics of geographical regions and no materials outside of that region will be permitted in the bottle. This classification system helps protect vineyards and consumers. The D.O. is the mainstream grading system and there are about 120 regions that are classified under this system. New subgroups were adopted in 1986.

D.O.C. or Denominacion de Origen Calificada is determined by the national committee. They determine which D.O.s are deserving for D.O.C. status. These wines usually follow strict requirements, one of which  is that the wine costs at least double that of the national average.
In 2003 Spain revised the laws and sanctioned new categories which include:

Vinos de la Tierra (VDLT) – These are considered the wines of the country. This is one level above Vino de Mesa.

Vino de Mesa (VDM) – This wine is the lowest quality and considered table wine.

They also created a category called D.O. Pago which applies to a single estate wine. Pago means vineyard, and this term applies to a wine that is wholly created and bottled in that region or area.

Spanish Wine Aging Terms:

Sometimes you may see a word like Reserva or Crianza on a Spanish wine label. These words explain the age of the wine. There are minimum requirements a wine must have to receive one of these terms:

Joven: This term is for younger wine which is usually sold one year after harvest.
Crianza: This wine is aged a minimum of two years with one year in a barrel.
Reserva: This wine is usually three years old and spends at least one year in the barrel.
Gran Reserva: This wine is five years old and spends two years in a barrel.

These terms are observed by the DOC and the DO. The Reservas and Gran Reservas of Spain are some of the greatest valued wines in the world. While not all wine is meant to be aged, the reservas, when aged, produce one of the best and most memorable wine tastes.

Reading the label:

1. Name: This shows the name of the wine.
2. Vintage: This shows the year of production.
3. Bodega: The bodega is another term for winery.
4. Region: The region is the location where the grapes have been grown.
5. Alcohol Content: This shows the amount of alcohol in the wine.
6. Size: This shows the size of the bottle.

Sometimes the label might show the varietal which is the type of grape used to make the wine. Some popular varietals include Garnacha, Albarino, Priorat, Malvasia, and Viura.

Reading a Spanish wine label – now that you know what you’re looking at – can be rather simple now. Just the translation of a few words, the identification of a label’s classification, and the discerning of its basic information will help you figure out which Spanish wine is right for you. Spain produces many delicious varietals, and Spain’s winemakers possess the passion that enables them to create magnificent products year after year.
