Sometimes the label might show the varietal which is the type of grape used to make the wine. Some popular varietals include Garnacha, Albarino, Priorat, Malvasia, and Viura.

Reading a Spanish wine label – now that you know what you’re looking at – can be rather simple now. Just the translation of a few words, the identification of a label’s classification, and the discerning of its basic information will help you figure out which Spanish wine is right for you. Spain produces many delicious varietals, and Spain’s winemakers possess the passion that enables them to create magnificent products year after year.

title: How to Read a Wine Label from the United States
post_content:
After being inundated with wine labels from France, Spain, Italy, Australia, and so many other places around the world, it can be rather refreshing to finally lay your eyes on a wine label from the U.S. And the truth is that it is a lot easier to read American wine labels, not only because they’re in English, but because they also feature information that we might be more used to looking for. Wine labels – when you know what you’re looking at – can be very useful sources of information for telling us about the location, wineries, varietals, vintages, and many other useful terms that help us choose the wine that is best.

In 1983, the federal government ruled that all domestic wine labels must contain, at minimum, a certain amount of information. Learning how to accurately read a label is only to your advantage – inaccurate labels are illegal, so this helps to enforce quality.

Remember that just because a bottle or a label looks good does not necessarily mean the wine inside is worth it. Here are the basic informational components you want to keep your eyes open for:

1. Name of Vineyard: This is optional information that vineyards may add because the property of the winery might produce high-quality grapes. Some vineyards might be well-known for the quality of their production, so they would most likely mention the vineyard on the label.

2. Vintage: The vintage is the year the grapes were harvested, and it is very important because wine differs year to year due to climate changes. There are published charts you can consult to determine which year was the best in certain regions.

3. Region: Region or Appellation of Origin (AOC) explains the region within certain states or geographical distinctions. California laws require that 100% of the grapes come from within California. Other states require at least 75% of the grapes come from that state. When a label states a particular area like “Napa Valley,” it means that at least 85 % of the grapes used come from that area.

4. Varietals: The varietal is the wine type. In the label above it says “Cabernet Sauvignon.” In 1983 the law stated that a varietal must contain at least 75% of the varietal listed. Remember that 100% varietals are not automatically better wines. Some of the best wines use different percentages of different grapes to create exotic flavors. Prior to 1983, the law required only 51% of the named varietal.

5. Alcohol Percentage: The alcohol percentage states the amount of alcohol the wine contains by volume. This is a mandatory requirement for all wines.

The government also intervened in 1988 and established a mandatory law declaring the quantity of sulfites that wine must contain, and all wines that have level above 10 parts per million of sulfur dioxide must clearly publish this on the label. You’ll also notice that wine labels have a federal warning, similar to the statements you used to see on cigarettes – this warning is thanks to another 1989 federal law.

Remember that even though there is a minimum requirement for how much information is published on the label, the actually quantity and design will differ depending on the producer. Thankfully, the words and appearances on United States’ wine labels can be comforting and relatively easy to read. If you’re interested in learning more about how to read wine labels from other countries, then check out my other blogs – you’ll notice that many countries choose to label their wines differently.

As always this is William Wineheart wishing you good friends, good food, and good wine…enjoy!

title: Does the Cost of Wine Determine Quality?
post_content:
Like many people, I used to think that the more I spent on a bottle of wine, the better it would be. Basically, I used to equate price to quality, and this equation is one of the largest misconceptions when it comes to wine. There is an “aura” surrounding expensive wine, and too many consumers believe that the quality of a wine is measured by its price. I often see consumers give me “the face” when I recommend to them a reasonably priced wine that has rated well. They believe, like I used to, that they should be paying more for good wine, but this is not necessarily true.

The price of a wine can depend on many factors, from the number of bottles produced to the location in which the grapes were grown.  Here are a few key characteristics:

Quantity- The quantity of wine that the vineyard produces is one factor that determines its cost. If a vineyard makes 20,000 cases of a wine, they can sell each bottle for less than a vineyard that produces only 200 cases would. The less wine a vineyard produces, the higher its prices might be. In this case, you’re paying for rarity, not quality.

Single Vineyard- Single Vineyard is a term used for wines that are produced from a only one vineyard, and it usually is associated with the signature style of the vineyard. Some wines are blends of different vintages or grapes from different regions which lowers their cost compared to single vineyard wines.

Location- Sometimes, the price is influenced by coming from a certain area that is known for producing really good wine. For example, Napa Valley, CA, is known for exceptional wines, and its location and its reputation help Napa Valley vineyards increase their prices a little more.

Estate Wines- Estate bottled wines are wineries that grow and produce their wine all in one location. Not to be confused with Single Vineyard, Estate bottled wines are all grown, picked, and produced in one winery, whereas Single Vineyard wines could acquire their grapes from a region outside the winery. The economics of an estate wine’s production influence the final bottle price.

Vintage- The vintage is the year the wine was produced. Sometimes a good climate or good weather could make for a great year or great vintage. The vintages are rated by all the major wine publications, which publish vintage charts. For example, in 2007, Napa and most of California had nearly perfect weather conditions, so that year made for a desirable vintage.

Production Costs- Sometimes manually-picked grapes, as compared to machine-picked grapes, can factor into the cost of a wine. Some vineyards that have hills or rough terrain may need to manually pick their grapes, and so their production costs are higher.

Wine Store- Another factor is where you buy your wine from. Some stores mark their wine up to make a certain profit. Other stores, such as a bigger wine shop, have the available space to purchase quantity-discounted wine and in turn can offer a lower price to the public.

These are a few of the most important factors that ultimately go into determining the price you pay for wine. Notice that these factors have a little to do with quality, but also include considerations of production, retail, and brand. The conclusion of this knowledge is that there are many lower priced wines that are equal, if not better, than high priced wines. Of course, when choosing a wine, don’t let the price be your guide. The best way to find another quality wine is by word-of-mouth.

title: Does Wine Vintage Matter?
post_content:
When we think of the word “vintage” we often think of something old that is good enough in some way to keep around. Cars, clothing, and memorabilia from previous eras are “vintage” when we value the age they represent and the current trend has brought it back into style. In fact, their age sets them apart from their modern counterparts. We often connect the vintage with “classic,” and we also connect these both to “good.” But when it comes to wines, is vintage always good? The truth is that vintage wines can be an important quality, but not in all situations.

The word “vintage” does not have the same meaning for wines and classic cars. When considering a vintaged wine, the vintage is referring to a wine produced in a particular area in a particular year. Just glance at any label and you will see a wine’s vintage when you read its location and year of origin. Do understand, though, that certain countries allow their wines to be mixed with wines from other years – they do this to maintain a consistent taste in the wine over time.

To better understand the vintages of wines, you can see how your vintage is rated on a vintage chart.

Vintage Charts

The natural cycles of nature bring good and bad years for wines. A vintage chart helps catalog which years for which wines were good, and which were bad. The factors that contribute to the good or bad rating a vintage chart lists include climate, region, and weather. Grapes suffer from even slight alterations in their growing conditions, and these small changes can make the difference between a good wine and a bad one. Many vintage charts are available in major wine publications such as Wine Spectator, Wine Enthusiast, and Wine Advocate. Many wine enthusiasts refer to these charts as guides when selecting their next wine purchase.

Remember that a vintage chart is not a guaranteed seal of approval: just because a certain region had a great vintage year doesn’t mean that all of the wine from that area is going to be good. The vintage chart is only a guide that provides estimates and recommendations, not guarantees. If you really want to use a vintage chart effectively, use it as a portion of your wine purchasing toolbox: consult charts, experts’ opinions, and your own experiences and preferences to find a wine that is truly pleasing to you.

The vintage’s importance is debatable. Although it serves as a guide, it is possible that high quality modern farming techniques can turn a so-so year into a good one. Vintage’s relevance also depends on the types of wines you purchase. The wines that elude the grip of the vintage chart are the wines that are not meant to age; young wines and wines with no aging potential are the exceptions to such charts. For example, Carlo Rossi table wines don’t list a vintage because their shelf life is so short.

So before leaping to a vintage chart, consider what wines you plan to buy. If you are a die-hard collector or if you want to purchase a gift for a wine lover, then definitely consult these charts and consider the vintage. But if you’re just looking for a good drink, don’t worry too much about the vintage – just enjoy.

As always I wish you good eats, good friends, and great wine.

title: Does Wine Cause Headaches?
post_content:
Sulfites

Sometimes, people complain that red wine gives them headaches. Some people suffer extreme migranes with blinding white spots after drinking a glass of wine. Some even get symptoms of nausea and flushing. Most of the myths associated with headaches from sulfites comes from the warning sticker on most wine bottles stating the wines contain sulfites. People generally see this warning and automatically believe that this is the cause of their headaches. No one knows for sure why this happens but it is not because of the sulfites. All wines contain sulfites, but what many don’t know is that white wines, dried fruits, and even processed lunch meats contain more sulfites than red wine. In fact, only 1% of the general population is sensitive to sulfites.

Tannins

Some people suggest, wrongly, that tannins are the cause of headaches from wine. Tannins are flavonoids that give wine the characteristics of being dry. Red wines have more tannins than white wines. Tannins play an important role in preventing oxidation. During aging, the tannins gradually become sediment, but until then they are vital to giving a wine the ability to age. Studies show that tannins cause the release of serotonin which may possibly cause headaches but more research is needed. Chocolate, soy and teas contain tannins like wine but, curiously, people do not report having similar reactions.

Histamines

A study reported in the Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (Feb 2001) showed that histamines whether in low or high doses had any effect or produced any headaches in their test subjects. Only in rare cases people were affected by histamines. The solution is to take a Claritin an hour before drinking to see if you have a histamine reaction.

Prostaglandins

Prostaglandins can contribute to pain and swelling because some people are not able to metabolize them. A prostaglandin is a group of compounds that come from fatty acids and have an important function in the body. Similar to hormones, they act as mediators and aid in the regulating the contraction and relaxation of smooth muscle tissue. Ibuprofen and acetaminophen as well as aspirin act as inhibitors and some may benefit from taking these before or after the consumption of wine.

Remedies

These are just a few of the causes of headaches and by experimenting with the preventive measures; you might be able to figure out what your allergic reaction is from. More studies are needed to determine the association of headaches and wine. Many customers come in to the store to try a sulfite-free wine, hoping to battle their severe headaches. Unfortunately, many of these customers come back looking for other solutions. Sulfite-free wines although say sulfite free may still contain natural sulfites and the label usually suggests that no additional sulfites have been added to the wine. In my experience, sometimes the brand of wine may be the most important factor, and it is just a matter of finding the right wine for you.

title: German Wine Classifications
post_content:
Those of you who begin getting acquainted with the exotic words associated with wine and bottle labels often feel that familiar intimidation resurface when it comes to German wines. Every once in a while I get in the mood for a nice sweet wine or dessert wine to sip on after a nice meal, and Riesling is ideal for many of these occasions. However, just one glance as words like Spatlese or Eiswein are enough to turn away even the most adventurous palates. No wonder people often walk right past the Riesling section.

Fortunately, by just learning a little bit about how German wine is classified and labeled, intimidating and unfamiliar wines can become dear friends. German wine is classified into several different quality categories based on several factors including region, sweetness, and the ripeness of the grapes. This system, developed in 1971, is different from the majority of wine classification systems set up across the globe. Many producers have criticized this system for not showing a large enough difference between better and lesser quality vineyards. Worse yet, wine drinkers uncomfortable with reading German will naturally have problems understanding the information placed on labels.

The easiest way to understand the German wine classification system is by knowing that there are two basic principles that the wine is separated into: Sweetness and Quality. The quality levels of these principles are defined into four categories.

Quality Categories

Deutscher Tafelwein- This quality level is associated with basic table wine. The European equivalent is Vin de Table. The alcohol level must be at least 8.5% by volume. This wine is produced exclusively from allowed German-grown varieties in one of the country’s five regions. The total acidity must reach a level of 4.5 grams/liter.

Deutscher Landwein- This wine is also known as German country wine, equivalent to the Europeans’ Vin de Pays. This classification was introduced in 1982 and the wine must come from one of the 19 regions where the grapes must reach an alcohol level of at least 0.5% or higher. The wine must be dry or off-dry in style. These wines can also be referred to as German fruit wines.

Qualitatswein bestimmter Anbaugebiete (QBA)- This wine is considered good quality and must be made of allowed varieties from 13 wine growing regions. The alcohol level must reach at least 7% by volume and the region must be shown on the label. QBAs range from semi-sweet to dry, and this information is usually located on the label.

Pradikatswein- This was renamed in 2007 from Qualitatswein mit Pradikat (QMP). This is the top-level wine in the German classification system. These wines range from dry to intensely sweet. The wine must be produced by grapes from the allowed 13 regions with an alcohol level of at least 7% by volume.

By just glancing at a German wine bottle label now, you can determine the quality of wine. When you identify which of the four classifications your bottle falls into, you’ll have a strong idea of what degree quality the wine possesses.

The second way to determine what the wine is like is by examining the sweetness levels indicated on the label.

Sweetness Classifications

Kabinett- This is a fully ripe light wine that is typically semi-sweet unless otherwise stated on the label. It possesses a very crisp and clean texture.

Spatlese- Spatlese is actually translated into “late harvest” and is on the sweeter side, unless designated as a full-bodied dry wine. Although Spatlese is not as dry as a dessert wine, it is fruitier and sweeter than Kabinett.

Auslese- Auslese means “select harvest” and is made from very ripe bunches or grapes that sometimes have the noble rot character which makes them semi-sweet or sweet. Auslese can also come in a very powerful dry wine if designated as such, and can be considered a dessert wine. This classification can cover an extensive quantity and range of wines.

Beerenauslese- This is translated in to “select berry harvest” (SBH) and is made from individually selected grapes affected by noble rot, which makes for a rich and sweet dessert wine.

Eiswein- Also considered an Ice wine, this is made from grapes that have been naturally frozen, making a very concentrated wine. This classification is required to have the same level of sugar as a Beerenauslese. Until 1980, Eisweins used grapes that were affected by noble rot.

Trockenbeerebauslese- Trockenbeerebauslese is translated into “select dry berry harvest.” This wine is made from overripe shriveled grapes often affected by noble rot, making them extremely sweet and rich.

Symbols and other descriptive words

German wines have very information labels, providing lots of information that other countries’ wines do not. In fact, there are names for just about everything on the labels, and unlocking the language is the key to discovering what each bottle contains. There is even wording for the color of the wine. For exampale, Weinwein is the word for white wine, Rotwein is Red wine, Rosewein is Rose wine. Weinherbst is rose or a blanc de noir, made from the pinot noir grape. Weinherbst must be made from Pradikatswein, or QBA. There are no restrictions on the color, and the wine ranges from dry to sweet.

Beyond wording, sometimes the label’s design tells you what you need to know about a German wine. You might find a gold foil on the bottle which indicates that the producer considers it better-than-average. Stars indicate that a Pradikatswein has been harvested at a higher level of ripeness than minimum requirements allow. Stars also indicates that the wine will be sweeter.

Fuder (vat) numbers usually indicate a better wine and often the numbers added to the label are arranged in order. Most wines in the Mosel region usually label their semi-sweet and sweet wines with numbers.

German wine classifications can get a little more detailed with wines from special regions. These wines include Liebfraumilch, Moseltaler, Riesling Hochgewachs, Rotling, Schillerwein, and Badisch Rotgold.

Dry Wine Classifications

When it comes to dry wines, there are three official classifications that you’ll see on wines bottled after 2000. There are also a few unofficial labels that you may observe:

Classic is dry or off-dry and conforms to higher standards. This wine is food-friendly and made from varietals from regions considered classical.

Selection is a wine that is a Spatlese trocken from a selected site.

Erstes Gewachs is used only in Rheingau for top level dry wines from selected sites.

Grosses Gewachs is a designation used by VDP members. This wine is designated as a top-level dry wine from a selected sites used by the Bernkasteler Ring.

Erste Lage is a designation used to denote selected sites suitable for Erstes Gewachs and Grosses wines. Also used by VDP in Mosel to design top level wines from selected sites.

Yes, it certainly does get a little complicated with all the different names and labeling, and considering that it’s all in German, one can definitely say that it takes time and practice to develop a comfort with accessing German wine labels. But if you know the four levels of sweetness and the four levels of quality, then you should be able to determine what wine is suitable for your tastes.

German wine labels are pretty easy to understand once you known the language and words used to describe the wine. Every label should have the vintage, the winery, the varietal, the ripeness, the vineyard, region, and government approved number or an AP#. The VDP used in the above descriptions stands for an elite group of winemaking estates in Germany which label which wines are approved with their logo of an eagle with the VDP above it. meta_keywords: German Wines, Wine Classification, Wine, Riesling
meta_description: Learn more about the differences between all the kinds of German wines at City Wine Cellar University.
short_content:
Those of you who begin getting acquainted with the exotic words associated with wine and bottle labels often feel that familiar intimidation resurface when it comes to German wines. Every once in a while I get in the mood for a nice sweet wine or dessert wine to sip on after a nice meal, and Riesling is ideal for many of these occasions. However, just one glance as words like Spatlese or Eiswein are enough to turn away even the most adventurous palates. No wonder people often walk right past the Riesling section.

Fortunately, by just learning a little bit about how German wine is classified and labeled, intimidating and unfamiliar wines can become dear friends. German wine is classified into several different quality categories based on several factors including region, sweetness, and the ripeness of the grapes. This system, developed in 1971, is different from the majority of wine classification systems set up across the globe. Many producers have criticized this system for not showing a large enough difference between better and lesser quality vineyards. Worse yet, wine drinkers uncomfortable with reading German will naturally have problems understanding the information placed on labels.

The easiest way to understand the German wine classification system is by knowing that there are two basic principles that the wine is separated into: Sweetness and Quality. The quality levels of these principles are defined into four categories.

Quality Categories

Deutscher Tafelwein- This quality level is associated with basic table wine. The European equivalent is Vin de Table. The alcohol level must be at least 8.5% by volume. This wine is produced exclusively from allowed German-grown varieties in one of the country’s five regions. The total acidity must reach a level of 4.5 grams/liter.

Deutscher Landwein- This wine is also known as German country wine, equivalent to the Europeans’ Vin de Pays. This classification was introduced in 1982 and the wine must come from one of the 19 regions where the grapes must reach an alcohol level of at least 0.5% or higher. The wine must be dry or off-dry in style. These wines can also be referred to as German fruit wines.

Qualitatswein bestimmter Anbaugebiete (QBA)- This wine is considered good quality and must be made of allowed varieties from 13 wine growing regions. The alcohol level must reach at least 7% by volume and the region must be shown on the label. QBAs range from semi-sweet to dry, and this information is usually located on the label.

Pradikatswein- This was renamed in 2007 from Qualitatswein mit Pradikat (QMP). This is the top-level wine in the German classification system. These wines range from dry to intensely sweet. The wine must be produced by grapes from the allowed 13 regions with an alcohol level of at least 7% by volume.

By just glancing at a German wine bottle label now, you can determine the quality of wine. When you identify which of the four classifications your bottle falls into, you’ll have a strong idea of what degree quality the wine possesses.

The second way to determine what the wine is like is by examining the sweetness levels indicated on the label.

Sweetness Classifications

Kabinett- This is a fully ripe light wine that is typically semi-sweet unless otherwise stated on the label. It possesses a very crisp and clean texture.

Spatlese- Spatlese is actually translated into “late harvest” and is on the sweeter side, unless designated as a full-bodied dry wine. Although Spatlese is not as dry as a dessert wine, it is fruitier and sweeter than Kabinett.

Auslese- Auslese means “select harvest” and is made from very ripe bunches or grapes that sometimes have the noble rot character which makes them semi-sweet or sweet. Auslese can also come in a very powerful dry wine if designated as such, and can be considered a dessert wine. This classification can cover an extensive quantity and range of wines.

Beerenauslese- This is translated in to “select berry harvest” (SBH) and is made from individually selected grapes affected by noble rot, which makes for a rich and sweet dessert wine.

Eiswein- Also considered an Ice wine, this is made from grapes that have been naturally frozen, making a very concentrated wine. This classification is required to have the same level of sugar as a Beerenauslese. Until 1980, Eisweins used grapes that were affected by noble rot.

Trockenbeerebauslese- Trockenbeerebauslese is translated into “select dry berry harvest.” This wine is made from overripe shriveled grapes often affected by noble rot, making them extremely sweet and rich.

Symbols and other descriptive words

German wines have very information labels, providing lots of information that other countries’ wines do not. In fact, there are names for just about everything on the labels, and unlocking the language is the key to discovering what each bottle contains. There is even wording for the color of the wine. For exampale, Weinwein is the word for white wine, Rotwein is Red wine, Rosewein is Rose wine. Weinherbst is rose or a blanc de noir, made from the pinot noir grape. Weinherbst must be made from Pradikatswein, or QBA. There are no restrictions on the color, and the wine ranges from dry to sweet.

Beyond wording, sometimes the label’s design tells you what you need to know about a German wine. You might find a gold foil on the bottle which indicates that the producer considers it better-than-average. Stars indicate that a Pradikatswein has been harvested at a higher level of ripeness than minimum requirements allow. Stars also indicates that the wine will be sweeter.

Fuder (vat) numbers usually indicate a better wine and often the numbers added to the label are arranged in order. Most wines in the Mosel region usually label their semi-sweet and sweet wines with numbers.

German wine classifications can get a little more detailed with wines from special regions. These wines include Liebfraumilch, Moseltaler, Riesling Hochgewachs, Rotling, Schillerwein, and Badisch Rotgold.

Dry Wine Classifications

When it comes to dry wines, there are three official classifications that you’ll see on wines bottled after 2000. There are also a few unofficial labels that you may observe:

Classic is dry or off-dry and conforms to higher standards. This wine is food-friendly and made from varietals from regions considered classical.

Selection is a wine that is a Spatlese trocken from a selected site.

Erstes Gewachs is used only in Rheingau for top level dry wines from selected sites.

Grosses Gewachs is a designation used by VDP members. This wine is designated as a top-level dry wine from a selected sites used by the Bernkasteler Ring.

Erste Lage is a designation used to denote selected sites suitable for Erstes Gewachs and Grosses wines. Also used by VDP in Mosel to design top level wines from selected sites.

Yes, it certainly does get a little complicated with all the different names and labeling, and considering that it’s all in German, one can definitely say that it takes time and practice to develop a comfort with accessing German wine labels. But if you know the four levels of sweetness and the four levels of quality, then you should be able to determine what wine is suitable for your tastes.

German wine labels are pretty easy to understand once you known the language and words used to describe the wine. Every label should have the vintage, the winery, the varietal, the ripeness, the vineyard, region, and government approved number or an AP#. The VDP used in the above descriptions stands for an elite group of winemaking estates in Germany which label which wines are approved with their logo of an eagle with the VDP above it. Now that you’re armed with this information, it’s time to go out, find a German bottle, and enjoy!

title: Will Glass Wine Bottles Be Replaced?
post_content:
Over time, wine has been transported in wooden barrels, clay amphoras, animal skins, and glass bottles. More recently, non-glass containers have been improved so that it is possible to replace glass bottles. PET bottles are one of the newest inventions that are gaining popularity. PET stands for polyethylene terephthalate, a type of plastic. PET bottles are produced using less carbon than other kinds of plastic bottles.

PET bottles are lighter than their glass counterparts. A PET bottle weighing 54 grams would weigh 400 grams if it was made of glass. They are also easy to transport, and they are recyclable. More bottles can be stored during transport, which also helps reduce the carbon footprint.

On the downside, PET bottles cause products to have a shorter shelf life because of the higher amount of oxygen inside them. Plastic bottles could also contain phthalates which can be absorbed into the body and cause damage.

It’s doubtful that plastic bottles will entirely replace glass. Glass has always given wine an elegant and classy feel, and plastic bottles do not have the same association.

title: Deciphering Wine Labels
post_content:
When faced with the task of picking out a bottle of wine, we rely on wine labels to tell us what the content is and will hopefully give us some hints on its quality. Understanding what wine labels need to show and what they mean can help us to decipher the content inside and make the selection clearer.

Information shown on a wine’s label is strictly governed by regulations. All wines produced within the EU follow the same labeling guidelines based on regulations differentiating a Quality Wine from a Table Wine, and information required for each category. New World regulations are less strict, and much of the success of New World wines has been attributed to wine makers’ greater freedom in communicating creatively with consumers. Labeling guidelines in the Old World are strictly regulated according to appellation rules sometimes to the extent of restricting the size and the type of font used.

Let’s look at the key information shown on a wine label:

Wine Designation
Within the EU, a wine must be designated as either a QWPSR (Quality Wines Produced in Specified Regions) or a Table Wine. For wines made outside of the EU, they must indicate the word “wine” when sold within the EU. In the United States, there is no designation requirement on wine label.

Geographical Reference
In the EU, geographical reference for Quality Wine is indicated by the name of controlled appellation (for example, names of AOC/AC/VDQS in France, DOC/DOCG in Italy, QmP/QbA in Germany, DO/DOC in Spain, DOC in Portugal). Labels for Table Wine must simply indicate the name of the producing country. There are intermediate categories such as France’s Vin de Pays, Italy’s IGT or Germany’s Landewein that allow the name of a broader region to be specified. Within the EU, if a geographical region is stated, 100% of wine must come from the specified region.

For the New World, geographical reference can take the form of country name, or the name of a state or region. In the United States, there is a movement to establish controlled zones called AVA (American Viticultural Area) similar to the controlled appellation system in Europe. If an AVA is listed, 85% of grapes must come within the AVA. Otherwise, only 75% is required. In Australia and South Africa, 85% of the grapes are required to come from the region specified on the label.

Quality Reference
Reserva, Gran Reserva, Riserva, and Reserve are regulated terms within EU. They are used with the intention of distinguishing superior wines and often carry a minimum ageing requirement and a higher alcohol level. For example, in Portugal, a Reserva wine comes from a superior vintage and must contain at least 0.5% more alcohol than the regional minimum. In Spain, Reserva and Gran Reserva carry minimum ageing requirements. A Spanish red Reserva wine must be aged for at least 3 years before release of which 1 year must be spent in oak. In New World countries, these terms do not carry any regulatory requirements and are often applied loosely.

Volume
It is required to state the volume of wine contained inside a bottle with the most common being 750mL plus an “e” mark.

Alcoholic Strength
This is simply an indication of how much alcohol is contained in a bottled wine. An ABV measurement expressed as a percentage of total volume (% by vol) is the standard used.

Vintage
A vintage cannot be stated for a Table Wine with the EU. It may only be shown for a Quality Wine. If a vintage is shown, the wine must comprise 100% of the vintage indicated. In the United States, Chile, Argentina, Australia, and South Africa, 85% minimum must come from the vintage stated.

Name of Producer/Bottler
This is simply an indication of who made or bottled the wine. Although in the EU, a producer’s address that includes the same name as that of a controlled appellation cannot be used on a Table Wine’s label. In this case, address information is substituted by a postal code. It is of particular importance in certain regions such as Bordeaux and Alsace as appellation rules require bottling must be done within the appellation. In France, terms such as mis en bouteille au château or mis au domaine are shown on label to indicate compliance.

Lot Marking
It is a requirement under EU regulations to show a lot number associated to a wine’s bottling batch in case of any consumer’s complaint or recall. The mark is typically shown starting with an L then a coded bottling date.

Sulphites & Other Allergens
In most countries, it is a requirement to indicate that a wine contains sulphites if it contains more than 10 mg/L of sulphur dioxide. EU regulation changes have taken effect since 2004 and the same rule pertaining to sulphites also applies to any wine made or sold within the EU. Since 2002, Australia and New Zealand require other allergens such as fish, milk, nuts or egg products used in processing aid to be listed. Starting June 30, 2012, EU members will also be required to disclose usage of casein (milk products) and ovalbumin (egg products) during a wine’s production.

Government Warning
In the United States, the government requires all wines to carry a health warning from the Surgeon General to pregnant women, car drivers and operators of heavy machinery against the consumption of alcohol.

Varietal Information
Varietal information is optional but is found to be behind much of New World’s marketing success. Many controlled appellations prohibit the use of varietal names on front labels. Some progressive producers have taken the route to communicate the varietal information on the optional back label. In the EU, if a variety is specified on a label, the wine must be made from at least 85% of the variety. There are more stringent laws according to the regulations of each controlled appellation. In the United States, the minimum varies according to each state. In Oregon, the requirement is 95%, in Washington it is 85%, and in most of the other states it is 75%.

Organic and Biodynamic Labeling
Studies by the International Organic Accreditation Service, Letis, indicate that organic wine consumption maintains its growth margin despite the recent economic downtown. The United States and Canada both register a high growth rate of 20% annually. Most countries in Europe register an increase between 5% to 15% annually (Sweden 18%, Holland 10%, Denmark 8%, Italy & Switzerland 7%, France & Austria 5%). The terms organic and biodynamic are not regulated by wine laws. Each country has her own governing bodies on organic products. In France, wine producers may seek organic certification through Ecocert, Qualité France, ULSAE, Agrocert, Certipaq and ACLAVE. In the United States, organic certification is handled by the USDA. Currently, biodynamic producers are certified through Demeter.

Other Optional Information
Information about a winery’s history, winemaking philosophy and vineyard characteristics are helpful in strengthening a brand’s prestige. With plenty of competitions on the market, many labels also include information on style, sweetness level, serving temperature, anticipated maturity window, and food pairing ideas to help consumers make purchasing choices. Many producers also choose to include technical aspects such as vintage & harvest data, yield, production method, method & length of aging, annual production, or even residual sugar and acidity levels.

On the business front, often the name of importer/distributor will be found on a label, alongside contact information (with a website address and QR code to encourage inquiry). An element that is considered beneficial by many is to show competition awards or scores from major critics and publications. Awards and medals are commonly to be printed on the label appear as stickers affixed to the bottles.

title: Why Are Decanters Important?
post_content:
Much of what many people suppose is purely ceremonial or symbolic about wine drinking and wine culture often has purely practical and logical reasoning behind it. A good example would be regarding the fact that the shape of the glasses from which we drink wines. This is due to far more than simple tradition-based posturing. Such things have come about through centuries of innovation, trial and error, and inspirational ideas which attempt to enhance the flavors and aromas of wine, and thus increase our enjoyment of these wonderfully varied and interesting drinks. Visit any good wine bar, cellar or restaurant, and it is highly likely that you will see your chosen wine decanted before you drink it. This is often undertaken with a certain sense of ceremony, and as such, has often been dismissed by the uninitiated as little more than an unnecessary moment of theatricality. But why exactly is the decanting process so important, and why has it remained more or less unchanged over the centuries?

History of Decanters

The pouring of wines into a crystal or glass decanter certainly adds a sense of style and class to any table, but this is merely one small aspect of the idea behind the process. It is widely agreed that it was those first great vintners – the Romans – who developed the early glass decanters. Indeed, glassblowing was a common practice in and around the Roman empire, and we can see some beautiful and impressive examples of surviving Roman glassware in various museums and archaeological sites around the world. For the Romans, wines were something deeply important, and even though they were drunk by almost everybody, everyday around the empire, efforts were consistently made to improve the drink. Wines were flavored with honey, spices, even seawater, they were the first to experiment with ageing wines in barrels. It should come as no surprise, therefore, to find that the Romans were the first to develop items designed to improve the wine-drinking experience, among which we must list the glass decanter.

Removing Sediments

The most basic reason why wines should be decanted is in order to deal with the potential sediments the liquid might carry. Sediments occur naturally in wines, and it is inevitable that a drink made from pressed fruit should contain some. Although most of the sediment will remain in the bottle as a wine is decanted, the flared shape of a classic decanter also helps to remove the sediment as it is tipped to fill a glass. This results in making the wine within the glass clearer in both texture and flavor: exactly as the winery intended it to be drunk.

Let it Breathe

The other key reason for decanting wine is to allow the wine to ‘breathe’ or aerate. This process is an especially important one for younger, un-aged wines, which require twenty minutes or so to mellow in the air in order for the best features of their flavor and aroma to come through and be enjoyed. Whilst this is commonly done in households by removing the cork, and leaving the wine to one side for some time, with the help of a decanter, the process comes about more fully and with far more satisfying results. The decanting process with older, aged wine, however, is quite different. Because they are likely to hold a considerably higher level of sediment, they must be decanted very slowly as to leave the sediment in the bottle, and the tip of the bottle should be in contact with the lip of the decanter while it is being poured. This prevents the wine from becoming aerated during the decanting process, which can rob it of many of its important and prized features. For much the same reason, a stopper should be placed on top of the decanter when drinking aged wines, and removed only when serving, and the wine should certainly not be left to breathe in the same way as a younger wine would.

Multi-Sensory Enjoyment

Of course, there is one final reason why decanters are used, and this is the same reason why they are made from transparent material like glass or crystal. A decanter allows you and your guests to admire the wine, to enjoy it visually and not merely with your nose or palate. Wines are often beautiful things, bearing delightful colors and refracting light in attractive ways. Why wouldn’t you want to keep it in a vessel which shows off some of its finest features?

title: Diabetes and Wine
post_content:
Diabetes is known as the “American disease,” and recent studies indicate that at least 6% of our population is diabetic. As our habits and diets continue to increase our susceptibility for diabetes, we are forced to confront the claim that wine and diabetes don’t mix. The truth is that, just like any other element of a diabetic’s diet, wine can be enjoyed if drunk in opposition.

The American Diabetes Association supports the fact that certain wines can in fact become a part of a diabetic’s diet. Even though wines have sugars, different wines feature different quantities and different types. The most recommended wine for diabetics is a dry wine, as it would contain less residual sugar. If one drinks this moderately, if one has a controlled diet, and if one also follows the ADA recommendation that any drinking be accompanied with eating, then consuming wine does not pose any significant risk to a diabetic.

Studies even suggest that while not posing any risks, drinking a dry wine offers several health benefits: low cholesterol and improved cardiac health accompany moderate wine drinking. So yes, a diabetic can enjoy a pleasant dry glass of wine from time to time without worrying about compromising health.

However, if you are a diabetic and are ready to uncork that next bottle, make sure that you’re well aware of the risks associated with diabetes, and with wine, too. Wine has the ability to prevent your liver from making sugars, which means that you might experience dangerously low blood sugar levels while drinking. If you eat while indulging in a glass of wine, you are less likely to experience this effect. Also, the symptoms of drinking too much and suffering from hypoglycemia are similar, so when you’re drinking it may be difficult to tell the difference between which one you are experiencing. You might even have both alcohol and hypoglycemia making you sleepy, dizzy, and disoriented. Caution is key, so before you pop that next cork, make sure you speak with your physician.

title: Can Wine Be Aged?
post_content:
Can I age this wine, and if so, for how long?

There are countless techniques for improving the taste, aroma and general character of wines. Vintners and wine producers have always searched for bold new methods and original ideas with which to achieve perfection in wine. From adding aromatic herbs and spices, to blending the liquid with seawater and honey, those who make wine have stopped at nothing on their quest for the perfect drink. Even today, several thousand years after wines were first produced, wineries all over the world continue to strive towards perfection – a delicate balance of tannins and acidity, of alcohol content and sweetness or astringency – and they are unlikely to stop.

The Ageing Process

One of the most commonly used methods for producing excellent wines of superb character is the aging process. By leaving wines to mature and age in vessels, the often harsh natural tannins present in the skins of grapes used for wine production begin to soften. As this process takes place, other characteristics of the grape are able to come through in the wine more strongly or more significantly. Aged wines are thus very different from their younger counterparts, even if the same grape varietals have been used. Aged wines are usually described as being more ‘mellow’ – usually referring to the softer tannins and more balanced acids in the wine, or more ‘complex’. The complexity of an aged wine often refers to the number of different flavours and aromas present in the wine – something which is usually overshadowed in younger wines by the strength of the tannins and acids. By aging wines, a wide bouquet of aromas is gradually released by the grapes, and subtler, often quite unusual flavors are allowed to come forward and shine, resulting in more interesting and unique vintages.

Roman Experimentation

Wine aging has been going on for centuries – indeed, it is believed that the Romans were the first to experiment with aged wines, using clay and wooden vessels to store their copious amounts of wine and improve their flavor. Today, aging is a mark of excellence, with many of the world’s finest wine regions having strict regulations and laws governing just how long a particular wine is allowed to be aged for in order for it to be of a quality high enough to represent a region. For example, Chianti Classico Riserva must be aged in oak for a minimum of two years, and a further three months within the bottle before being released, in order to ensure that the wine within is complex, balanced and smooth enough to deserve having such an esteemed and famous label.

Aging In The Bottle

Of course, the other side of ageing takes place not in the winery or wine cave, but at a home or in a wine cellar. For those who adore fine wines, home aging is a key component for ensuring their wine collection is at an optimum quality when they come to open and enjoy the bottle. But can all wines be aged at home? And which wines require the most aging?

Aging Red Wines

Because aging generally concerns the mellowing of tannins, white wines do not age as well as red wines. Because white wines most commonly contain very low tannin contents (due to the fact that the skins of white and green grapes contain few tannins), they usually need to be drunk within two or three years of the vintage date on their bottle. Red wine, on the other hand, is a whole different matter, and often red wines can be kept in a cellar or properly stored for a remarkable amount of time before reaching their optimum flavor potential.

Cabernet Sauvignon, being a grape varietal with thick skins and a high tannin content, has a natural affinity for oak which makes it a favorite for wineries looking to produce superb aged wines. Cabernet Sauvignon wines age extremely well in the bottle, and a fine bottle made with this grape varietal can be aged at home for between ten to fifteen years, consistently improving, mellowing and rounding. Most of the fine Bordeaux blended red wines (often regarded as the best in the world) usually contain a high percentage of Cabernet Sauvignon, and as such, it is not uncommon to find these wines gathering dust in famous wine cellars, waiting patiently to be enjoyed.

Other red wines made from different grape varietals also age well, although unless the grapes used to produce them are as astringent and tannin-heavy as Cabernet Sauvignon, they needn’t be aged for quite so long. Pinot Noir reaches optimum excellence between five and ten years, as does Zinfandel. Merlots generally don’t require more than five years, and wines made from Italian grapes such as Sangiovese and Barbera require about the same, due to their relatively light body and big, juicy flavours which burst through the tannins almost as soon as they are bottled.

title: Australian Wines
post_content:
When most people think of Australia, they think of kangaroos and boomerangs. What they hardly ever think about is wine; but the truth is that Australia is actually the fourth-largest exporter of wine in the world, and winemaking contributes $5.5 billion annually to the nation’s economy. Australian wine is most widely consumed in the south Asian wine markets and the nation’s major varietals include Shiraz, Cabernet Sauvignon, Chardonnay, Merlot, Semillon, Pinot Noir, Riesling and Sauvignon Blanc.

The history of Australian wine begins over two centuries ago, in 1788, when vine cuttings arrived from the Cape of Good Hope. Although the wine from these cuttings met with mixed success, the settlers did manage to cultivate suitable wine-making vines. Thirty years later, in 1820, wine began to be sold locally, and in 1822 an entrepreneur by the name of Gregory Blaxland began exporting Australian wine. He even won an overseas aware for his exports.

Australia’s climate and terroir presented unique challenges to potential wine producers. After experimentation, mixed success with cultivation, and plenty of failed attempts, Australia finally made its big impression on the world stage in 1873 when French wine judges – the most renowned judges in the world – thoroughly enjoyed the Australian product. At least, until they discovered where it originated. Australian wines continued to earn high honors in French competitions for many years.

As recently as the 1970s, Australia produced many sweet and fortified wines. Since then, Australia has rapidly grown into a wine producing leader in both quantity and quality. Over the last twenty years, Australia has suffered from low grape prices, which has resulted in the government urging producers to pull their wines. One result of this move was the introduction of clean skin wines. Organic and biodynamic farming have been popular methods in Australian wine production, and the demand for this sort of organically produced wine has grown in European markets.

Part of what has contributed to Australia’s success with wine is how strictly it is regulated. Like other countries, Australia’s wine regions are regulated – as reflected on their labels – and are divided into South Eastern Australia, Victoria wine region, New South Wales wine region, and the Western Australia wine region. Australian winemaking results have been impressive and have established benchmarks for a number of varietals.

One of the most famous Australian wines is called Penfolds Grange. This impressive wine has won more than 50 gold medals around the globe and has topped the major charts and reviews in publications worldwide. Some of the more popular names you may or may not have heard of are Peter Lehman, Yellow Tail, Little Penguin, Molly Dooker, and Greg Norman. Some rather impressive and inexpensive wines have come from Australia, and I am sure you will enjoy many of the wines they produce. Now that you know that Australia isn’t just famous for its kangaroos and boomerangs, you can keep your eyes open for its labels at your local wine store.

title: Biodynamic wines
post_content:
Biodynamic wines – the latest phase of the organic revolution?

All over the world, a change is happening in how people are choose their consumer products and spend their money. Mass production has fallen greatly out of favor among the discerning public, and small, independent companies doing things in their own way and to their own principles have become increasingly more successful and prominent in the market. Part of this change in the attitudes of both producers and consumers has been due to the rise in demand and popularity of organic produce, items which have a strong connection to the region in which they are produced, and items certified to carry as little chemical content as possible, or none whatsoever. We have seen this have a huge effect on way the food is produced, manufactured and purchased, and it was only a matter of time before such principles began to effect the world of wine.

The Rise of Biodynamic Farming

Perhaps the more niche and extreme end of this issue has been evident in the rise of biodynamic wines, those which have been made from vines grown to the strict biodynamic principles of organic farming laid down by Rudolph Steiner in 1924. Such principles involve the use of cow manure, powdered quartz and several preparations made from medicinal plants. Steiner’s belief was that by working with fruits and vegetables (including grapes) using his methods, and by aligning one’s farming practices with the changes in the moon, one could greatly increase both the yield and the quality of your harvest. However, the biodynamic principles go considerably further when it comes to wine production, and biodynamic wineries often do all that they can to ensure their vineyards are moving with what Steiner referred to as the earth’s ‘natural rhythms’ – the changing of the tides, the regeneration of soil, the way moisture is pulled from the earth and released by the vines into the air. Indeed, even many high end wineries in established appellations of France, Germany, Austria and elsewhere are now plowing their fields with horses, scattering crystals on their soil, and rearranging their barrels to benefit from the moon’s gravitational pull in order to reap the supposed benefits of biodynamic wine production.

Positive Results

It is probable that many wineries began experimenting with biodynamics as a way of assuring their customers they had the interests of the environment in mind, such were the concerns and interests of a particular (and wealthy) demographic of the wine buying market. However, as the initial results were surprisingly very positive indeed (with not only sales of such wines being much higher than anticipated, but the reviews and general feedback also) the past few years have seen more and more wineries turning to biodynamics to improve their chances in the highly competitive wine market. Interestingly, most wineries would now claim their choice to convert to biodynamics was based on the quality of their produce alone, and less to do with the selling appeal of the biodynamic label they could put on their bottles.

Tasting Biodynamic Wine

What is biodynamic wine like? Does it have any distinguishing features that make it worth paying extra for? In recent years, many Michelin-starred chefs in both the United Kingdom and France have insisted on stocking only biodynamic and organic wines in their cellars, based on the belief that they couple far more successfully with organic foods. Such opinions are hard to ignore, and if biodynamic wines are good enough for Paris, perhaps it is high time the rest of us paid more attention to them. The general consensus seems to be that biodynamic wines are much the same as other organic or natural wines, containing slightly more sediment than usual and holding a more mellow, sappy character than might be expected.

One of the most regular statements made by wine experts regarding biodynamic wines is that they hold more of the terroir in their flavors – that is, that the characteristics of the soil and land they are grown in come across in the taste and the aroma of the wines. This would certainly chime with the initial theories put forward by Steiner in the 1920′s, and is enough for fans of biodynamic farming to claim its superiority. However, the statement is in itself deliberately broad and open to interpretation, and such subtleties of flavour (if they exist at all) are highly likely to not be picked up by the general wine drinking public. All of this aside, though, if biodynamics helps farmers and wine producers attain quality produce without resorting to the overuse of chemicals and a disconnection from the land they work with, it is surely a step in the right direction. If the end product also tastes great and has something valuable to offer to the wider world, then who could possibly argue against it?

title: Sulphur Dioxide in Winemaking
post_content:
What are the benefits and risks with the use of sulphur dioxide in winemaking?

Sulphur dioxide is one of the most common additives used in winemaking. Although it is toxic at a high dosage, its controlled use offers many benefits. In particular, its antiseptic and anti-oxidative qualities ensure wines remain stable and safe until opening. Since 1987 in the US and 2005 in the EU, there have been regulations in place requiring that a wine made with sulphur dioxide carries a warning label saying it contains sulphites.

Despite its usefulness, sulphur dioxide can also be risky to use. During the winemaking process, protecting a wine from oxidation and spoilage is crucial. After fermentation, racking is a common first step to clarify the wine. During this process, any movement may lead to oxygen intake. Sulphur dioxide works as a protective measure to treat the equipment used during racking.

Barrels, used during aging process, are commonly treated with sulphur dioxide due to the risk of allowing oxygen exchange. It is also crucial to treat used barrels due to their higher risk of bacteria contamination. Right before bottling, it is common to treat bottles with sulphur dioxide to flush out any oxygen and bacteria. Finally, a controlled amount is added at bottling but its level is regulated by the EU according to wine type and sweetness level.

When used in a sufficient dosage, sulphur dioxide is an effective antioxidant as it combines with any free oxygen to form sulphuric acid, thus removing the risk of oxidation. It also kills enzymes (called oxidases) that promote oxidation. It is especially important for a white wine to be treated with sulphur dioxide to prevent the ill-effects of oxidation such as browning and off-aromas. If sign of minor oxidation is present, a correct dosage of sulphur dioxide can bind with acetaldehyde, which is the main product of oxidation, to remove any aroma of oxidation and to freshen the wine.

Acting as an antiseptic, sulphur dioxide kills any bacteria that could cause spoilage. Acetabacter, a common bacteria affecting wine, is the culprit turning wine into vinegar. Sulphur dioxide is effective in that it kills both the bacteria and removes any oxygen that the bacteria relies on to survive. It also kills any yeast that may remain inside a bottled wine, especially critical in the presence of residual sugar, to prevent re-fermentation in the bottle. Without sufficient amount of sulphur dioxide added, a wine runs the risk of spoilage, oxidation, browning, presence of off-aromas, and re-fermentation in the bottle.

The addition of sulphur dioxide must be carefully controlled as too high a level brings negative effects. Sulphur dioxide reacts with anthocyanins that are responsible for color in red wines. If there is excessive sulphur dioxide present, it renders the anthocyanins inert causing a wine to lose color. Furthermore, volatile sulphur dioxide smells and affects the aroma profile of a wine, while dissolved sulphur dioxide can be tasted and can negatively affect its flavor. A key reason behind warning label indicating that a wine contains sulphites is that some people may suffer allergic reaction due to it. Despite only affecting a small percentage of the population, it is a health risk that propels recent trends for lower level of sulphur dioxide used in winemaking.

Being both an antioxidant and antiseptic, sulphur dioxide is an important additive in winemaking. When correctly used, it ensures safety and freshness of wines until they reach the dinner table. The ill-effects of excessive sulphur dioxide use are obvious and have prompted a trend toward much lower level or in some cases, none at all. Alternative techniques are available, but they present another set of challenges and drawbacks. Good winemaking involves careful and controlled use of sulphur dioxide to protect and preserve the finished wine.

A key reason behind warning label indicating that a wine contains sulphites is that some people may suffer allergic reaction due to it. Despite only affecting a small percentage of the population, it is a health risk that propels recent trends for lower level of sulphur dioxide used in winemaking.

Being both an antioxidant and antiseptic, sulphur dioxide is an important additive in winemaking. When correctly used, it ensures safety and freshness of wines until they reach the dinner table. The ill-effects of excessive sulphur dioxide use are obvious and have prompted a trend toward much lower level or in some cases, none at all. Alternative techniques are available, but they present another set of challenges and drawbacks. Good winemaking involves careful and controlled use of sulphur dioxide to protect and preserve the finished wine.

title: Are All Champagnes Created Equal?
post_content:
For centuries, the name Champagne has come out above all others when it comes to sparkling wine. The wineries of this very special region of France have been carefully perfecting their produce for hundreds of years and building up a legendary reputation around themselves in the meantime, with many of the most famous brands of their fizzy white wine becoming household names.

How did this happen? Many people would claim that we can place the blame for this perhaps over-inflated sense of importance on European royalty. The sparkling wines of Champagne were favoured by aristocracy of the past few centuries, leading the wineries of this region to boost their production and their prices simultaneously. To this day, few people regularly drink Champagne, and it is reserved for birthdays, anniversaries or the launching of ships.

The quality of the produce cannot be completely ignored, and a fine Champagne is a very carefully constructed and wonderful thing in itself. The delicate blending of Chardonnay varietal grapes with Pinot Noir, boosted by a little touch of Pinot Meunier is one of the all-time great combinations. The Chardonnay offers acidity, bite, and the distinctive biscuity flavours the wine holds; the other two varietals give their length and backbone, coming through in elegant bubbles during the second fermentation of the wine. The result is something splendid – delicate, giddy and exciting, with a taste quite unlike any other sparkling wine.

It has been a great source of frustration that the wineries of Champagne have allowed their reputation to overshadow any significant develop in the field of sparkling wines. Even in the Champagne region, wineries producing sparkling wines which differ from the norm are struggling to get noticed, due to the fact that the people who buy sparkling wines around the world are still nervous about exploring new options. The best of these overshadowed varieties is the superb ‘blanc de noir’ sparkling Champagne, which are a single variety wine made exclusively with Pinot Noir grapes, giving a really impressive flavour with a hint of orchard fruits behind the decadent fizz of the drink.

If other, alternative, wineries in Champagne are struggling with their sparkling wines, then the rest of the world needs to start taking notice of the plight of wineries in other countries trying to get people to select their (often extremely good) sparkling wines. Spain’s Cava wines have long been seen as an affordable, cheerful alternative to Champagne. Cavas tend to be slightly more fruity than other sparkling wines, and the rosé varieties are a delightful addition to the world of fizzy wines which have long been left under the radar of most wine drinkers, despite being treasured in their native Spain.

Italy’s Prosecco wines are another great example of a sparkling wine too often cruelly overlooked on the shelf. Indeed, many people who take the time to try a few different Prosecco sparklers generally return to them, claiming they prefer the softness and drinkability of these fine, fizzy wines. Prosecco has less acidity than Champagne, with a more refined, blushed and rounded flavour which shows plenty more variation from winery to winery. Furthermore, Prosecco itself is versatile, and doesn’t have such a sacrosanct air about it – get yourself a bottle and use it as the base for some of the best cocktails you’ll have all year!

All over the world, from South Africa to California, wineries are consistently producing excellent quality sparkling wines which have plenty to offer, and importantly, are not necessarily trying to emulate Champagne. Even England, whose wine industry is just starting to get underway, has done very well at many tastings. Unfortunately, so long as the (admittedly, very good) sparkling wines of Champagne continue to dominate the minds and choices of wine buyers, this great variety of wines with all their unique flavours, aromas and characteristics will begin to dwindle, and possibly disappear. We have a responsibility to think, and buy, outside the box.

title: Cooking with Wine
post_content:
When cooking with wine, it’s important to choose a wine that you could drink. The alcohol is the only thing that gets cooked out, and the flavor is left. Cheap cooking wines are often full of sodium and bad for your diet.

Consider wine as an important ingredient in your cooking. For example, you wouldn’t use artificial cheese powder in your homemade macaroni and cheese recipe. Use the same consideration when choosing a cooking wine. It isn’t necessary to use a very expensive wine, but you shouldn’t cook with a cheap wine that will ruin your meal.

There are plenty of reasonably priced wines to choose from. Experiment with different varietals while cooking. Try adding a little Chardonnay to your alfredo or a dash of Cabernet Sauvignon to your lasagna sauce. A light wine should be used for light dishes while a dry, heavy wine should be used for hearty dishes.

Red wines are great for pasta dishes, sauces, and red meats. White wines are good for cream sauces, poultry dishes, and seafood dishes. Be wary of using a wine that is too sweet because it might counteract with the seasonings in the dish. If you’re new to cooking with wine, play it safe by starting with a dry wine. The wine in your recipe and the wine you serve with dinner should be of the same varietal.

The different characteristics of wine can enhance and add character to your food. It takes some experimenting before you get the hang of it. You don’t need to splurge on a wine that you are just going to splash into your dish. Save the expensive wines to serve with dinner.

title: Corks or Screw caps?
post_content:
To cork or not to cork? Sounds familiar? Well, it should, this book written by George M Taber is all about the continuous battle between the traditional cork and its arch nemesis, the screw cap; a debate that has haunted all wine lovers for many generations. Which is better? Which is best for storage? These questions lead to more, and when one problem is solved another arises. The debate between which is a better way to seal off a bottle of wine is a long and tiresome road, but it is a very important one in the wine industry. To understand the battle let us review what is so important about the cork and what is so amazing about the screw cap.

Traditionally, wine bottles have been sealed by corks. Corks are very environmentally friendly because the part of the tree that is used to produce corks is the bark, which is an easily renewable resource. Corks also allow for natural aging. They are one of the few kinds of top that allow wine to age naturally. Because corks allow for natural breathing, the wine they seal can age on its own. This is very desirable for red wines.

Although there are many good qualities to corking a wine, probably the best reason for corking a wine is that nothing compares to the traditional, dramatic, and romantic sound of a cork popping out as you open the bottle. Too many wines are far more complex than how most people see it. It has history and hundreds of years of traditions that come with the bottle and the corks are just as important in that tradition as the bottle itself.

Although the cork does hold a lot of sentimental value and is a great way to store your wine there are a couple problems with the cork. One of the biggest problems with using a cork is that sometimes the wine will react to a substance called 2, 4, 6 – Tricloroanisole, which is caused by the bark from the tree, because sometimes mold will grow in it. This causes the wine to become “corked” wine. A lot of wines get this problem and it is because of the cork itself. Another problem with using a cork is since the cork is made from all natural bark and it does allow the wine to breath, oxygen can get into the wine and too much can cause the wine to become oxidized. Oxidation completely alters the flavor, texture and smell of the wine. Just as bad is that sometimes corks are very difficult to remove; they can crumble and break apart instead.

Screw caps are small metal caps that screw onto the neck of the bottle. The introduction of screw caps met with a lot of resistance, but now they are fairly common. Screw caps have the big advantage of preventing wines from becoming corked or becoming oxidized. Another advantage is that they are always very easy to remove, and do not require the use of a special tool like a cork does. Just as screw caps are easy to open, they are also easy to close, which is convenient if you don’t drink the whole bottle. White wines are often found with screw caps, because they keep the wine fresh.

However, because screw caps are machine-made from metal or plastic, they are not renewable, and they contribute significantly to landfill. Screw caps also seal the opening of the bottle, which limits the benefits of the aging process. The biggest flaw in the screw cap is basically the same thing as the corks biggest strength, although it does help prevent a lot of taint, it stripes the tradition aspect of the wine, the cork is naturally grown like the wine and the beauty behind it, some wine enthusiasts will say that the screw cap is too man-made and doesn’t have enough of that personal touch that corks do.

This debate between corks and screw caps have been argues for so many years and there are many valid points in both sides. There isn’t a lot of hard proof that proves one makes the wine better but there are a lot of ideas and opinions. The truth is that it’s based on personal preference.

title: Boutari Grande Reserve Naoussa 2004
post_content:
Boutari Grande Reserve Naoussa 2004

In northern Greece, much of the vineyard’s area is located at high altitude where climate is decidedly cool and continental.  Naoussa is its most celebrated region known for full-bodied red wines made from local grape Xinomavro.  These grapes produce earthy and powerful red wines with high acidity and pronounced tannins that rival some of the best wines of the world capable of long ageing.

At 8 years old, this garnet-hued wine is displaying attractive developing notes of savory meat and nuttiness yet retaining much of its color intensity and ripe red fruits, plum and fig notes.  2 years of ageing in French oak barrels plus additional time in bottle, tannins are aplenty but resolved and elegant.  Its distinctive meaty and savory flavors linger to a smooth and very long finish with hints of clove.  Structure is well-supported by persistent acid and firm tannin suggesting its potential for further ageing and development.  This full-bodied red wine has shed some of its early power but continues to express complexity and depth beyond its modest price tag.  Lovers of big red wines such as Barolo, Brunello and Bordeaux should not miss this.

Pair this with game, porterhouse steak, braised meat, or strong firm cheeses.

Vintage: 2004
Appellation: Naoussa
Grape: 100% Xinomavro
Size: 750mL
Alcohol: 13%

title: Henry Fessy Chateau des Reyssiers RÃ©gniÃ© 2009
post_content:
Henry Fessy Chateau des Reyssiers Régnié 2009

Beaujolais has gained its fame mostly from the young, fruity Beaujolais Nouveaux that appear on the market every November within weeks of harvest. However, this region that sits just south of Maçonnais, Burgundy deserves a deeper look.

Although all the red wines produced in the region are made from Gamay, the quality fluctuates significantly depending on where within Beaujolais the wines come from and who the producers are. Beaujolais Nouveau is mostly produced via carbonic maceration which leads to simple, fruity and low-tannin red wine that has little structure or complexity.

Toward the north of the region, along rolling hills with granite soil, more serious versions of Beaujolais can be found. They are recognized for their higher quality by designation “Beaujolais Villages.” Several villages are further elevated as individual “crus” to denote their superior quality. Régnié is one of the crus — one that is cherished for its ballerina-like lightness and youthful appeal.

Chateau des Reyssiers is a 300-years-old domain located in the heart of Régnié that belonged to Henry Fessy. Today, it is part of the famed Burgundian house Louis Latour’s holding in the region. The 14-hectare vineyard is planted with old-vines Gamay and pruned Gobelet-style — the traditional pruning method in the region.

2009 is considered an outstanding vintage because of its ideally warm summer in which grapes were able to achieve full ripeness. It is a vintage marked by intense fruits and a higher concentration of color and flavors. Some of its best wines will take more time to reveal their full potentials.

Régnié, known for its delicate and youthful nature, means this is drinking well early. Expressive fruity flavors of both black and red berries are balanced by tart acidity to make this wine salivatingly juicy. Made by traditional fermentation method similar to those used in Burgundy gives this wine some structure despite its delicate nature. Soft texture on the palate but showing good depth of color and fruit profiles; it is open and drinking well today.

Vintage: 2009
Appellation: Régnié
Grape: 100% Gamay
Size: 750mL
Alcohol: 13.5%

title: Eyrie Vineyards Chardonnay 2009
post_content:
Eyrie Vineyards Chardonnay, Dundee Hills, Oregon

In 1966, David Lett went against the advice of his viticulture professors at UC Davis and went to Oregon to plant the first Pinot Noir vineyard in the Willamette Valley. His perseverance and dedication has paid off and placed Oregon on the wine map as synonymous with the best and most elegant Pinot Noir in the US.

Today, his vineyards have been passed down to his son, Jason Lett, who carries forth the same principle of not conforming and seeking to make the best wine possible with the vineyards that his father planted.

Even though Pinot Noir got all the spotlight, David Lett’s wife Diana shared “he really loved making Chardonnay even though all the fuss was about Pinot Noir, and Pinot Gris to a certain extent. He always liked that there was no 108 [a Chardonnay clone isolated by UC Davis in 1967 for its high yield and low acid and gained tremendous popularity in California] in the wines at all, except for a couple of the purchased vintages.”

Persistance and the goal to strive for excellence today continue with very demanding biodynamic regimens. There is no spraying of herbicide and insecticide. Vines are non-irrigated and un-grafted, with minimal intervention and 100% hand harvesting. The vines average 50 years old and were planted in 2 adjacent blocks in the original Eyrie Vineyards facing south and southeast in iron-rich limestone soil.

In the cellar, the wine was allowed to ferment slowly over a period of several months in large neutral French barrels with indigenous yeast, followed by extended ageing on lees for 1 year and then lightly filtered before bottling.

There are plenty of blockbuster Chardonnays made these days that wow you on the first sip, even if subsequent sips tend to become tiring on the palate. We like to see The Eyrie Chardonnay as a long-distance runner. This is a wine that gets better over the course of dinner. Decanting is not common for white wine, but we think this wine could benefit from a quick decanting. With some time in glass, red apple, hints quince and pineapple start to reveal themselves. This wine shows a leesy quality with a smooth softened texture and continues to open up to reveal a Meursault-like quality with its rich mouthfeel and hazelnut note. Oak is subtle and integrated. Finish is clean and elegant.

Its structure is built for the long haul as evidenced by a recent 1970-2007 Chardonnay retrospective tasting attended by Jancis Robinson MW. She marveled at how well the wines aged: “Indeed these wines showed practically no obvious oak notes whatsoever – and were much lighter, drier, and longer- lived, than most North American Chardonnays….I had to go back and alter my suggested drinking dates for the younger vintages on the basis of how well the older wines had lasted. And by the time we had got back to the 1980s and 1970s, I started wondering just how many Burgundian domaines could present an array of white wines that has lasted as consistently well.”

As far as Oregon goes, the Eyrie Vineyards is considered THE vino-royalty. If it weren’t for the Lett family, we would be missing out on some very distinguished wines. Pinot Noir gets the spotlight but Chardonnay is well deserving of an equal share on the stage too.

Biodynamic
Vintage: 2009
Appellation: Dundee Hills
Grape: 100% Chardonnay
Size: 750mL
Alcohol: 13.5%
