She marveled at how well the wines aged: “Indeed these wines showed practically no obvious oak notes whatsoever – and were much lighter, drier, and longer- lived, than most North American Chardonnays….I had to go back and alter my suggested drinking dates for the younger vintages on the basis of how well the older wines had lasted. And by the time we had got back to the 1980s and 1970s, I started wondering just how many Burgundian domaines could present an array of white wines that has lasted as consistently well.”

As far as Oregon goes, the Eyrie Vineyards is considered THE vino-royalty. If it weren’t for the Lett family, we would be missing out on some very distinguished wines. Pinot Noir gets the spotlight but Chardonnay is well deserving of an equal share on the stage too.

title: Domaine de FondrÃ¨che CÃ´tes du Ventoux Persia 2007
post_content:
Domaine de Fondrèche Côtes du Ventoux Persia 2007

Côtes du Ventoux is a small appellation located in the Southern Rhône Valley. Its name may not mean much but lovers of Rhône Valley Syrah should take note of this producer – Domaine de Fondrèche. This cuvee Persia, as it is closer in expression to the more majestic Northern Rhône (think Côte-Rôtie and Cornas) than to most of its Grenache-based neighbors in the South. This recently arrived, late-release 2007, with its brooding structure, is 90% Syrah and 10% Mourvèdre. We think the extra time spent in the cellar is well justified and doing great things to the wine.

The wine has just been rested enough and is in its prime drinking window. Showing a deep intensity of blue-tinged red, at 5 years of age, it opens up to show attractive nose of savory meat (Yes, bacon!), provencÄ…l herbs and dried violets. On palate, notes of rich but fresh blackberries and sweet licorice are framed by a structure of rounded soft tannin and great acidity.

Domaine Fondrèche works biodynamically at its cool high-elevation vineyard (temperature here tends to be lower than other areas of southern Rhône) with minimal sulphur dioxide. All wines are bottled unfined and unfiltered.

Cuvée Persia consistently garners 90+ scores from the Wine Advocate (Robert Parker gave the 2007 92 points and Neal Martin 93 points) but don’t hold it against the wine. It is classically well-balanced with a long, graphite-laced, minerally finish.

Vintage: 2007
Appellation: Rhone Valley
Grape: Red Rhone Blend
Size: 750mL
Alcohol: 14.5%

title: Willamette Valley Vineyards South Block Pinot Noir
post_content:
Willamette Valley Vineyards South Block Pinot Noir
Certified organic by Oregon TILTH

In 1966, David Lett went against the advice of his viticulture professors at UC Davis and went to Oregon to plant the first Pinot Noir vineyard in the Willamette Valley. We all remember the rant from Miles in Sideways about how finicky and difficult this thin-skinned grape is. David Lett proved all naysayers wrong and produced a high quality Pinot Noir that wasn’t seen domestically at the time. Today, Willamette Valley in Oregon is synonymous with the best and most elegant Pinot Noir in the US.

After multiple trips to Burgundy and classes at UC Davis, in 1983, Jim Bernau, a Pinot Noir enthusiast and Oregon native, purchased the land that makes up today’s Willamette Valley Vineyards and planted the first 15 acres of Pinot Noir in what is known today as South Block. Using a small tractor, he cleared the land of old blackberry vines and plum orchard and replaced them with Burgundian clones of Pinot Noir (namely Pommard, Wadenswil, Dijon 667 and 777). The soil is a red iron rich volanic clay that is similar to the red clay found in the famed grand cru vineyard of Romanée St Vivant in Burgundy.

Each vineyard lot is fermented and barreled separately with the aim of identifying uniqueness of each plot. They are used to produce elegantly balanced Pinot Noir reflective of their origin and soil.

South Block is the original vineyard planted in 1983 by Jim Bernau. Its limited production of 10 barrels shows a medium-bodied character filled with fresh cherry and raspberry notes, with a touch of spice box and well-integrated oak. The wines spent 13 months in 54% new French oak which attributed to its subtle vanilla and sweet spice character and a rounded texture. Mouth-filling volume, rounded tannin and a plush texture, together with its lightness on palate, this is a Pinot Noir that is easy to love and is friendly with food. Its long lingering finish and elegant balance (with a very sensible 13.5% abv) remind us of its indisputable Oregonian root.

As a side note, we like to think that we’ve pulled plenty of corks on a daily basis but this is the first cork that we notice being sourced from a sustainably managed forest that is certified by the Forest Stewardship Council. Organically grown grapes, sustainably minded production methodology, classically balanced and layered wines, it is no surprise that the Willamette Valley Vineyards was named the Wine and Spirits’ Winery of the Year in 2011.

Vintage: 2008
Appellation: Willamette Valley
Grape: 100% Pinot Noir
Size: 750mL
Alcohol: 13.5%

title: Fayolle Fils & Fille Crozes-Hermitage â€œSensâ€ 2008
post_content:
Fayolle Fils & Fille Crozes-Hermitage “Sens” 2008

Cave Fayolle Fils et Fille is a small family domain that was established in 1870. Today, the brother-and-sister team of Laurent and Cecile Fayolle manage the family estate following their father and uncle’s split in 2002.

Crozes-Hermitage is situated along the eastern bank of the Rhône River in the northern Rhône. It is a region known for its red wine made from predominantly Syrah but it can be blended with up to 15% Marsanne and Roussanne. White Crozes-Hermitage is also produced from Marsanne and Roussanne but it remains a small percentage of total production.

This easy-drinking Syrah is a result of blending from various hillside parcels with old vines averaging 40 years old. Fermentation and ageing were carried out in neutral vats to preserve more fruit characters. Fresh black cherries and bramble berries are evident on the attack followed by hints of dried herbs and peppery notes. Tannins are elegant and well-resolved thanks to a few years of bottle age. It is expressive and accessible with lovely berry fruits. Pair this with any grilled meat but reach for the dry-rub instead of heavy BBQ sauces.

title: Wine Refrigerators
post_content:
Tradition holds that the best place for storing wine is in a dark, quiet, sturdy wine cellar or cave. However, not many of us possess the acres of land and underground storage necessary for these ideal conditions. If you’re a connoisseur developing your collection and trying to determine the best place to store your wine, you will want to consider the next best alternate to cellars: wine refrigerators.

Like any modern day innovation, there are a perplexing number of options to select from when determining which wine refrigerator is right for your needs. The top priorities are finding wine refrigerators with air circulation and humidity controls, along with specially treated glass to maintain constant temperature. These are not like regular refrigerators that just turn down the temperature and keep food cool. Maintaining a consistent, ideal environment for your wine is what a wine refrigerator specializes in, and you can find many impressive features on these state-of-the-art appliances. You will also want to consider what kind of style – what external décor – your wine refrigerator comes in so that it enhances the overall design of the room it resides in.

Also, before investing in this lavish purchase, consider how many bottles you are looking to store. Don’t just think about what you have today – consider what you see yourself having in the future as well. When in doubt, a larger refrigerator is better because it provides you with the option of expanding your collection. If you concede for a smaller refrigerator, you might eventually come to regret it if your collection exceeds your space. You find wine refrigerators in every shape, size, and style. Make sure you consider what your needs and wants are first, then go shopping to find the designs that match your desires.

Don’t make the mistake of using your kitchen’s refrigerator as your wine cooler or storage. Normal refrigerators will bring down a wine’s temperature far below what is ideal, and this will result in inferior wine quality. Over-chilled white wines possess a lackluster aroma and condensed flavor. If you want the most out of your wine, then you want to the most out of the environment in which you store it. Investing in a great wine refrigerator may be just the solution you need for your wine storage and consumption.

title: Sustainable Winemaking: 5 Ways Wine Is Going Green
post_content:
Environmental concerns are changing the way we live — and winemaking is no exception. Vintners are responding to consumer demands for more sustainable viniculture and packaging options, and they’re getting creative in the process. Wine kegs, paper bottles and water conservation initiatives are just some of the steps vintners are taking to protect the environment while producing delicious fine wines.

Wine Kegs Cut Costs and Meet Sustainability Goals

Restaurants that sell wine by the glass typically buy it in kegs, just like beer. These containers keep the wine fresh until the last glass is poured, so restaurants can buy high-quality wines at bulk discount prices to serve to their customers without the fear of losing wines due to oxidization.

Reusable wine kegs are cleaned and returned to the winery to be filled with more wine. That process can increase the wine’s carbon footprint, both in terms of the resources used to clean the keg and those used to transport it back and forth from the winery. New, recyclable wine kegs from a German company known as Shafer Container Systems can be added to curbside recycling, saving the cost of cleaning and transporting the keg back and forth to the winery.

Paper Wine Bottles Reduce Glass Waste

Wine drinkers around the world enjoy an astounding 17.5 billion bottles of wine a year, which leave behind 8.75 billion tons of glass waste. Wine therefore accounts for more packaging waste than any other food or beverage product. Truett-Hurst, Inc. recently introduced the PaperBoy, the first paper wine bottle. It’s made from recycled cardboard with a plastic liner — a fully recyclable product.

New Recycling System Reuses 90 Percent of Winery’s Water

It takes a lot of water to make wine — up to 20 gallons of water per gallon of wine, to be exact. Most of that water is used to rinse barrels and tanks. Jackson Family Wines and the University of California at Davis have been working together to develop a water recycling system that will recycle 90 percent of tank and barrel-rinsing water for up to 10 rinses. The water will also retain 75 percent of its heat, to save even more energy.

California Vintners Are Working Together for Sustainability

California’s winemakers understand that sustainability is good business — it makes their wines more appealing to consumers in the present and guarantees there will still be enough resources to make wine in the future. That’s why most California vintners have joined the California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance. They’re working on making Sonoma County the nation’s first 100 percent sustainable wine growing region.

Winemakers Tap the Vegan Market

While many vegans eschew animal products out of concern for animal rights, there’s no doubt the practice has environmental benefits, as well. A vegan diet reduces an individual’s carbon emissions by 1.5 tons a year due to the massive amount of resources required to raise livestock. Most wines contain some animal products, including gelatin, milk proteins and egg whites. Vegan wines are made without these products, making them both more sustainable and more appropriate for meatless diets.

As the sustainability movement gains momentum, the wine industry is making changes. While some traditions, like bottling wine in glass bottles, may fall by the wayside as a result, that’s a small price to pay to preserve the ancient tradition of winemaking as well as the Earth that allows it.

title: How Do Tannins Influence the Taste of Wine?
post_content:
Tannins are natural plant compounds found in the stems, seeds and skins of wine grapes. They’re also found in many other foods, like walnuts and tea leaves. The tannins in wine are what give it its texture and help it to age. As wine ages, the tannins separate from the liquid and find their way to the bottom of the bottle as sediment, in a process known as polymerization.

Processing Affects Tannin Levels

A wine’s tannin content depends on the type of grapes used to make it and how those grapes are processed. Red grapes have more tannins, so red wines are typically more tannic than white wines, although white wines can also have a high level of tannins.

Vintners take the tannic content of their grapes into account in deciding when to harvest and how to make their wines. Some varietals of grape are naturally low in tannins, like pinot noir, for example. Such varietals may be fermented “whole cluster,” with their stems included, to give the wine more tannins and a richer, more substantial texture. More tannic grapes, like syrah and cabernet sauvignon, are generally fermented without the stems.

How the grapes are pressed also affects the tannin content of the wine. For a lighter, less tannic wine, the vintner will give grapes a lighter pressing. A firm pressing squeezes more tannins out of the grape seeds, leading to a bolder, more tannic wine.

Vintners may soften young wine during the fermentation process using a technique called micro-oxygenation, which exposes the fermenting wine to small and carefully controlled amounts of oxygen. The barrels in which the wine is aged can also influence its tannic content. New barrels can significantly reduce a wine’s tannin content. For this reason, most vintners prefer older barrels that have already been used to ferment a few vintages.

How to Taste the Tannins in Wine

The way tannins influence the flavor of a wine is less a matter of taste and more a matter of texture. Wine is said to be astringent, firm or supple, depending on how tannic it is.

Though the other flavors in the wine, such as its fruitiness or sweetness, can certainly work in harmony with its tannins, a very tannic wine will have an overwhelmingly astringent, bitter texture. You will feel this bitterness throughout your mouth, in the back of your throat, on your gums and on the inside of your cheeks. Such a wine needs to be aged before drinking.

When you taste a firm wine, you’ll be able to distinguish the grape flavors interacting with the tannins, which you may perceive as a sensation of bitterness at the back of your throat. A tannic wine will also leave your mouth feeling dry after you swallow it. Supple wines with lower tannic contents will leave no feeling of bitterness at all.

A common mistake when tasting wine is to confuse its acid content with it tannin content. A tannic wine leaves your mouth feeling dry. If your mouth begins to water immediately after you swallow the wine, any bitterness you perceived was the result of its acid content, not its tannins.

Very tannic wines should be paired with red meats, while less tannic wines can be paired with seafood, poultry or vegetables. Learning to taste the tannins in wine can help you choose the wines that will best complement your meals.

A wine’s tannin content depends on the type of grapes used to make it and how those grapes are processed. Red grapes have more tannins, so red wines are typically more tannic than white wines, although white wines can also have a high level of tannins.

Vintners take the tannic content of their grapes into account in deciding when to harvest and how to make their wines. Some varietals of grape are naturally low in tannins, like pinot noir, for example. Such varietals may be fermented “whole cluster,” with their stems included, to give the wine more tannins and a richer, more substantial texture. More tannic grapes, like syrah and cabernet sauvignon, are generally fermented without the stems.

How the grapes are pressed also affects the tannin content of the wine. For a lighter, less tannic wine, the vintner will give grapes a lighter pressing. A firm pressing squeezes more tannins out of the grape seeds, leading to a bolder, more tannic wine.

Vintners may soften young wine during the fermentation process using a technique called micro-oxygenation, which exposes the fermenting wine to small and carefully controlled amounts of oxygen. The barrels in which the wine is aged can also influence its tannic content. New barrels can significantly reduce a wine’s tannin content. For this reason, most vintners prefer older barrels that have already been used to ferment a few vintages.

How to Taste the Tannins in Wine

The way tannins influence the flavor of a wine is less a matter of taste and more a matter of texture. Wine is said to be astringent, firm or supple, depending on how tannic it is.

Though the other flavors in the wine, such as its fruitiness or sweetness, can certainly work in harmony with its tannins, a very tannic wine will have an overwhelmingly astringent, bitter texture. You will feel this bitterness throughout your mouth, in the back of your throat, on your gums and on the inside of your cheeks. Such a wine needs to be aged before drinking.

When you taste a firm wine, you’ll be able to distinguish the grape flavors interacting with the tannins, which you may perceive as a sensation of bitterness at the back of your throat. A tannic wine will also leave your mouth feeling dry after you swallow it. Supple wines with lower tannic contents will leave no feeling of bitterness at all.

A common mistake when tasting wine is to confuse its acid content with it tannin content. A tannic wine leaves your mouth feeling dry. If your mouth begins to water immediately after you swallow the wine, any bitterness you perceived was the result of its acid content, not its tannins.

Very tannic wines should be paired with red meats, while less tannic wines can be paired with seafood, poultry or vegetables. Learning to taste the tannins in wine can help you choose the wines that will best complement your meals.

title: Matching wine with food in the right way
post_content:
Having a meal with good company, a pleasant atmosphere and a glass of good wine cannot go wrong. It is true that sometimes people tend to drink a little bit more than they should when they are enjoying a fine wine. However, real gourmands who love to keep their sense of taste with refined tastes on every meal should definitely keep an eye of what kind of wine they will drink during the meal. It can be a fun pairing exercise to do this, too.

 

It is not always easy to make a choice and you can sometimes see people in wine shops that are wandering around the aisles trying to figure out what will make their guests at the dinner satisfied. The truth is that there are wines that are appropriate for every type of meal, you just have to know how to choose them.

 

Red Meat

Red wine is the perfect option for roast beef, steak, barbecue or steak in sauce. One of the other most popular types of wine for these meals is Cabernet Sauvignon. Another wine grape variety that is suitable is the popular Merlot. Those who enjoy more intense tastes can have Chianti. Many people use this wine with venison. Brunello is another popular choice when it comes to venison.

 

Lamb

People who love lamb meat, especially baked lamb will also enjoy drinking Cabernet Sauvignon and merlot with it. In addition they can try black Pinot too. If you want to try something that is out of the ordinary you can try the sweeter Californian Zinfandel. This wine matches the taste of pork and you won’t be wrong if you choose Merlot with this meat. In addition,  you should try French Beaujolais as well as the fruity, light and sweet Dolcetto.

 

Veal

Red wine is suitable for veal too. You’ll have everything under control if you serve it with the previously mentioned Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Chianti, but you can also opt for a slightly acrid black Pinot that provides slightly stringing taste. This wine is an excellent choice if you choose to serve roasted duck or rabbit. Fine wine and wine with fuller flavor and strong aroma like Shyrasa will make the veal tastier.

 

Poultry

Chicken and turkey meat are interesting because you can use both white and black wine with them. Turkey steaks or turkey in a combination with pasta or rice will pair well with Beaujolais and Zinfandel.Roasted turkey, however, can be served with black Pinot or a wine with a slightly sour taste, like Riesling. This wine combines both sweet and bitter flavors. Deliciously roasted chicken meat will have an even better taste when you drink Merlot or Zinfandel with it. Some other recipes with this popular meat will look and taste better with Chardonnay which combines sweet, bitter and sour tastes in the best possible way. Finally, you can't really go wrong if you select white light Pinot wine.

title: How to Select the Best Wine Gift
post_content:
When attending a party of any sort, it can sometimes be difficult to select the proper courtesy gift. For fancy dinner parties and social events, a bottle of wine is a great gift option to consider. Not only is it classy, but it is also versatile and can be tailored to your specific needs, comes in a variety of price ranges and you can even buy wine online. There are many things to consider that will help you select the perfect wine gift for your host.

 

Think About the Receiver

 

Before you decide to give wine as a gift, consider the person you are giving it to. If you don’t know them very well, wine is something you can select if you'd like to introduce someone else to the joys of drinking wine. Consider your host and make sure that wine would actually be a good gift for them and if they would enjoy it or not. Choosing wine for someone who would not appreciate it is sure to leave a bad taste in his or her mouth.

 

Consider the Right Type of Wine

 

Wine is very versatile and there are many different types of wine out there to be considered. Here are a few things to keep in mind in terms of selecting the right kind.

 

  • Think about your host and consider their tastes, especially if you know them well. If you are unsure about their preferences, a simple generic type of white-wine or red-wine will work perfectly.
  • Chardonnay, Champagne or Merlot are great options for generic wines that most people love. Try to avoid sweet wines, as most people do not enjoy those.
  • Think about how much you want to spend on the wine as well as what the style of your individual is.
  • There are nice wine selections in any price range from new-york wine to rose-wine and a good rule of thumb is to spend between twenty and fifty dollars. It all depends on your host and their general preference.

 

Presentation is Everything

 

After you have selected the perfect wine for your gift, think about the presentation. For a general token of appreciation, and a more casual style, an unwrapped bottle is preferred. Other options include giving it in a fancy wine holder or simply wrapping it with a bag and tissue.

 

Gizmos and Gadgets

 

If you want to achieve a more elaborate gift, consider including various gadgets to go along with it. A wine bar kit that includes a corkscrew and other various tools is a great option. A cheese palate or other wine accessories can make that gift truly pop. It all goes back to thinking about the host and what he or she will prefer.

 

Wine can be a truly great gift of appreciation to someone and can be enjoyed by virtually anyone. If you are considering getting wine as a gift to your host or hostess, think about these pointers and be sure to select the perfect one. Buying and giving the perfect wine can make an impression that will last for ages to come.
short_content: Choose the best wine gift for your upcoming event.

title: Stuck on Gift Ideas? Grab Wine Online!
post_content:
Are you having trouble finding that perfect gift for your loved one or long lost friend? Stop worrying! Purchasing a bottle of wine online is not only convenient, wine makes an ideal gift to give to anyone.

Wine is often consumed as a hobby, during dinner, and at social gatherings. With many options to choose from, you can find the perfect wine to send to your family and friends. Choosing the right type of wine to send is easy once you identify the different types and what each one goes well with. 

Choose Red Wine

Red wine varies in taste from hints and aromas of blueberries and black olives to bell peppers and sweet cherries. Many of the red wines you will find are made from red grapes and carry a bold and strong taste along with them.

Red wine goes well with different types of foods depending on the type of red wine you choose. A light red wine is perfectly matched with soft shell fish such as crabs. Darker red wine pairs nicely with red meat, pasta, and more.

Often, red wine is enjoyed with dessert including a variety of chocolate cakes, candies, and fondue.

Choose White Wine

Made with white grapes, white wine carries undertones and flavors of fruits including pears, apples, pineapple, and papayas. Many people enjoy sipping on white wine because of its rich and light taste.

White wine goes well with a variety of food and is most commonly paired with cheese. In addition to cheese, white wine is a great accompaniment for roasted chicken, seafood, turkey, and more.

Many people choose to cook with white wine and use it in slow cooked foods and when they deglaze a pan.

Choose Champagne

Champagne is used as a celebratory drink and is a sparkling wine. The flavor is rich and the drink is bubbly. Champagne is often enjoyed with either citrus foods or desserts. Some great additional pairings include mussels and cheese.

Choosing the type of champagne you want for your friend or loved one will depend on the type of occasion you want them to use it for. Champagnes can be purchased specifically as a dessert champagne or they can be purchased for enjoying during dinner or at social gatherings.

Order Wine Online Today

Ordering wine online is one of the best gifts and most convenient ways to send someone you love a gift. Purchasing rose wine and other exotic wines online helps save you money and you can choose from a larger variety of choices. Since online wine retailers do not have to pay for shelving space and overhead, they are able to offer much more affordable pricing on their bottles of wines.

If you cannot seem to narrow down your options or you are looking for something a bit more, consider purchasing one of the wine gift baskets that many of the online wine retailers offer. The baskets come filled with goodies that pair well with wine.

title: What Are the Best Ways to Wrap a Wine Gift?
post_content:
There are many different occasions where people give wine as a gift. Whether it is a bottle of wine for a new father or a Christmas present for the special woman in your life, you don't want to go with just dull wrapping paper and a bow. A good red or white wine is meant to be savored, so the package that wine comes in should be savored as well. Whether you're buying red wine or white wine, the wrapping can really make your gift stand out. 

Read on below for some festive ideas on how to wrap the wine gift that you intend to give, no matter what the occasion.

 

Bundle it Up

If you are giving the gift of wine to a new or expectant father, you will want to dress the wine bottle up in style. You can knit a teeny hat and scarf to go over the bottle, or if you aren't handy with a needle and yarn, you can buy one instead. Make sure that they are blue or pink, in order to celebrate the occasion.

 

Give it Rustic Frills

Burlap bags have long been a Christmassy way to wrap a bottle of wine. If you have a friend that loves wine, but is a rustic country type person, then wrapping the wine in rustic frills, will satisfy their every need. Make sure to choose festive burlap and don't forget to add a little metallic paint and a silver ribbon to dress the package up.

 

Instant Labeling

If you are invited to a last minute Christmas party next season and need to carry a bottle of wine, pull one from your own stash. Of course, you don't want it to look like you did just that, so print an instant label with Merry Christmas and a festive tag on it, wrap the wine in it, and head out the door.

 

Wrap it in a Cozy Sweater

If you are heading out to a party in the dead of winter and want to present your host with a bottle of wine, you can dress it up in a cozy sweater fit for the season. You can simply take the sleeves off sweaters that have seen better days and wrap the wine in one. You have a gorgeous, colorful gift of wine and you didn't have to spend a dime.

 

Sock Time

If you have a tall bottle of wine that you can't find the right packaging for, then get out a pair of argyle socks and start wrapping. Make sure you choose an immaculately clean pair of course. An argyle sock is just the right size and height to wrap a tall bottle of red wine in and it will look festive as well.

These are just a few of the great and festive ways you can make the expensive wine you brought for a gift look even classier. From gift-wrapping it in an argyle sock to dressing it up in baby hats and a little shirt, you can be sure that the gift of wine you give will keep on giving, long after the bottle is gone.

title: What Are Some Popular Gift Wines?
post_content:
When it comes to giving wine as a gift, it can be easy to get confused. No two wine lovers have the same taste, so you are stuck with several questions. Would they prefer white to red? Would they prefer bitter to sweet? Would they prefer fruity to dry? With these questions in mind, you can read on below to find out what some of the most popular wines people like to receive for gifts are today.

 

Pinot Grigio

This is one of the most popular wines around the world and you would be hard pressed not to find at least one bottle of Pinot Grigio in every wine lovers wine cabinet. This wine also goes by a few other names, which are listed below.

  • Pinot Gris in France
  • Rulander in Germany

The style of this wine differs according to which part of the world you buy it from. For example, the Pinot Gris from France has a mineral taste, whereas the Pinot Grigio from Italy is more fruity and light.

This wine can be paired with a variety of foods and can be served with just about anything from the sea as well.

 

Sauvignon Blanc

This wine is the prefect wine to give as a gift for someone going on a romantic picnic. It is considered to be a warm weather wine, so in the spring this wine sees a lot of action. It is a dry white wine that is popular all over the known world and the subtle flavors include citrus, pineapple, and kiwi, according to which region the wine comes from.

Pair Sauvignon Blanc with anything from salad to sushi, or anything you can put on a grill and you have a wine that you can give as a gift over and over again.

 

Pinot Noir

Often considered a great wine to pair with a holiday dinner, the Pinot Noir has notes that range from a spicy horseradish to some type of dark fruit. The wine is the perfect gift to take to your hostess to go with the turkey for Thanksgiving dinner and a good time will be had by all involved.

 

Chardonnay

Who could ever forget Chardonnay when it comes to the most popular wines for gift giving? This type white wine is, of course, known worldwide. The wine is well known for its tropical fruit taste with just a little tang. There are also hints of vanilla and white fruit in many Chardonnay's according to which region you get yours from. Chardonnay is not only known around the world, it is one of America's most popular white wines as well.

These are just a few of the popular wines Americans are drinking today. From a white Chardonnay to a Pinot Noir to go with the Thanksgiving feast, you can be sure that these popular wines are well worth giving to friends and family as gifts any time of the year.
